instruction: In WordPress-Android, there was a bug where rotating the device while taking a photo to add to an Image block causes the captured photo to fail to upload and the app shows the error message “The media item couldn’t be retrieved”. This reliably happens when the user selects “Take a photo”, rotates the device during capture (triggering an activity recreation), then captures and confirms the photo. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is WordPress/src/main/java/org/wordpress/android/ui/posts/EditPostActivity.java (module: org.wordpress.android.ui.posts.EditPostActivity). The predicted root cause reason is that the media capture path (mMediaCapturePath) was not persisted across activity recreation on orientation change — missing save/restore of the capture path in onSaveInstanceState/onRestoreInstanceState, causing the app to lose the path to the captured photo and fail to process/upload it.

instruction: In WordPress-Android, tapping multiple bottom tabs at the same time (for example pressing the “Reader” and the “Notifications” buttons simultaneously after logging in) causes the app to crash instead of selecting one of the tabs or doing nothing. This reliably reproduces on several devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is WordPress/src/main/java/org/wordpress/android/ui/reader/ReaderPostListFragment.java (class: org.wordpress.android.ui.reader.ReaderPostListFragment). The predicted root cause reason is use of an invalid/view-tied Context (container.getContext()) and related resource access after the view may have been destroyed; a wrong context was stored/used instead of the fragment's stable context/getResources(), causing a crash when tabs were selected simultaneously.

instruction: In WordPress-Android, there was a crash in the editor when restoring activity state after navigating to the History tab. With "Don't keep activities" enabled, a user edits a published post, opens Options → History, backgrounds the app while History is open, and then reopens the app — the editor crashes during state restoration. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure: which file/module is responsible and what went wrong to cause the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is WordPress/src/main/java/org/wordpress/android/ui/posts/EditPostActivity.java (module: org.wordpress.android.ui.posts.EditPostActivity). The predicted root cause reason is that the ViewPager offscreen page limit was too low after the adapter gained more pages (offscreenPageLimit set to 3 while adapter has 5 pages), so the editor fragment was not retained/instantiated on restore. This led to code accessing UI/state on a null fragment/toolbar (NullPointerException/state accessed before initialization).

instruction: In WordPress-Android, there was an app crash that occurred when a user opened the editor, collapsed the top toolbar (if expanded), and then tapped the three-dots (overflow) button in the bottom Aztec editor toolbar while composing a new post. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is libs/editor/WordPressEditor/src/main/res/layout/fragment_aztec_editor.xml (WordPressEditor module: libs/editor/WordPressEditor). The predicted root cause reason is a missing XML attribute for the Aztec toolbar (the aztec:mediaToolbarAvailable flag was not specified), causing the toolbar to be initialized without the expected mediaToolbarAvailable state and leading to a crash when the three-dots action tried to use that state.

instruction: In WordPress-Android, users who host sites on shared SSL certificates could not log in: when the server presented a certificate whose name did not match the blog domain (SNI/hostname mismatch), the app failed with a generic "We can't log you in" flow and did not offer the same ability to proceed/accept the certificate that a browser provides. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/org/xmlrpc/android/TrustUserSSLCertsSocketFactory.java (Module: org.xmlrpc.android.TrustUserSSLCertsSocketFactory). The predicted root cause reason is overly strict hostname verification (use of a StrictHostnameVerifier / no BrowserCompat-style verification) and lack of a fallback to check and trust the presented X509 certificate against the app's SSL trust store when hostname verification fails, causing the SSL handshake to be aborted for shared-cert (name-mismatch) sites.

instruction: In social-app, there was an issue where the unread-message indicator for a conversation would briefly show a single unread message after opening or refreshing the app/window, then disappear moments later. This happened after interacting with a conversation and receiving a new message; on startup the UI would flicker an unread badge even though the convo's unread count was 0. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this transient unread notification behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/state/messages/events/agent.ts (module: src.state.messages.events.agent.MessagesEventBus). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect initialization of the log-polling state: the poller was started using the wrong basis (leading to initializing latestRev incorrectly), which caused a backlog of historical/non-embodied log events to be processed at startup and produced transient unread/optimistic updates. In short, improper initialization of latestRev using the wrong API/value caused startup processing of past logs and the flickering unread notification.

instruction: In element-x-android, there was a bug where an incoming call's UI and ringtone would disappear very quickly (often in 10-15 seconds or even under 1 second) on certain devices when the phone was locked and the call was not answered, making the incoming call unusable. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is features/call/impl/src/main/kotlin/io/element/android/features/call/impl/utils/ActiveCallManager.kt (module/class: io.element.android.features.call.impl.utils.DefaultActiveCallManager). The predicted root cause reason is that the flow handling of the ringing/activeCall state filtered out null values before flatMapLatest, so transitions to "no active call" were never emitted and previous flatMapLatest inner coroutines were not cancelled; this allowed lingering inner flows/timers to run and prematurely stop/dismiss the incoming call UI and ringtone (missing proper cancellation/cleanup when activeCall becomes null).

instruction: In the element-x-android repository, building the app for F-Droid failed: CI reported a reproducibility/build mismatch where a generated resource file (third_party_license_metadata) differed between variants (gplay vs fdroid), causing the F‑Droid build to be rejected. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle.kts (Module: app.build.gradle.kts). The predicted root cause reason is use of the Google OSS Licenses Gradle plugin which produced non-deterministic / variant-specific generated license metadata (ordering/format differences) leading to reproducibility/build mismatches; replacing it with a deterministic license-generation solution and per-variant copy tasks fixed the issue.

instruction: In talk-android, opening a conversation on a Samsung Galaxy S9+ running Android 10 caused the app to crash: the chat starts loading but after a second or two the app returns to the conversation overview and the conversation cannot be opened. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is a dependency version issue: incompatible / mismatched Mockito dependency versions (org.mockito:mockito-core vs org.mockito:mockito-android) that needed to be bumped/aligned, causing the crash.

instruction: In the talk-android app, call setup was flaky: when a call was started from the Android client and accepted in a web browser, sometimes the web could hear Android but Android could not hear the web and no remote participant appeared. Debugging showed that no SDP offer from the browser was ever received on Android, so the MediaStreamEvent never fired. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason that allowed this to happen.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/nextcloud/talk/activities/CallActivity.java (Module: com.nextcloud.talk.activities.CallActivity). The predicted root cause reason is premature/incorrect creation of PeerConnectionWrapper instances (creating connections for arbitrary signaling messages instead of only when an offer is expected), causing a race/invalid connection state and resulting in no offer being received from the browser.

instruction: In the talk-android app, users reported that when User 1 sent a Talk message to User 2, User 2 received no pop-up notification on their Android device even though a notification was expected. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file or module) and the root cause reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle (Module: app.build.gradle). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/mismatched test dependency: mockito-core was pinned to 4.10.0 (a test dependency version issue) and was bumped to 4.11.0 to address the problem.

instruction: In talk-android, there was a crash when a user tried to join a video call on a second Android device. In the reported scenario, User A starts a video call; User B opens the chat with User A and taps the "video call" button, and the Nextcloud Talk app on User B's device immediately crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle (Module: app.build.gradle) — the joda-time dependency declaration that was changed. The predicted root cause reason is a bug in the third-party joda-time library (the earlier version 2.12.2) causing a runtime crash on certain Android devices/versions; the issue was resolved by upgrading joda-time to 2.12.4 (i.e., a faulty/outdated dependency causing the crash).

instruction: In talk-android, there was a problem where after upgrading the server and using the Android Nextcloud Talk app, Android devices did not receive any push notifications: chat messages appeared in the conversation but produced no notification, and incoming calls did not make the device ring. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this lack of notifications.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle (module: app) — specifically the dependency com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-core (version pinned in this Gradle file). The predicted root cause reason is an issue with the Jackson core dependency version (outdated/buggy jackson-core 2.12.4) causing incorrect JSON deserialization/handling of push/call payloads (i.e., a dependency-version-related parsing bug), which was resolved by bumping jackson-core to 2.12.5.

instruction: In trezor-suite, after completing a firmware installation during onboarding the app became stuck on a “Device connected” screen and the user could not continue. The firmware was actually installed, but the Suite UI never proceeded — even after restarting the app the same blocking “Device connected” screen remained. This happened reliably on one machine (and intermittently on others); in one run a Bluetooth pairing screen appeared instead of the stuck screen. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the app to hang on the “Device connected” screen after firmware installation.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/connect/src/core/onCallFirmwareUpdate.ts (module: packages.connect.src.core.onCallFirmwareUpdate). The predicted root cause reason is a missing reference/argument for postMessage passed into getRebootMethod (postMessage was not provided), causing a runtime error in the reboot/wait-for-reconnect logic and preventing the reconnect flow from completing.

instruction: In trezor-suite, there was a bug where after reinstalling or updating a Trezor T's firmware (≥2.6.0) via Suite, the app appears to have the device connected but becomes mostly unusable: device-related UI like "+ Add wallet" behaves as if no device is available. This happens immediately after following the on-device firmware reinstall/update flow. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that lead to Suite not fully recognizing the device after the firmware reinstall.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/connect/src/core/index.ts (Module: packages.connect.src.core.index). The predicted root cause reason is an unhandled error thrown when rebooting the Model T into bootloader (device.run throws on disconnect), i.e., missing error handling/try-catch causing subsequent cleanup/lock-removal logic not to run.

instruction: In the trezor-suite repository/app, users observed that Coinjoin discovery progress sometimes goes backwards (progress decreases unexpectedly). This happened in scenarios such as when a user created a Coinjoin account and immediately opened the device selection/modal, after which discovery progress regressed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this incorrect progress behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/actions/wallet/coinjoinAccountActions.ts (module: packages.suite.src.actions.wallet.coinjoinAccountActions). The predicted root cause reason is a reentrancy/race condition: fetchAndUpdateAccount used stale/passed-in account data and performed a syncing check before re-reading the current account state, allowing Coinjoin discovery to be started twice in parallel (missing fresh state re-fetch/guard resulting in duplicate session starts).

instruction: In trezor-suite, there was an issue where the CoinJoin custom setup page became effectively unresponsive: after finishing discovery of a coinjoin account in the 23.6.1 release candidate, users could not change the mining fee or privacy level from the settings UI (controls did not respond). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is the proxy-memoize dependency referenced in package manifests (e.g. packages/suite/package.json (Module: packages.suite.package) and suite-common/wallet-core/package.json (Module: suite-common.wallet-core.package) — and other package.json entries / yarn.lock where proxy-memoize was updated). The predicted root cause reason is an upgrade/regression in the proxy-memoize library (upgrade to 2.0.4) that broke selector memoization, leading to stale/incorrect selector results and UI state not updating (memoized selectors returning wrong/stale values), causing the CoinJoin settings UI to be unresponsive.

instruction: In trezor-suite, there was a bug where starting CoinJoin while Tor was in the process of starting (Tor handshake not yet fully finalized) caused the UI to show the "Enable Tor for CoinJoin" modal stuck at 0% and block the CoinJoin flow. From a user perspective: if Tor is started just before opening CoinJoin, the modal never progresses and the flow cannot continue. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/components/suite/modals/RequestEnableTor.tsx (module: packages.suite.src.components.suite.modals.RequestEnableTor). The predicted root cause reason is that the modal did not handle the Tor "enabling/loading" state (it only checked whether Tor was already enabled), i.e., missing/incorrect handling of tor status/progress (missing isTorLoading detection or progress reflection), so the UI never reflected an in-progress Tor startup and failed to auto-close or continue when Tor became enabled.

instruction: In the trezor-suite app, there was a problem during a firmware update of a Trezor Model One: after being prompted to reboot the device to bootloader and confirming on the device, the suite failed to detect the device in bootloader mode (reconnecting the device did not make the bootloader appear). This happened reproducibly on some macOS machines but not on others. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong conceptually).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/hooks/firmware/useRebootRequest.ts (module: packages.suite.src.hooks.firmware.useRebootRequest). The predicted root cause reason is that the hook selected an automatic reboot mode for Trezor Model One (i.e., returning 'automatic' for that firmware range), causing an unreliable auto-reboot/bootloader detection on affected macOS systems; the automatic reboot behavior needed to be disabled/changed to 'manual'.

instruction: In the trezor-suite repository/app, there was a firmware update bug where, when updating a device running firmware older than 1.6.3 (and the device was already initialized), the Suite repeatedly installed only the intermediary firmware (1.10.0) and never completed the update to the latest firmware (1.10.2). Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/reducers/firmware/firmwareReducer.ts (module: packages.suite.src.reducers.firmware.firmwareReducer). The predicted root cause reason is that the firmware update state (targetRelease) was not updated/reset after the intermediary firmware was installed — i.e., missing state update to set the target release to the latest version (or reset when transitioning), causing the updater to repeatedly select/install the intermediary firmware.

instruction: In trezor-suite, there was an unhandled error during a firmware update on a Model One device: when the user aborted the firmware installation by pressing the device button (or reconnecting in bootloader and then aborting), Suite displayed an error and the firmware update flow failed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is the trezor-connect iframe bundle included in the app (packages/suite-data/files/connect/js/iframe.c177a20ab3c1b068663c.js — the trezor-connect module / iframe script packaged under packages/suite-data/files/connect/js, later replaced by iframe.a8737f59423666392ed3.js). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect/insufficient error handling in the connect iframe: the firmware-abort path produced a null/undefined error object and the code accessed error.code (or similar) without a null check, causing an unhandled TypeError (missing null-check / improper error normalization).

instruction: In trezor-suite, there was a bug in the Trade/Exchange UI: if a user types non-numeric text into the crypto amount input and then presses the 'All' (or a fraction) button, the app kicks off the 'Compare offers' process which never completes and appears to run indefinitely. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that allowed this behavior to occur.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/views/wallet/coinmarket/exchange/components/ExchangeForm/Inputs/index.tsx (module: packages.suite.src.views.wallet.coinmarket.exchange.components.ExchangeForm.Inputs) and also the analogous sell component packages/suite/src/views/wallet/coinmarket/sell/components/SellForm/Inputs/index.tsx (module: packages.suite.src.views.wallet.coinmarket.sell.components.SellForm.Inputs). The predicted root cause reason is that the code did not clear/reset the crypto/output amount input when the user pressed 'All' (missing setValue to empty the input), leaving non-numeric text in the form state; this invalid value was then used by the compose/compare-offers flow and caused the compare-offers process to run indefinitely (state with invalid input not handled/validated).

instruction: In trezor-suite, the app crashes when a user connects a device running firmware 1.6.0 while Suite is asking to connect a device (this happens during onboarding and when Suite is already started). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/components/firmware/FirmwareInitial.tsx (Module: packages.suite.src.components.firmware.FirmwareInitial) and packages/suite/src/components/firmware/FirmwareInstallation.tsx (Module: packages.suite.src.components.firmware.FirmwareInstallation). The predicted root cause reason is that the code assumed a cachedDevice object was always present and accessed its properties without null/undefined checks (missing optional chaining / null check), causing a runtime error when cachedDevice was undefined.

instruction: In the trezor-suite app, letting the application run idle for a long period (with a remembered wallet, transaction history and all coins enabled) caused the UI renderer to consume more and more memory and eventually the app became unusable when the renderer crashed from running out of memory. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure: which file/module in the repository is associated with the fix introduced, and what was the underlying reason the renderer crashed and left the user unable to continue.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite-desktop/src-electron/modules/crash-recover.ts (module: packages.suite-desktop.src-electron.modules.crash-recover). The predicted root cause reason is the renderer process running out of memory (OOM) — a memory leak / unbounded memory growth in the renderer leading to process termination and no prior recovery handling (renderer crash left the app unusable).

instruction: In trezor-suite, typing into the Transaction history search input while the wallet is still discovering transactions causes the app's render process to crash and the Suite window to go completely white (the typed characters also do not appear). This happens when starting to type a long string immediately after opening an account with a long transaction history and discovery still running. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/suite/src/views/wallet/transactions/components/TransactionList/components/Actions/components/SearchAction/index.tsx (Module: packages.suite.src.views.wallet.transactions.components.TransactionList.components.Actions.components.SearchAction.index). The predicted root cause reason is an unguarded / inefficient "fetch all" search implementation that triggered heavy or repeated fetchTransactions calls on every keystroke during discovery (missing state/guard to prevent repeated fetches), causing excessive work and ultimately crashing the renderer (performance/state-management bug).

instruction: In the ente repository/app, there was a failure: F‑Droid could not build the Ente Auth Android app. The failure appeared during the app build process (the problem surfaced around the authentication/two‑factor UI and related dependencies). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file or module was responsible and what specifically went wrong to cause the F‑Droid build to fail.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is auth/lib/ui/two_factor_authentication_page.dart (auth.lib.ui.two_factor_authentication_page.TwoFactorAuthenticationPage) and the related dependency specification in auth/pubspec.lock / auth/pubspec.yaml (the pinput package entry). The predicted root cause reason is an incompatible pinput package version / API change (mismatched widget/API usage between Pinput and the older PinPut API) causing a dependency/API incompatibility that broke the F‑Droid build.

instruction: In the AntennaPod app, there was a bug where after entering multi-select in the Queue, tapping the Select All action and then pulling down to refresh the list, the app became unresponsive (UI froze / stopped responding). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/ui/episodeslist/EpisodeItemListAdapter.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.ui.episodeslist.EpisodeItemListAdapter). The predicted root cause reason is that the adapter removed/failed to provide a click handler for the item's secondary action button while in action mode (setOnClickListener(null)), so selection toggling was missing/incorrect — a missing click listener / missing toggle-selection behavior that caused inconsistent selection state and led to the UI becoming unresponsive during refresh.

instruction: In the AntennaPod app, there was a security issue where an external app could cause AntennaPod to add podcast subscriptions or import feeds without the user's knowledge or consent simply by sending a broadcast intent. This could happen during normal app startup or when AntennaPod queried for feeds. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module in the codebase allowed this to happen and what went wrong that enabled unauthorized subscriptions/imports.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/spa/SPAReceiver.java (Module: de.danoeh.antennapod.spa.SPAReceiver) — additionally the receiver declaration in app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml and the SPA-related utility/call in app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/PodcastApp.java (Module: de.danoeh.antennapod.PodcastApp / de.danoeh.antennapod.spa.SPAUtil) are part of the vulnerable flow. The predicted root cause reason is that an exported BroadcastReceiver accepted and processed untrusted broadcast intents (and their extras) without validation or authorization (no permission checks / missing input validation), which allowed arbitrary apps to supply feed URLs that were imported/added silently into the app.

instruction: In the AntennaPod app, users observed that many network requests were missing or using the wrong User-Agent header (for example when tapping the download button or viewing the subscription screen). This can be reproduced by running the app and inspecting outgoing HTTP request headers — the User-Agent is absent in various places, potentially causing under-reporting of app usage. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for the User-Agent not being sent consistently.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is net/common/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/net/common/AntennapodHttpClient.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.net.common.AntennapodHttpClient) and ui/glide/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/ui/glide/ApOkHttpUrlLoader.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.ui.glide.ApOkHttpUrlLoader). The predicted root cause reason is that the User-Agent interceptor was not applied to all HTTP clients: it was registered as a network interceptor (and thus not applied in all request flows) and the Glide-specific OkHttp client did not include the UserAgentInterceptor, so some requests were sent without the User-Agent header (missing/incorrectly registered interceptor).

instruction: In AntennaPod, there was a problem where attempting to configure Nextcloud synchronization in Settings produced an unhelpful authentication failure: after entering a host and trying to log in the app did not present clear, actionable information (for example that a required Nextcloud/gpoddersync plugin might be missing). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ui/preferences/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/ui/preferences/screen/synchronization/NextcloudAuthenticationFragment.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.ui.preferences.screen.synchronization.NextcloudAuthenticationFragment). The predicted root cause reason is that the fragment's error handling did not surface a user-friendly generic message—errors were only shown via an inline/hidden error view or as raw text, so users were not informed to check network/server address or to install the gpoddersync Nextcloud plugin (missing/insufficient error presentation).

instruction: In the AntennaPod app, right-clicking (using a mouse) on an episode to open the context menu often caused the app to crash, whereas long-pressing the same item worked fine. The crash happened when trying to open the episode menu via a right-click; after opening the menu once with a long-press, subsequent right-clicks would sometimes stop crashing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/adapter/EpisodeItemListAdapter.java (Module: de.danoeh.antennapod.adapter.EpisodeItemListAdapter). The predicted root cause reason is that the code accessed a null longPressedItem when creating the context menu (no handling/initialization for mouse secondary-button right-click), resulting in a NullPointerException / missing null check.

instruction: In AntennaPod, there was a problem in the podcast discovery ("Find podcast" / "Add Podcast") flow: when the device network was turned off and the discovery screen showed an error like "Unable to resolve host ...", the error message remained after network recovery and the discovery list would not refresh unless the app was restarted (there was no way to manually retry/refresh). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/fragment/QuickFeedDiscoveryFragment.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.fragment.QuickFeedDiscoveryFragment). The predicted root cause reason is that the discovery fragment's error UI/handling did not provide a retry action (it used only a static error view/text and did not expose a retry button or retry handler), so after a network error the UI never offered a way to re-trigger loadToplist (missing retry control/incorrect error view handling).

instruction: In the AntennaPod app, tapping the fast-forward or rewind controls several times in quick succession (from the app UI, notification, or external controller) causes the app to become unresponsive: playback continues, but the app card and notification do not respond and the app must be force-stopped to regain control. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: determine which file/module was responsible for this behavior and explain what went wrong to cause the UI/notification freeze.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/service/playback/LocalPSMP.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.playback.LocalPSMP). The predicted root cause reason is a threading/concurrency bug in the seek-completion handling: the seek-complete logic spawned/used separate threads (and invoked callbacks while holding locks/using seekLatch) which led to races/deadlocks around playerLock/seekLatch and callbacks being run on the wrong thread, causing the app to freeze.

instruction: In AntennaPod, the app sometimes crashes when playback is resumed after being paused by an incoming call on bluetooth or wired headphones — the user flow is: start playback on headphones, get a call which pauses playback, keep the call long (about 10 minutes) so the interruption is long, then end the call and the app crashes as it tries to restart playback. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that leads to this crash (which file/module was changed to fix it, and what went wrong internally).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/service/playback/LocalPSMP.java (module: de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.playback.LocalPSMP). The predicted root cause reason is that audio-focus/audio callbacks remained registered after the playback service was stopped/killed, so audio focus change callbacks were delivered to a destroyed service whose executors had been shut down (i.e., listeners not removed / audio focus not abandoned), causing the app to crash.

instruction: In App, there was a crash when performing a basic export from the Report Actions menu: after selecting one or more expenses on a report (tap-and-hold → Select → choose items) and then choosing the Download/Export option from the actions menu, the app crashed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/hooks/useSelectedTransactionsActions.ts (module: src.hooks.useSelectedTransactionsActions). The predicted root cause reason is a missing/invalid action handler (missing null check or missing onPress callback) for the new Download/Export push-row action, which resulted in undefined being invoked (state/handler accessed before proper initialization) and caused the crash.

instruction: In tmail-flutter, there was a failure when selecting and moving a very large number of emails (1000+). When the user tried to move the large selection, the app sent the move request and the backend refused to process it due to the request containing too many items. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed the app to send that oversized request instead of performing the operation in smaller batches or respecting the server limits.  In tmail-flutter, there was [description of the bug/failure]. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/features/email/data/network/email_api.dart (Module: tmail_ui_user.features.email.data.network.EmailAPI). The predicted root cause reason is that the move operation built and sent a single oversized EmailSetRequest (more items than the server's maxSetSize) instead of splitting the work into batches or checking the session capability — i.e., missing batching/limiting logic based on session max set size, causing the backend requestTooLarge error.

instruction: In tmail-flutter, an email containing an inline image referenced by a CID was not rendered in the message body (the image appeared only as an attachment or not at all). The mail contained an reference but the corresponding MIME part had no Content-Disposition header. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is docs/adr/0038-logic-for-displaying-attachment-types-in-emails.md (and the attachment display logic in the core attachment/display module, e.g. core/lib/src/domain/attachment_display_rules.dart). The predicted root cause reason is that the display logic required Content-Disposition == 'inline' and did not treat a missing disposition (disposition == null) as inline; therefore CID-based parts with no disposition were not considered for inline display (missing handling / missing null check for disposition).

instruction: In the tmail-flutter repository, users reported that the composer UI showed two vertical scroll bars at once when replying to an email and switching to full-screen, making scrolling confusing and redundant. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the double-scrollbar behavior in the composer.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is pubspec.lock (the git dependency for the html-editor-enhanced package - https://github.com/linagora/html-editor-enhanced, package module html-editor-enhanced, version bumped from 3.1.1 to 3.1.2). The predicted root cause reason is a bug/regression in the html-editor-enhanced package that introduced a nested/duplicate scrollable area (the editor created its own scrolling behavior) causing two simultaneous scroll bars; fixed by updating the dependency to a version that removes the extra scrollable area.

instruction: In tmail-flutter, there was a calendar event banner that displayed a specific explanatory line (“We are canceling the event due to bad weather.”) even though the underlying .ics did not mention any reason; users expected a neutral message like “XYZ cancelled this meeting.” Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/features/email/presentation/extensions/calendar_event_extension.dart (Module: lib.features.email.presentation.extensions.CalendarEventExtension) and lib/main/localizations/app_localizations.dart (Module: lib.main.localizations.AppLocalizations). The predicted root cause reason is the use of a hard-coded/localized subtitle for canceled events (the getSubTitleEventAction logic + localization entries) which caused a speculative "bad weather" message to be shown in the UI instead of a neutral, data-driven cancellation message.

instruction: In the tmail-flutter repository, HTML links coming from some emails were displayed but not navigable: links that appeared to be quoted-printable / encoded (containing '3D' artifacts and starting with bare 'www') did not open when clicked in the app. This happened while rendering HTML email content in the app's HTML viewer. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: name the file/module that needed to be fixed and explain what went wrong (the underlying bug or missing handling that caused these links to be mis-handled).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/lib/presentation/utils/html_transformer/dom/sanitize_hyper_link_tag_in_html_transformers.dart (Module: core.presentation.utils.html_transformer.dom.SanitizeHyperLinkTagInHtmlTransformer). The predicted root cause reason is that href values were not properly sanitized/normalized: quoted-printable/encoded links and URLs starting with bare "www" (missing scheme like http/https) were not decoded or prefixed, so unstandardized/encoded hrefs were not recognized as valid clickable URLs (missing normalization/handling for encoded '3D' sequences and absent URL scheme / mailto handling).

instruction: In tmail-flutter, there was an issue where printing a long HTML email produced an unexpected blank first page when sending the message to the printer. This happened while printing long emails (HTML content) and caused the printed output to start with a blank sheet. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/lib/presentation/utils/html_transformer/dom/remove_style_tag_outside_transformers.dart (Module: core.presentation.utils.html_transformer.dom.RemoveStyleTagOutsideTransformer) and also related transformer core/lib/presentation/utils/html_transformer/dom/remove_max_width_in_image_style_transformers.dart (Module: core.presentation.utils.html_transformer.dom.RemoveMaxWidthInImageStyleTransformer) as wired in core/lib/presentation/utils/html_transformer/transform_configuration.dart. The predicted root cause reason is leftover CSS in the email HTML (style tags and inline image style like "max-width:100%") that affected print layout, causing a layout/overflow that produced a blank first page (missing removal/normalization of those style rules before printing).

instruction: In tmail-flutter, there was a UI bug where attachments for some emails were not visible in the email view even though the message list indicated an attachment. This occurred specifically for emails whose attachments included a Content-ID (cid). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to attachments not being displayed in the email detail view.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is model/lib/extensions/list_attachment_extension.dart (module: model.lib.extensions.list_attachment_extension.ListAttachmentExtension) and the related model/lib/email/attachment.dart (module: model.lib.email.attachment.Attachment). The predicted root cause reason is that the attachment filtering logic omitted attachments that had a Content-ID but were not actually inlined: the code only checked for absence of cid when deciding to display attachments outside the HTML content and lacked a check for the Content-Disposition (inline vs. attachment), causing non-inlined cid-marked attachments to be excluded from the displayed attachments list.

instruction: In tmail-flutter, there was a UI bug where calendar invites coming from Office 365 / Outlook did not show the expected blue bar in the email view (other event sources showed the blue bar correctly). This happened when opening emails that contained meeting invitations. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to Office 365 events not getting the blue bar.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/features/email/data/datasource/calendar_event_datasource.dart (Module: tmail_ui_user.features.email.data.datasource.calendar_event_datasource.CalendarEventDataSource). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect calendar event parse contract/behavior: the parse method used the wrong return type/structure (was returning/expected a List<CalendarEvent> instead of a Map<Id, List<CalendarEvent>> mapping events to blob IDs), so Office 365/Outlook event data were not associated/parsed correctly and the blue bar detection failed.

instruction: In the Kreate app, playback suddenly stopped on an Android 8 device and a crash report dialog popped up while the user was playing audio. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash: name the specific file/module that was responsible and explain what went wrong (the programming/runtime mistake or incorrect behavior that caused the crash).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/.../PlaybackService.kt (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is that the playback service was started with startService from background on Android 8 (Oreo), which triggered an IllegalStateException due to background service start restrictions — the code failed to use startForegroundService / startForeground properly (missing compatibility handling for Android O).

instruction: In the Kreate app, there was a problem when using Android Auto: if you connect the phone to a car, open Kreate from the car display, and try to play a track that has never been played before, the car shows “source error” and playback does not start. If you then open the Kreate app on the phone and select the same track, playback succeeds. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/kreate/service/MediaPlaybackService.kt (module: app:MediaPlaybackService). The predicted root cause reason is that playback is attempted before the media source is prepared or initialized when launched from Android Auto (lazy initialization/caching only happens when the phone UI is opened), causing the player to fail to open the data source (missing pre‑prepare or missing provisioning of the playable URI/permission).

instruction: In Kreate, there was a crash that prevented songs from being downloaded: on Android 14 using version V1.1.1-fy, a user opens the app, taps a song and then taps the download button — the app immediately crashes instead of downloading the song. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (the mediaPlayerKMP dependency entry / the io.github.khubaibkhan4:mediaplayer-kmp dependency). The predicted root cause reason is a buggy/incompatible third-party library version (mediaPlayerKMP 2.0.6) that caused a runtime crash in the download flow; upgrading the dependency to 2.0.9 fixed the issue.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a cosmetic bug where using the deselect-all button removed mods one-by-one with the expected sequential animation, but right-clicking the mods button to deselect mods cleared them instantly (all at once). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the differing deselection behavior between these two actions.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/SongSelect.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.SongSelect). The predicted root cause reason is that the RequestDeselectAllMods handler unconditionally cleared Mods.Value (directly setting an empty array), bypassing the mod selection overlay's DeselectAll logic/animation when the overlay was visible (i.e. missing the conditional call to modSelectOverlay.DeselectAll).

instruction: In the osu repository/app, SFX (sound effects) did not mute while the soundtrack was muted when holding the beatmap restart bind. This happened when using the hold-to-confirm restart (e.g., set confirmation speed to 500ms, hold the restart bind during autoplay and release at the last moment): the music was being muted but UI/game SFX continued to play. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Overlays/HoldToConfirmOverlay.cs (module: osu.Game.Overlays.HoldToConfirmOverlay). The predicted root cause reason is that sample/SFX volume adjustments were not applied/removed (missing audio.Samples.AddAdjustment and corresponding RemoveAdjustment), so samples were not muted when the track volume was adjusted.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a bug in the skin editor where selecting multiple skin elements and rotating them caused the elements to move off screen. When two or more elements were selected and a rotation was applied, the objects rotated around the top-left corner of the screen instead of around their expected center points, requiring manual repositioning. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Overlays/SkinEditor/SkinSelectionRotationHandler.cs (module: osu.Game.Overlays.SkinEditor.SkinSelectionRotationHandler). The predicted root cause reason is a coordinate-space mismatch: the rotation origin (default origin/local-space) was used without converting to screen space when rotating multiple objects, causing the pivot to be incorrect.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a visual bug where the spinner RPM overlay was being rendered on top of the spinner's spin and clear graphics during gameplay, causing those spinner elements to be covered (and the spinner-spin to disappear faster than expected). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game.Rulesets.Osu/Skinning/Legacy/LegacySpinner.cs (module: osu.Game.Rulesets.Osu.Skinning.Legacy.LegacySpinner). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect drawable layering/draw-order: the spinner spin/clear sprites were added in the wrong order in the children collection, causing the spinner-rpm overlay to be rendered above them (layering order bug).

instruction: In the osu repository, the editor's selection box sometimes removes vertical and diagonal scaling handles for sliders that visibly contain non-horizontal motion (for example, zig-zag shaped sliders). As a result, those sliders are treated as purely horizontal or vertical and cannot be scaled correctly unless you adjust them until they no longer appear "flat." Your task is to identify the root cause component (file or module) and the root cause reason explaining why the editor is misclassifying these sliders.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Utils/GeometryUtils.cs (Module: osu.Game.Utils.GeometryUtils). The predicted root cause reason is that the geometry calculation only considered slider start and end positions (ignored intermediate/control points) when computing surrounding quads/convex hulls, causing sliders with non-axis-aligned control points to be misclassified as purely horizontal/vertical.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a cosmetic UI bug: when using the ArgonJudgementCounterDisplay in vertical mode with the wireframe opacity set to 0.0, the Perfect/Great judgement count appeared visually misaligned while the value was a single digit (alignment looks correct for multi-digit values). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Graphics/UserInterface/Argon/ArgonJudgementCounterDisplay.cs (module: osu.Game). The predicted root cause reason is that hiding the wireframe via opacity (setting it to 0) did not preserve/layout-reserve the wireframe's spacing, so single-digit text was measured/positioned using a different (tight) width and ended up visually offset (i.e. the layout failed to account for a hidden element's reserved space).

instruction: In the osu repository/app, when browsing the song select screen with date-ranked grouping and difficulty sorting enabled, repeatedly pressing the left arrow (tapping it, not holding) could cause the UI to freeze and the last-selected beatmap to become unselected. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/osu.Game.csproj (module: osu.Game). The predicted root cause reason is inconsistent/outdated SignalR-related dependency versions (Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Client and related protocol packages) leading to runtime issues (dependency version mismatch causing unstable behavior such as freeze and selection loss).

instruction: In osu, there was a gameplay issue where the Flashlight mod displayed at very different sizes on different devices. Players reported that the flashlight appeared noticeably larger on Android than on PC while running the same version. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the inconsistent flashlight sizing across devices.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Rulesets/Mods/ModFlashlight.cs (module: osu.Game.Rulesets.Mods.ModFlashlight). The predicted root cause reason is that the flashlight used the wrong scaling source (it read PlayfieldAdjustmentContainer.Scale) and therefore did not account for additional nested/container scaling applied between the adjustment container and the playfield, causing incorrect effective flashlight size across different device aspect ratios/resolutions.

instruction: In osu, there was a bug in the Song Select search where queries using the '!=' (not equal) operator — for example typing "status!=ranked" — displayed no maps even though some should have matched. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused not-equal queries to fail in the song selection filter.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Select/FilterQueryParser.cs (osu.Game.Screens.Select.FilterQueryParser) and osu.Game/Screens/Select/FilterCriteria.cs (osu.Game.Screens.Select.FilterCriteria). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect handling of the 'not equal' operator ('!=') — the query parser and filter criteria did not implement or evaluate the not-equal operator, so '!=' queries were parsed or applied incorrectly and filtered out all results.

instruction: In osu, there was a visual glitch on the Select V2 header: when switching leaderboard scope away from Local the Sort dropdown produced a brief "step" — it remained at a non-zero width for a moment and caused the adjacent Group dropdown to pause/shift for a couple of frames while the scope was toggled. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/BeatmapDetailsArea_Header.cs (Module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.BeatmapDetailsArea_Header). The predicted root cause reason is a layout/visibility handling bug: the Sort dropdown was being hidden by animating/resizing its width to zero (and fading), causing intermediate non-zero width and layout shifts; the UI relied on resizing/hiding instead of keeping a fixed allocation and disabling the control, producing the visible "step".

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a cosmetic bug where the left side of song select carousel panels showed a thin (0–1px) white border or seam that changed width depending on horizontal position, making it especially noticeable during motion. This occurred across renderers (DirectX, OpenGL, Vulkan) and window modes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/Panel.cs (Module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.Panel). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect background/layout composition: background and padding containers plus an X offset and separate background layer produced a subpixel/rounding gap (missing coverage or incorrect masking) that manifested as a 0–1px seam on the left edge of panels.

instruction: In osu, there was a bug where the editor's background updated correctly the first time a beatmap's background was changed but failed to update on the second change. This happened while working in the editor and repeatedly changing a map's background: the first change was reflected in the editor, subsequent changes were not. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Backgrounds/EditorBackgroundScreen.cs (osu.Game.Screens.Backgrounds.EditorBackgroundScreen). The predicted root cause reason is that a previously cancelled CancellationTokenSource (cancellation token) was being reused for refresh operations, causing the scheduled background refresh to be immediately cancelled (missing recreation of a new CancellationTokenSource for each refresh).

instruction: In the osu repository, there was a multiplayer UI bug: if a player opened the difficulty selection for a playlist item while the beatmap was still being extracted/downloaded, then when the beatmap finished populating the difficulty menu the client immediately showed a "the selected beatmap's duration differs too much from the host's selection" error. The error persists until the player exits and re-enters the difficulty selection menu. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong to cause this behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/OnlinePlay/OnlinePlayFreestyleSelect.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.OnlinePlay.OnlinePlayFreestyleSelect.DifficultySelectFilterControl). The predicted root cause reason is that the filter criteria used the beatmap length and set id before they were initialized (lifecycle/order-of-initialization bug): itemLength and beatmapSetId were left at default values because CreateCriteria ran before the values were populated by the loader, producing incorrect length/set filtering and triggering the duration-mismatch error.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, hovering over a beatmap host's mini-profile in the beatmap listing did not load the user's online status or country flag (the mini-profile remained missing online/country info). The same hover works correctly in the comment section. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the beatmap host mini-profile to be missing online status and country flag information.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Online/API/Requests/Responses/APIBeatmapSet.cs (module: osu.Game.Online.API.Requests.Responses.APIBeatmapSet). The predicted root cause reason is that the beatmap set's author information was not being deserialized/populated correctly (missing/incorrect JSON mapping for the author/'user' data / helper properties), so the APIUser for the beatmap author stayed empty and online status/country could not be shown.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a cosmetic bug in the new song select UI: rank labels for sufficiently low ranks were being cut off at the edges in score/leaderboard entries (the rank text appeared truncated in the new SongSelectV2). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Utils/FormatUtils.cs (module: osu.Game.Utils.FormatUtils, method: FormatRank). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect rank formatting logic (an inappropriate decimal-precision threshold) that caused unnecessary one-decimal formatting for large rank values, producing longer text that overflowed and was clipped in the UI.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a regression in song select: when a user holds Shift and presses Left/Right arrow keys they expect to skip between groups (stopping at the currently selected beatmap), but in the affected version those keys do nothing. This happens while using the keyboard to navigate the beatmap/song select carousel. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/BeatmapCarousel.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.BeatmapCarousel). The predicted root cause reason is missing/unwired handling for Shift-modified navigation keys (Shift+Left/Shift+Right and Shift+Enter) — i.e. keyboard input with the Shift modifier was not being handled to traverse groups or toggle group expansion (missing keybinding/handler).

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a cosmetic bug in Song Select v2: when hovering over scores on the local leaderboard the leaderboard tooltip did not show the “PP” stat, while the same tooltip showed PP immediately when viewing/hovering global leaderboard scores. Your task is to identify the root cause component (the file/module that was changed) and the root cause reason explaining why the PP stat was missing for local leaderboard scores.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/BeatmapLeaderboardScore_Tooltip.cs (Module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.BeatmapLeaderboardScore_Tooltip). The predicted root cause reason is that the tooltip only added/displayed the PP row when Score.PP was already present (non-null), so scores from the local leaderboard with a null PP value had no PP row; there was no on-the-fly PP calculation/display for missing PP values.

instruction: In osu, there was a performance bug in Song Select v2: when starting certain beatmaps (notably one that hits the 00:00 timestamp) the game produced a short but severe lag spike very soon after the map started, making it impossible to hit objects immediately after the first slider. This only appears in the Song Select v2 flow and seems tied to beatmap/library changes occurring around gameplay start. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/BeatmapCarousel.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.BeatmapCarousel). The predicted root cause reason is that the beatmapSetsChanged event handler ran synchronously and performed expensive work during gameplay (e.g., costly collection/Items.IndexOf and filtering operations) instead of being deferred/scheduled; a missing scheduling/deferral caused the heavy work to execute at gameplay time and produced the lag spike.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a UI bug where, whenever background difficulty recalculation ran, every beatmap panel in the Song Select carousel appeared to update on each difficulty cache update — causing the carousel to jump around and producing noticeable lag spikes while interacting with song selection. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed these frequent, unnecessary updates to occur.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Graphics/Carousel/Carousel.cs (module: osu.Game.Graphics.Carousel.Carousel). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect CurrentSelection handling: keyboard/visual selection was being reset/invalidated too often due to wrong assignment order and an improper equality check (missing proper model equality handling), causing unnecessary selection invalidations and UI updates.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was an intermittent navigation bug in the song selection carousel: when pressing arrow keys (or other traversal keys) repeatedly or pressing multiple traversal keys within the same frame, the selected beatmap sometimes jumped unexpectedly to the top- or bottom-most item in the carousel. The problem does not occur when holding the keys down, only on repeated or near-simultaneous presses. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that allowed this behaviour to occur.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Graphics/Carousel/Carousel.cs (module: osu.Game.Graphics.Carousel.Carousel). The predicted root cause reason is that multiple traversal operations were being scheduled independently (different scheduled delegates/methods such as traverseKeyboardSelection, traverseSetSelection, traverseGroupSelection), allowing more than one traversal to be enqueued and processed in the same frame. This lack of unified/deduplicated scheduling for key traversal caused conflicting updates to selection state, resulting in unexpected jumps/resets.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a bug where the Song Select V2 leaderboard did not animate correctly when the application window was resized: leaderboard score entries (especially those partially visible at the edge of the screen) could look wrong and their resize animation would not play. This issue happened during window/display mode changes (but not during in-game UI scaling). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/BeatmapLeaderboardScore.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.BeatmapLeaderboardScore). The predicted root cause reason is that the rank label/container was placed inside a layout cell that could become masked/IsMaskedAway when partially offscreen (due to use of an auto-sized GridContainer cell), preventing the container from being updated so its resize transform/animation never ran.

instruction: In osu, there was a bug where the rank change sound effect failed to play if only LegacyRankDisplay was present when the game loaded into gameplay. When using a legacy skin that only provides a LegacyRankDisplay, the rank-up / rank-down samples do not load and no sfx are played on rank changes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Skinning/LegacyRankDisplay.cs (module: osu.Game.Skinning.LegacyRankDisplay). The predicted root cause reason is that LegacyRankDisplay did not implement or initialize rank-change sample playback (missing SkinnableSound fields / PlaySamples binding and related loading logic), so when it was the only rank display present the rank change samples were never loaded or played.

instruction: In the osu repository, the Song Select V2 standalone beatmap panel displayed the wrong status for difficulties: after editing a single difficulty that had a different status, all difficulties in the carousel appeared to have the same status (for example, showing as local/loved when only one difficulty was). Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason explaining why the panel showed an incorrect status across difficulties.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/SelectV2/PanelBeatmapStandalone.cs (osu.Game.Screens.SelectV2.PanelBeatmapStandalone). The predicted root cause reason is that the code used the beatmap set's status (beatmapSet.Status) instead of the individual difficulty's beatmap status (beatmap.Status), causing the panel to display a set-level status for all difficulties rather than their per-difficulty status.

instruction: In osu, there was a bug where, if the application UI language was set to Thai, the "Add Audio Track" flow became unresponsive and users could not add audio tracks (switching the UI back to English made the feature work again). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Utils/TagLibUtils.cs (module: osu.Game.Utils.TagLibUtils). The predicted root cause reason is that TagLib's file creation/MIME type detection was culture-sensitive (dependent on CultureInfo.CurrentCulture), causing incorrect MIME/type resolution under the Thai locale; the code used TagLib.File.Create directly (missing a culture-invariant wrapper), which led TagLib to mis-detect or fail to open the audio file and thus prevented adding the track.

instruction: In osu, there was a cosmetic bug where some sliders (notably cursor sensitivity and UI scaling) did not update their displayed value/tooltip while the user was adjusting them — the value text remained unchanged until the change was committed, unlike other sliders. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Graphics/UserInterface/OsuSliderBar.cs (Module: osu.Game.Graphics.UserInterface.OsuSliderBar). The predicted root cause reason is that the slider's display formatting used the wrong source value: the GetDisplayableValue method used the slider's CurrentNumber.Value (a stale/committed value) instead of the passed-in live value parameter, causing the tooltip/text to not update while dragging (i.e., wrong variable used leading to stale tooltip display).

instruction: In osu, there was a cosmetic bug where the "Delete difficulty" option in the editor's file menu did not appear as a destructive (red) action like other delete options, instead showing as a standard menu item. This was noticed when opening the editor's file menu to remove a beatmap difficulty. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Edit/Editor.cs (Module: osu.Game.Screens.Edit.Editor). The predicted root cause reason is that the "Delete Difficulty" menu item was created with the wrong menu item type (MenuItemType.Standard) instead of the destructive type (MenuItemType.Destructive), so it was not rendered as a red/destructive action.

instruction: In the osu repository, there was a cosmetic bug on the song select screen: when playing beatmaps with non-integer BPM values while a rate-adjust mod (e.g. Double Time) was applied, the BPM shown on song select could be rounded incorrectly or display an incorrect range (for example, showing a different high-end value or a single integer instead of the expected range). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the incorrect BPM display.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Utils/FormatUtils.cs (osu.Game.Utils.FormatUtils). The predicted root cause reason is that BPM values were being rounded before the rate adjustment (pre-rate/double-rounding) instead of multiplying the raw BPM by the rate first and then rounding, causing incorrect displayed BPM for non-integer values with rate mods.

instruction: In osu, beatmap objects (for example sliders and hitobjects) sometimes disappear after scrolling the timeline while editing, and using undo (Ctrl+Z) does not restore them. This happens during normal mapping workflows when placing or dragging objects and interacting with the timeline or other mouse inputs. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) responsible for this behavior and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that allowed the editor state/undo system to become corrupted.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Edit/Compose/Components/BlueprintContainer.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.Edit.Compose.Components.BlueprintContainer). The predicted root cause reason is that mouse-up events other than the left button were treated as ending/affecting a drag, which corrupted drag/change state so change transactions were not properly finalized (EndChange never called), leaving the undo/redo system locked and causing objects to disappear.

instruction: In osu, there was a cosmetic usability issue: when placing objects on the timeline the yet-to-be-placed preview markers were visually almost identical to already-placed objects, making it hard for users to tell which markers were previews and which were actual placed objects. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Edit/Compose/Components/Timeline/TimelineBlueprintContainer.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.Edit.Compose.Components.Timeline.TimelineBlueprintContainer). The predicted root cause reason is that the placement preview used indistinguishable visual styling (insufficient contrast / wrong visual state) for the placement blueprint—missing or inappropriate styling (e.g., relying on a nearly identical color rather than a distinct selection state), so previews could not be visually differentiated from placed objects.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a gameplay/ui audio bug: when interacting with the main menu (for example, pressing the osu! logo on the title screen) a loud star-fountain activation sound was heard and kiai behaviour was triggered even for classic skins that do not visually show star fountains. The sound could also play while the game was not active/in the background. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this incorrect audio behaviour.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Menu/KiaiMenuFountains.cs and osu.Game/Screens/Play/KiaiGameplayFountains.cs (modules: osu.Game.Screens.Menu.KiaiMenuFountains and osu.Game.Screens.Play.KiaiGameplayFountains). The predicted root cause reason is that the fountain activation SFX was loaded/played as a non-skinnable/global sample and played unconditionally (including when the game was in the background), so skins without a fountain sample still produced the sound. In short: missing use of a skinnable sound (and a missing background/IsActive check) causing unintended playback.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, there was a UI bug: when opening the Settings overlay to jump to a specific control (for example, to calibrate the global offset), the target control would sometimes not be visible because a previous settings search term was still active. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Overlays/SettingsOverlay.cs (module: osu.Game.Overlays.SettingsOverlay) and the related SettingsPanel file osu.Game/Overlays/SettingsPanel.cs (module: osu.Game.Overlays.SettingsPanel). The predicted root cause reason is that the settings search textbox state (previous search term) was not cleared before showing the overlay at a specific control, causing the search filter to hide the target control; additionally the search textbox was private/ inaccessible, preventing the overlay from clearing it previously.

instruction: In osu, there was an issue where the "High precision mouse" option's tooltip in the settings UI displayed incorrect wording and capitalization (the tooltip text used the wrong terminology and capitalization). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Localisation/MouseSettingsStrings.cs (module: osu.Game.Localisation.MouseSettingsStrings). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect localisation string content (typos/terminology and capitalization errors in the tooltip text).

instruction: In the osu repository, there was a bug where, while spectating a multiplayer lobby with multiple players waiting for results, the results screen applause/music played multiple times (sounded too loud or overlapping) instead of a single applause. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behaviour.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Ranking/ResultsScreen.cs (Module: osu.Game.Screens.Ranking.ResultsScreen). The predicted root cause reason is that the applause sound drawable/sample was not being added to the screen hierarchy before being played (missing AddInternal(rankApplauseSound)), causing the applause to be played multiple times/with incorrect/overlapping volume when spectating multiple players.

instruction: In osu, there was a cosmetic bug: the editor's "Test!" button visually contracts when held down, producing a gap so you can see through the button while trying to test a beatmap. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Edit/Components/Timelines/Summary/TestGameplayButton.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.Edit.Components.Timelines.Summary.TestGameplayButton). The predicted root cause reason is the base press animation (scale transform) on OsuButton was allowed to run when the button was held down — the component did not prevent/override the base scale animation on mouse down/up, causing the button to contract and reveal a gap.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, spectating an online player showed different Repel mod behaviour for the viewer than for the player being watched. As a result, spectators could not see the true gameplay and could give incorrect/wrong scores to the player. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/osu.Game.csproj (module: osu.Game) — specifically the SignalR-related package references (Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Client and the SignalR protocol packages: Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocols.MessagePack / Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocols.NewtonsoftJson). The predicted root cause reason is using mismatched/outdated SignalR client/protocol package versions that caused incorrect serialization/deserialization (or protocol incompatibility) of spectator/gameplay state (the Repel mod), leading to inconsistent mod state between the player and the spectator.

instruction: In the osu repository, there was a crash to desktop and loss of ability to change the beatmap offset when pressing the +/− keys (for example during a break in multiplayer or at the start of a map). Sometimes the game would immediately stop when attempting to adjust the offset and at other times offset changes would be disallowed unexpectedly. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Screens/Play/PlayerSettings/BeatmapOffsetControl.cs (module: osu.Game.Screens.Play.PlayerSettings.BeatmapOffsetControl). The predicted root cause reason is an async race / missing-guard: a Realm write callback (and other code paths) could update UI state (Current.Value / related controls) while the control was disabled/near cut-off or being disposed, causing an invalid access (null/invalid state) — i.e. lack of guards around updating Current and related UI in async callbacks.

instruction: In the osu repository/app, right‑clicking the random button in song select no longer reverts the selection (the expected “random rewind” behavior). Using the alternate binding (shift+F2) still works, and the issue is specific to mouse right‑click on the random button. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is osu.Game/Input/Bindings/GlobalActionContainer.cs (Module: osu.Game.Input.Bindings.GlobalActionContainer), with a related migration change in osu.Game/Database/RealmAccess.cs (Module: osu.Game.Database.RealmAccess). The predicted root cause reason is that the right mouse button was configured as a global binding for the AbsoluteScrollSongList action, causing right‑click events to be captured/swallowed by the global action system (and/or persisted in user bindings) so the UI no longer received the right‑click to perform the random rewind.

instruction: In the mullvadvpn-app repository, users on Linux reported frequent, unexplained VPN disconnects while using the desktop application. The disconnects happened at seemingly random intervals (tens of minutes to a couple of hours) and affected both WireGuard and OpenVPN modes; the same machine did not show the problem when using the vendor config files with wg-quick, and the issue did not appear on Windows. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these Linux disconnects. Your answer should name the file or module responsible and explain what went wrong to cause the repeated connection drops.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is talpid-core/src/tunnel/wireguard/network_manager.rs (module: talpid_core.tunnel.wireguard.network_manager.NetworkManager). The predicted root cause reason is a conflict between the daemon-created WireGuard interface and NetworkManager: the tunnel interface was created/managed outside NetworkManager (missing/incorrect integration), causing NetworkManager to interfere/reset the device (DNS/routes/device state) and trigger frequent disconnects.

instruction: In the pocketpal-ai app, loading any q_4_0_4_8 quantized model caused the app to crash while attempting to open the model (q4_0_4_4 models loaded successfully). This happened when selecting or switching to those q_4_0_4_8 models from the model picker/settings — users expected q4_0_4_8 to run faster on devices that support i8mm but the app would immediately crash instead. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module in the repository was responsible for this failure and why it caused the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/store/ModelStore.ts (module: src.store.ModelStore). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect or missing handling/mapping for the q4_0_4_8 quantized model (i8mm) — the code did not recognize/map the q4_0_4_8 quantization to the proper backend/lib, causing the loader to attempt an incompatible/native backend and crash.

instruction: In SeriesGuide, there was a bug where after signing into Trakt only Movies were synced while Series were not. The user signed into Trakt (More > Trakt), forced a sync and observed that movie items were imported but series items did not appear in the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/assemble-test-lint.yml (module: github.workflows.assemble_test_lint).
