The predicted root cause reason is that the GitHub Actions workflow was pinned to an outdated actions/checkout version/commit (v3.6.0); updating the checkout action to v4.1.1 resolved the issue.

instruction: In the forge app, an AI vs AI match crashes during AI decision-making: when the AI controls Territorial Kavu and on the next turn chooses to Attack, the game eventually crashes and the match aborts after a delay. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-ai/src/main/java/forge/ai/ability/CharmAi.java (module: forge.ai.ability.CharmAi). The predicted root cause reason is an unintended infinite recursion: the method called itself instead of delegating to the superclass (missing/incorrect call to super.checkApiLogic), causing a StackOverflowError.

instruction: In forge, there was a bug where during AI-only games (for example Prossh vs Rainbow) the game would become stuck/hung for hours while the application remained responsive; the run ended with an error in the logs. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/cost/CostPayment.java (module: forge.game.cost.CostPayment). The predicted root cause reason is iterating directly over a mutable ManaPool while it may be modified, causing a ConcurrentModificationException — missing a defensive copy before iteration.

instruction: In the forge repository/app, there was a gameplay bug where effects phrased like "each player/opponent loses X life unless they discard X cards" sometimes failed to default to life loss in a corner case: an AI player with no cards in hand (and at 1 life) did not lose the life they should have, and in one case an AI paid a discard cost using the wrong number of cards. This occurred when resolving UnlessCost-style costs (discard-based). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-ai/src/main/java/forge/ai/ComputerUtilCost.java (module: forge.ai.ComputerUtilCost) together with the related changes in forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/cost/CostPayment.java and forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/cost/Cost.java (modules: forge.game.cost.CostPayment and forge.game.cost.Cost). The predicted root cause reason is that cost-checking used the wrong payer when evaluating additional/unless costs: the code defaulted to or used the SpellAbility's activating player instead of the actual player who must pay the discard cost (missing/incorrect payer parameter propagation), causing the engine to check the wrong hand/state and thus fail to fall back to life loss.

instruction: In the forge app, there was a gameplay bug where an opponent's creature enchanted by Sigil of Sleep put a damage trigger on the stack, the creature was destroyed in response, and after priority passed the trigger still dealt damage even though the enchantment (and/or creature) was no longer on the battlefield. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason — name the specific file/module that was changed to fix this, and explain what went wrong conceptually (what code/pathological condition allowed the trigger to still apply).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/card/Card.java (module: forge.game.card.Card). The predicted root cause reason is that ability resolution used stale/incorrect card state (last-known information) or failed to validate that the source/enchantment was still on the battlefield before applying its effect — i.e., a missing check for the source still being in play (using a stale reference), allowing the on-damage trigger to resolve after the source had been removed.

instruction: In the forge app, there was a bug where the AI cast Ecological Appreciation with X=1 and then chose four copies of Herald's Horn, even though those cards did not meet the spell's creature type, mana value, and different-names constraints. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed the AI to select illegal cards.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-gui/res/cardsfolder/e/ecological_appreciation.txt (module: forge_gui.res.cardsfolder.e.ecological_appreciation_txt). The predicted root cause reason is an erroneous AI logic flag in the card definition (an inappropriate AILogic value) that caused the AI to use the wrong selection algorithm and ignore the card filters/constraints (ChangeType, mana value, DifferentNames), allowing invalid card choices.

instruction: In forge, there was a crash observed while playing in Adventure mode: when starting/creating an adventure event (for example, after attempting to collect draft rewards) the app would sometimes crash while generating the event opponents/participants. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-gui-mobile/src/forge/adventure/data/AdventureEventData.java (module: forge.adventure.data.AdventureEventData). The predicted root cause reason is that the code sampled a list of enemies before filtering out invalid entries (wrong order of operations), resulting in too few valid participants and an index-out-of-bounds when populating the participants array.

instruction: In the forge repository/app, there was a problem with the newly added Insidious Roots card: when creature cards left your graveyard the expected effect (creating a Plant token and then putting +1/+1 counters on your Plants) did not always occur during gameplay. This happened in situations where cards left the graveyard but the card did not produce the token/counters as described. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-gui/res/cardsfolder/upcoming/insidious_roots.txt (the Insidious Roots card script in the cardsfolder upcoming resource). The predicted root cause reason is that the trigger configuration incorrectly restricted the zone change trigger (TriggerZones set to Battlefield) for a ChangesZoneAll trigger, so the effect only fired for moves to the battlefield instead of firing whenever creature cards left the graveyard (i.e., wrong trigger zone parameter).

instruction: In the forge repository/app, there was a crash when the card Bloodthirsty Adversary entered the battlefield: instead of prompting the player to pay 2R to copy a spell from their graveyard, the game crashed as the creature entered play. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused this crash when the Adversary entered the battlefield.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/ability/SpellAbilityEffect.java (Module: forge.game.ability.SpellAbilityEffect). The predicted root cause reason is that duration-based effects (e.g. those using durations like UntilHostLeavesPlay / UntilLoseControlOfHost / UntilUntaps) were being applied without verifying the host card was in a valid zone (on the battlefield or stack). In other words, a missing validation check allowed effects that depend on the host being in play to run when the host was not yet in the correct state, causing a crash (state accessed before proper initialization / missing guard for duration applicability).

instruction: In the forge repository/app, there was a crash that occurred in commander mode when the card Patriar's Humiliation killed the opponent's commander: after casting and resolving the spell and the commander died, the game crashed instead of moving the commander to the command zone and offering the expected options. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-ai/src/main/java/forge/ai/AiController.java (module: forge.ai.AiController). The predicted root cause reason is that AiController.confirmAction assumed a non-null SpellAbility and did not handle the ChangeZoneToAltDestination player action mode, leading to an unhandled case and a NullPointerException / crash when sa (or its API) was null or when the ChangeZoneToAltDestination mode was requested (missing null check and missing handling for that mode).

instruction: In the forge repository/app, there was a bug where resolving a particular triggered ability (Reflect) produced the token for the wrong player: when the ability was resolved the token ended up controlled by the opponent instead of by the player who triggered/activated the ability. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the token being created for the wrong player.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/spellability/SpellAbility.java (Module: forge.game.spellability.SpellAbility). The predicted root cause reason is that the copied/triggered SpellAbility retained incorrect context (host card / controller) when created or executed, so the ability used the original ability's controller/host instead of the activating player — effectively a missing or incorrect transfer/update of controller/host information on the copied ability.

instruction: In the forge repository/app, the AI in a HBG draft kept casting Dragon's Fire and the spells resolved as dealing 0 damage. The reporter could not reproduce the issue when playing the card themselves, but whenever the AI had the card it repeatedly produced the 0-damage outcome. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led the AI to produce this incorrect resolution behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-ai/src/main/java/forge/ai/AiCostDecision.java (module: forge.ai.AiCostDecision). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect handling of the RevealOrChoose additional cost: the AI did not handle the "reveal from hand or choose from battlefield" cost case, so it failed to select an appropriate Dragon to reveal/choose (causing the spell's damage calculation to use an invalid/zero value).

instruction: In forge, there was an issue where a creature that should have assigned deathtouch damage when it lost all counters sometimes failed to deal deathtouch damage if a replacement effect changed where it went from the battlefield (for example, being moved to the command zone as a commander or exiled/redirected by a card like Anafenza). In normal cases the damaged creature dies as expected, but when the graveyard/zone replacement takes effect the target can survive. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/GameAction.java (module: forge.game.GameAction) and forge-game/src/main/java/forge/game/Game.java (module: forge.game.Game). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect/ill-timed capture/storage of last-known-information (LKI): LKI was saved from the wrong object or at the wrong point (missing or inappropriate copying) when zone replacement effects occurred, so the LKI used for damage/deathtouch resolution did not reflect the pre-change state.

instruction: In forge, there was a bug where Ancient Bronze Dragon's triggered ability failed to place +1/+1 counters on the chosen creature(s). After the Dragon dealt damage to a player and the d20 was rolled, the subsequent effect that should put counters on the target creature(s) did not occur. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is forge-ai/src/main/java/forge/ai/GameState.java (Module: forge.ai.GameState). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect handling of RememberTargets: targets were not being recorded properly (wrong use of the remember API/logic), so the chosen creatures were not remembered for the later effect and therefore no +1/+1 counters were applied.

instruction: In the wgtunnel app, users reported that when their WireGuard network used only IPv6 addresses, the VPN worked on IPv6-enabled networks but stopped delivering IPv6 connectivity when the phone was on an IPv4-only public Wi‑Fi. After switching back to an IPv6-enabled network the tunnel resumed working; when returning to the IPv4-only network some connections persisted briefly (likely due to keepalives) but then failed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is userspace/src/main/java/app/wgtunnel/tunnel/WireGuardManager.kt (module: userspace).  The predicted root cause reason is that the userspace WireGuard engine picked/used an IPv6 transport address (or otherwise failed to prefer an IPv4 endpoint) when the underlying network only provided IPv4, i.e., incorrect DNS/address selection / missing IPv4 fallback for the peer endpoint leading to attempted IPv6 transport on an IPv4-only network.

instruction: In the notes-android repository/app, users reported that notes continually failed to sync and the app showed an "Upload failed not acceptable" error when attempting to synchronize. This happened while performing a sync/upload operation and prevented notes from being uploaded. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/codeql.yml (module: github.workflows.codeql.yml) and .github/workflows/scorecard.yml (module: github.workflows.scorecard.yml). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/incompatible pinned github/codeql-action (init/analyze/upload-sarif) version in the workflow files which caused the SARIF/upload step to be rejected (HTTP 406 Not Acceptable) — i.e., the CI workflow used an incorrect/old GitHub Action version leading to upload failure.

instruction: In notes-android, there was an intermittent synchronization failure: when a user manually triggered a sync the app sometimes showed “synchronization failed: no network connection” even though the device had a working network connection and other apps were able to use the network. Force-closing and reopening the app temporarily fixed the problem. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/it/niedermann/owncloud/notes/persistence/NoteServerSyncHelper.java (Module: it.niedermann.owncloud.notes.persistence.NoteServerSyncHelper). The predicted root cause reason is that the sync helper used a stale/cached network status (isSyncPossible returned false) because the network status was not refreshed/updated before checking — updateNetworkStatus was not accessible/called (missing network status refresh / wrong access to update method), causing false "no network" errors.

instruction: In the keyman repository, a user observed that Build-bot commands in commits and PR body were being parsed incorrectly: when the commit/PR contained a command like 'Build-bot: skip build:windows,developer', the build system produced warnings about an invalid platform string such as 'common_windows:windows:developer' (platform names appeared concatenated with colons). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that produced this incorrect parsing/concatenation of build platforms.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/build/ci/trigger-build-bot.inc.sh (Module: resources.build.ci.trigger-build-bot.inc.sh). The predicted root cause reason is a parsing/word-splitting bug in the Build-bot command handling: improper use of arrays/IFS and incorrect function argument/parameter handling in the message parsing/update logic caused multiple command/platform tokens to be concatenated and mis-split (resulting in platform strings like 'common_windows:windows:developer' instead of separate platform entries).

instruction: In the Keyman repository, an Android release pipeline failed during the publish step: the job attempted to copy a release .apk but the expected APK file was not present, causing the release to fail. This happened as part of the automated TeamCity release build for Android. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/teamcity/android/android-actions.inc.sh (module: resources.teamcity.android.android-actions.inc.sh) and the related release script resources/teamcity/android/keyman-android-release.sh (module: resources.teamcity.android.keyman-android-release.sh). The predicted root cause reason is that the build variant flag was not propagated/passed through the build scripts (missing/omitted --release argument / missing ARGS forwarding), so a debug build was produced and the expected release APK file did not exist.

instruction: In keyman, there was a failure during a Keyman Developer release build on the CI agent: a pre-build step that downloads the symbol server index caused the build to abort because the Windows MSBuild executable could not be found. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/teamcity/developer/keyman-developer-release.sh (module: resources.teamcity.developer.keyman-developer-release.sh). The predicted root cause reason is that the release script invoked a Windows PowerShell/rsync-based download step which triggered MSYS path rewriting / altered the environment so that the Windows msbuild.exe could not be located (i.e. incorrect invocation/path translation of Windows tools from the MSYS shell).

instruction: In the keyman repository, a web release build step was failing: while preparing/uploading web artifacts the build log showed the sourcemap-path-remapper configure step failing because jq could not open keyman/package.json (file not found). This happened during the CI release/zipping/uploading actions for a web release. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason — name the file/module that needed the fix and explain what went wrong that caused the missing-file/error behaviour.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is web/ci.sh (path: web/ci.sh, module: web.ci.sh). The predicted root cause reason is a mismatched environment variable name (typo): the script looked for SEVEN_Z_HOME but the build agents used SEVENZ_HOME, so the 7-zip path/compression command was not detected/configured leading to the release packaging step failing.

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a failure during the CI alpha release build: the 'zip and upload artifacts' step failed and caused the build to exit with an error while attempting to package and upload release artifacts. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/teamcity/web/keyman-web-release.sh (Module: resources.teamcity.web.keyman-web-release.sh). The predicted root cause reason is that the PowerShell helper script was invoked using a relative filename instead of the script's full path, so the -File argument pointed to a non-existent file when executed (missing path when calling the PowerShell script).

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a failure during the Web release build: the publishing step for the Web release failed with a missing s.keyman.com directory error and the build exited with a non-zero status during the "zip and upload artifacts" phase. This happened as part of a TeamCity script transition and prevented the release from being published. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/teamcity/web/keyman-web-release.sh (module: resources.teamcity.web.keyman-web-release.sh). The predicted root cause reason is that the release script ran with the wrong working directory (the PowerShell artifact-upload script was invoked from the incorrect CWD), causing relative paths (such as the s.keyman.com directory) to be not found.

instruction: In keyman, there was a failure during an Android release build: the CI log showed a shell error about an unbound variable (reporting that ‘TIER’ was unbound) while generating Play Store release notes. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module) and the root cause reason explaining why this unbound variable error occurred.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/KMAPro/build-play-store-notes.inc.sh (Module: android.KMAPro.build-play-store-notes.inc.sh). The predicted root cause reason is a leftover reference to the old variable name 'TIER' after a rename to 'KEYMAN_TIER', causing an unbound/undefined variable error (e.g., when shell option set -u is enabled).

instruction: In the keyman repository, a CI build/publish run produced script-related failures: a build step for the keyman-version component reported a jq iteration error and subsequent npm publish steps warned that package.json errors were auto-corrected (notably that invalid "scripts" entries were removed). This happened during automated packaging/publishing of multiple npm packages. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is common/web/keyman-version/package.json (module: common/web/keyman-version). The predicted root cause reason is that package.json lacked a valid "scripts" entry (the build/publish tooling/jq expected to iterate over .scripts but found null), i.e., a missing/invalid "scripts" field causing the jq iteration error and npm warnings.

instruction: In the keyman repository, a release build failed while configuring Play Store publishing for the kMAPro app: the build process could not access the TIER value used to select the Play track, causing the build to abort during project evaluation. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/KMAPro/kMAPro/build.gradle (Module: android.KMAPro.kMAPro.build.gradle). The predicted root cause reason is that the 'tier' variable was declared with too-narrow/incorrect scope (not visible where the Play publisher configuration used it), causing the build evaluation to fail due to the missing/undefined tier value.

instruction: In the keyman repository/app, the macOS Keyman app crashed on startup on machines running macOS Catalina (10.15) while trying to determine or request the user's Privacy & Security (Accessibility/PostEvent) permission. This happened at launch when the app attempted to check or prompt for the required permission, preventing the app from starting. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module (component) contained the defect, and what specifically went wrong (the root cause reason) that led to the crash on Catalina.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mac/Keyman4MacIM/Keyman4MacIM/Privacy/PrivacyConsent.m (module: mac.Keyman4MacIM.Keyman4MacIM.Privacy.PrivacyConsent / PrivacyConsent). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect macOS availability check leading to calling a PostEvent/ListenEvent API that is not present on macOS 10.15 (Catalina). In other words, the code assumed the API was available on 10.15 (per documentation) but it was only safe to call on 11.0+, so the wrong availability guard caused the app to call an unavailable API and crash.

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a packaging failure: building the libkeymancore Debian package triggered Lintian errors related to the package's symbols file and caused the package to be rejected. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is linux/debian/libkeymancore2.symbols (module: linux.debian.libkeymancore2.symbols) and also touches linux/debian/libkeymancore1.symbols (module: linux.debian.libkeymancore1.symbols). The predicted root cause reason is that C++ std/template implementation symbols were present in the Debian .symbols file (i.e., C++ mangled symbols from std:: leaked into the symbols listing), causing Lintian to complain (symbols-file-contains-current-version-with-debian-revision); the packaging lacked filtering/ignoring of those C++ symbols even though only the C API is intended to be exported.

instruction: In keyman, there was a CI build failure on Windows where the FirstVoices installer prereq step attempted to run the keyboards build script to produce keyboard packages but the build script rejected its arguments and the build aborted. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is oem/firstvoices/windows/src/inst/Makefile (Module: oem.firstvoices.windows.src.inst.Makefile). The predicted root cause reason is that the Makefile invoked the keyboards build.sh with incorrect command-line arguments (missing the required -k parameter), causing build.sh to report an invalid parameter and fail.

instruction: In keyman, there was an intermittent CI build failure where downloading keyboard and lexical-model package files from downloads.keyman.com failed (e.g. a download step reported "Downloading ... failed with error 3"), causing the resource download step to abort the build. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/build/build-download-resources.sh (module: resources.build.build-download-resources). The predicted root cause reason is that the curl-based download commands had no retry/backoff behavior (missing retry handling), so transient network/download failures caused the script to fail the build.

instruction: In the keyman repository/app, there was a Windows installer problem: after a release, package installation stopped finding the bundled MSI and always attempted to download a remote version instead. The failure was tied to differences in the generated setup.inf between a working and a non-working self-installer. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what specifically went wrong) that led to the installer not recognizing the bundled MSI.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is windows/src/desktop/setup/Keyman.Setup.System.InstallInfo.pas (module: Keyman.Setup.System.InstallInfo.TInstallInfo). The predicted root cause reason is that the setup.inf parsing did not trim whitespace from lines, keys, and values (and the setup.inf generation introduced trailing spaces), causing section/header comparisons and the MSI filename check to fail (so the bundled MSI path was not recognized).

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was an app crash: the FV Keyboards stable-16.0.142 iOS build crashed immediately on launch while under Apple review. The release had no functional code changes from the previous stable build, though it was built with updated tooling/environment. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ios/Cartfile (and the iOS KeymanEngine project file: ios/engine/KMEI/KeymanEngine.xcodeproj, module: KeymanEngine). The predicted root cause reason is a missing/unembedded third-party Zip framework (dependency packaging/linking failure) that caused the dynamic loader to fail to load the framework at app startup.

instruction: In the keyman repository/app, Launchpad builds were failing for Ubuntu Mantic (23.10) packages — e.g., arm64 builds reported as "Failed to build" when the CI tried to build for the Mantic distribution. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these failing Launchpad builds. In particular, which file/module was responsible and what went wrong to cause Launchpad to attempt or perform those failing builds?
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is linux/scripts/launchpad.sh (module: linux.scripts.launchpad.sh). The predicted root cause reason is that the release/distributions configuration included the unsupported 'mantic' distribution (the distributions variable contained 'mantic'), causing Launchpad to attempt Mantic builds that fail due to an upstream/packaging incompatibility; the build script needed to exclude/disable Mantic builds (remove/comment out 'mantic').

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a build failure: compiling the core component with GCC 13 failed while processing include headers, producing errors that a fixed-width integer type (such as uint32_t) was not defined. This happened when building core headers that are used by both C and C++ code. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/include/keyman/keyboardprocessor_bits.h (module: core.include.keyman.keyboardprocessor_bits). The predicted root cause reason is a missing #include <stdint.h> in that header, causing fixed-width integer types like uint32_t to be undefined when compiling with GCC 13.

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a Windows build failure: the Text Editor component's symbol packaging/upload step failed during automated builds, causing the overall build to fail when producing debug symbols for the text editor. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is windows/src/support/texteditor/Makefile (Module: windows.src.support.texteditor.Makefile). The predicted root cause reason is a missing 'wrap-symbols' Makefile target (i.e., the Makefile did not define the symbol-wrapping/upload rules), so the build attempted to invoke a symbols packaging step that wasn't implemented in this module.

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a CI build failure on the stable-16.0 branch: mac packaging shell scripts that compute file sizes and hashes for DMG/artifacts failed during the iOS/mac build pipeline, causing the build to abort. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mac/Keyman4MacIM/write-download_info.sh (module: mac.Keyman4MacIM.write_download_info) and resources/shellHelperFunctions.sh (module: resources.shellHelperFunctions). The predicted root cause reason is that the scripts invoked the stat command without using the absolute system path, allowing an incompatible/stat binary from PATH (e.g., a Homebrew-provided stat) to be used; this caused file-size extraction to fail (missing/incorrect stat invocation) — fixed by calling /usr/bin/stat explicitly.

instruction: In the keyman repository/app, there was a failure in the release/build pipeline during the npm publish step: the publish step aborted due to a shell script syntax error, and on Windows builds lines that looked like shell comments were executed as commands (causing noisy errors) while the build scripts did not fail-fast. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these failures (which file/module was at fault, and what exactly went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is resources/build/npm-publish.inc.sh (Module: resources.build.npm_publish_inc_sh). The predicted root cause reason is a mismatched shell control structure (an extra/stray 'fi' left in the script) causing a bash syntax error; additionally the script assumed builder.inc.sh was already included (so bash-style comments could be embedded when the snippet was used in the wrong context), leading to comment lines being interpreted in a Windows batch context and scripts not failing fast.

instruction: In the keyman repository/app, there was a bug where Keyman Developer's compiler emitted invalid JavaScript when keyboards used unquoted single-digit numbers in stores/if() comparisons. In practice a compiled keyboard contained malformed escape sequences for those stored numeric values which caused the generated JavaScript to be incorrect and fail at runtime. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is developer/src/tike/compile/CompileKeymanWeb.pas (module: developer.src.tike.compile.CompileKeymanWeb). The predicted root cause reason is that hexadecimal escapes were generated using a single-digit width (IntToHex with width=1), producing single-digit escapes like "\x1" instead of zero-padded two-digit escapes like "\x01" (missing padding), resulting in invalid JavaScript.

instruction: In the keyman Android app, there was a bug where rapid typing sometimes produced missing letters (and sometimes malformed suggestions). While a user was typing quickly, some key presses would be ignored and sequences of characters would be missing even though every key was touched. This happened intermittently during fast input and appears related to how touch/longpress behavior was being handled. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/KMEA/app/src/main/java/com/tavultesoft/kmea/KMKeyboard.java (module: com.tavultesoft.kmea.KMKeyboard). The predicted root cause reason is that touch/gesture movement detection in the keyboard's touch handling erroneously triggered longpress/subkey behavior on tiny finger movements (or otherwise mis-handled subkey window state), which blocked or swallowed subsequent key events and caused letters to be omitted during rapid typing.

instruction: In keyman, there was an attempt to release version 14.0 but the CI build failed when publishing the APK to Google Play — the publishReleaseApk step failed and the release could not be completed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/KMAPro/kMAPro/build.gradle (module: com.tavultesoft.kmapro). The predicted root cause reason is that the project was targeting/compiling against API level 29 (targetSdkVersion/compileSdkVersion set to 29), which did not meet the Play Store requirement to target API level 30, causing the publish task to be rejected.

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was an installation failure when installing the keyman Debian package: during post-installation the installer reported it was "called to compile glib schemas" and then failed with "glib-compile-schemas: command not found", causing package configuration to abort. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is linux/keyman-config/debian/control (module: linux.keyman-config.debian.control). The predicted root cause reason is a missing dependency: the post-install script invoked the glib-compile-schemas tool which was not available because libglib2.0-bin was not listed in the package Depends, causing the command-not-found error and installation failure.

instruction: In the keyman repository, there was a severe performance problem when tapping into the emulated text input (TouchAliasElement) on touch/mobile devices: focusing a textarea with only a few thousand characters could take many seconds, and a profile showed nearly all of the touchstart time was spent trying to place the caret. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that produced this slow caret placement behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is web/source/dom/domEventHandlers.ts (module: com.keyman.dom.DOMEventHandlers). The predicted root cause reason is an inefficient caret-placement implementation in the touch-focus handler (setFocusWithTouch) that performed an expensive, iterative/linear search (repeatedly moving the caret and measuring positions) rather than using an optimized search, causing excessive work and very poor performance when the text content was large.

instruction: In keyman, there was a progressive input lag on mobile devices: after typing a moderate amount of text (roughly a dozen lines on Android) each keystroke became visibly slow (hundreds of milliseconds per key). Profiling pointed to the text transform construction path (the code that computes and applies changes to the output target) being invoked many times per keystroke and dominating the time. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is common/core/web/keyboard-processor/src/text/outputTarget.ts (module: com.keyman.text.OutputTarget). The predicted root cause reason is an inefficient O(N^2) algorithm in OutputTarget.buildTransformFrom that repeatedly used SMP-aware per-character access (String.kmwCharAt) / scanned from the start of the string, causing excessive repeated work and poor handling of surrogate pairs; in short, a missing algorithmic optimization (inefficient string traversal) causing severe performance regression.

instruction: In keyman, there was a crash on Windows when a user clicked the “(none)” link in the Hotkeys dialog while trying to change a hotkey — the application consistently crashed on that action. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is windows/src/engine/kmcomapi/com/system/keymancontrol.pas (Module: windows.src.engine.kmcomapi.com.system.keymancontrol.TKeymanControl) and the related engine export files windows/src/engine/keyman32/k32_globals.cpp (Module: windows.src.engine.keyman32.k32_globals) and windows/src/engine/keyman32/KEYMAN32.DEF (Module: windows.src.engine.keyman32.KEYMAN32). The predicted root cause reason is a binary compatibility/interface stability regression: COM/interface methods and exported endpoints were removed/reordered (vtable/exports changed), causing a mismatch between the caller and the updated DLLs (missing/reordered exports or vtable entries) which led to the crash.

instruction: In keyman, there was a recurring test failure during Debian package builds: unit tests for the keyboard processor package crashed on armhf and s390x while running tests that load and process keyboard files. The failures only occurred on those architectures and appeared while the test suite was initializing/expanding keyboard data read from .kmx files. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is common/core/desktop/src/kmx/kmx_file.cpp (and its declaration in common/core/desktop/src/kmx/kmx_processor.h) — specifically the FixupKeyboard method in module common.core.desktop.kmx.KMX_Processor. The predicted root cause reason is incorrect handling of file-relative offsets/empty arrays in FixupKeyboard: pointer arithmetic/offset expansion produced an invalid pointer for empty key arrays (and used NULL in arithmetic), causing an invalid pointer/cast on certain architectures (armhf/s390x) and resulting in crashes (bus errors).

instruction: In the keyman repository/app, there was an iOS app crash that occurred shortly after a user tapped “download” to install a keyboard package. The crash happened while the Installed Languages screen was handling package download/update notifications (e.g., download failure or batch update completion) and was observable as an immediate app crash or freeze when the package operation finished. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ios/engine/KMEI/KeymanEngine/Classes/Settings/InstalledLanguagesViewController.swift (Module: ios.engine.KMEI.KeymanEngine.Classes.Settings.InstalledLanguagesViewController). The predicted root cause reason is improper use of DispatchQueue.main.sync (synchronous dispatch to the main queue) from code that is already running on the main queue, causing a deadlock/crash (i.e., incorrect main-thread concurrency handling; should use async instead).

instruction: In the keyman repository (keymanweb), selecting a keyboard on keymanweb.com caused the page to lock up for several seconds while the on-screen keyboard (OSK) was built. Profiling showed the UI was spending almost all of that time during OSK construction (the desktop OSK build), causing very slow keyboard load times. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that made OSK building so slow.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is web/source/osk/oskManager.ts (module: com.keyman.osk.OSKManager). The predicted root cause reason is repeated, expensive parsing/loading of the OSK-related web cookie (redundant loadCookie calls / missing caching of cookie-derived state), causing excessive CPU work during OSK construction and dramatically slowing keyboard load.

instruction: In keyman, there was an iOS app crash that occurred while performing resource updates: when a package download/install failed during a batch update the app crashed instead of gracefully reporting the failure. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ios/engine/KMEI/KeymanEngine/Classes/Resource Management/ResourceDownloadQueue.swift (Module: ios.engine.KMEI.KeymanEngine.Classes.ResourceManagement.ResourceDownloadQueue). The predicted root cause reason is an out-of-bounds/incorrect array access when recording download errors for a batch (wrong index used when writing into batch.errors), causing a crash (invalid index access/force unwrap).

instruction: In the keyman repository, building the Debian package for the keyman-config component failed during packaging: the package build aborted because a required gsettings schema file was not present in the files to be installed, so the packaging step could not copy and compile the schema. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this packaging failure. In particular, state which file or module needed to be changed and why the missing schema file was not included during packaging.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is linux/keyman-config/MANIFEST.in (module: linux.keyman-config.MANIFEST.in). The predicted root cause reason is that the gsettings schema file com.keyman.gschema.xml was not listed in the MANIFEST.in, so it was not included in the package sources/manifest and therefore missing during dh_install packaging, causing the build to fail.

instruction: In keyman, there was a problem where upgrading Keyman Desktop from 9.0 to 11.0 beta caused all user settings and installed keyboards to be lost; the upgrade did not preserve existing keyboards and settings and left behind the old 9.0 program data folder. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is windows/src/desktop/setup/UfrmRunDesktop.pas (module: windows.src.desktop.setup.UfrmRunDesktop.TfrmRunDesktop). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect initialization/usage of upgrade flags (a copy-paste/variable-name bug: CheckVersion10Upgrade was resetting FCanUpgrade9/FRunUpgrade9 instead of FCanUpgrade10/FRunUpgrade10), causing the upgrade path to not run/preserve settings.

instruction: In the android app repository, there was a problem where the "Always show first view when opening app" option stopped working after upgrading Home Assistant core (reported on core 2025.5). Users with the option enabled expected the app to start on the default/first dashboard view on next launch, but the app would instead remain on the previous view or not present the default dashboard. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed this behavior to occur.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/kotlin/io/homeassistant/companion/android/webview/WebViewActivity.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.webview.WebViewActivity) and the related external bus message file app/src/main/kotlin/io/homeassistant/companion/android/webview/externalbus/ExternalBusMessage.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.webview.externalbus.ExternalBusMessage). The predicted root cause reason is that the WebView navigation logic relied on injecting DOM-manipulating JavaScript and did not clear/replace the WebView history, and there was no support for the newer external-bus "navigate" command (ExternalBusMessage was not structured/serializable to send the new navigate payload). Together this caused the app to fail to reliably navigate to and present the first/default view on start.

instruction: In android/app, there was a failure where users connecting to a Home Assistant server protected by HTTP authentication could not reliably log in via the companion app. When the in-app HTTP auth prompt appeared it would often be quickly covered by a "couldn't connect" error dialog after a couple seconds, preventing users from entering credentials or causing them to get locked out. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/webview/WebViewActivity.kt (io.homeassistant.companion.android.webview.WebViewActivity). The predicted root cause reason is that the HTTP-auth flow in WebViewActivity did not properly guard against other webview error UI and interrupted the auth prompt (isShowingError was not set/managed when the auth dialog was shown), and additionally the auto-proceed path used nullable-safe calls for httpAuth fields (httpAuth?.username / httpAuth?.password) which prevented correct automatic credential submission.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android app, opening the Allow List selection popup for the 'Next Alarm' sensor caused the app to hang or appear to crash, preventing the user from choosing which apps are allowed to register alarm notifications. This occurred when tapping the Allow List option to open the selection dialog. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/settings/sensor/SensorDetailViewModel.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.settings.sensor.SensorDetailViewModel). The predicted root cause reason is that the code loaded setting/dialog entries synchronously on the UI thread (blocking/long-running work), causing an ANR/hang; missing asynchronous loading and loading-state handling for dialog entries.

instruction: In the android repository/app, there was a problem where picture/camera widgets failed to display SVG images — when an image entity produced an SVG the widget showed a blank/missing image instead of the SVG. This occurred in the context of updating the app's image loading code for widgets. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/HomeAssistantApplication.kt (Module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.HomeAssistantApplication). The predicted root cause reason is that Coil was configured/used without an SVG decoder (missing coil-svg dependency or missing registration of the SVG decoder in the ImageLoader), so SVG images could not be decoded and therefore did not display.

instruction: In the android repository/app, there was a bug where notification action URIs generated from a template did not open the expected todo entity and instead opened the default /lovelace view; the clickAction behavior was unaffected. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect handling of the templated notification URI.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: kotlinx-coroutines). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/incorrect dependency version of kotlinx-coroutines (1.8.1) causing the notification template URI handling to behave incorrectly; upgrading to kotlinx-coroutines 1.9.0 fixes the issue.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android app repository, users reported that the network sensors were not reporting the Wi‑Fi IP address while the device was connected to Wi‑Fi on a HUAWEI Mate 10 Pro running EMUI 12. The app showed no Wi‑Fi IP address despite an active Wi‑Fi connection. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (Module: gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is that the change only bumped the io.sentry:sentry-android dependency from 7.19.0 to 7.19.1 and did not change the network sensor code — the actual bug is an issue in the network sensor implementation: incorrect/insufficient handling of Wi‑Fi IP retrieval on certain Huawei/EMUI devices (platform/API/permission handling), causing the IP address to not be detected.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android app repository, users reported that when creating or editing a Service Button Widget for the nodered.trigger service, SWITCH entities (for example, switch.* entities) do not appear in the list of selectable entities. This happens while attempting to pick an entity target for that service in the widget configuration UI. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to SWITCH entities being omitted from the candidate list.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/widgets/servicebutton/ServiceButtonEditViewModel.kt (module: :app).  The predicted root cause reason is incorrect parsing/filtering of the service's target/entity domains when building the selectable entity list (a logic bug that excludes 'switch' entities for the nodered.trigger service — e.g., wrong field checked or missing domain handling leading to switches being filtered out).

instruction: In the android app, there was an issue where Android Auto's vehicle screen got stuck on a perpetual loading state: the app showed a loading spinner forever and did not display any entities or favorites when opening the vehicle UI. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/vehicle/MainVehicleScreen.kt (Module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.vehicle.MainVehicleScreen). The predicted root cause reason is that the loading logic relied on domains.isEmpty() and did not track whether domains had been loaded (missing/incorrect initialization/state flag). This caused the loader to remain visible indefinitely when domains were initially empty or not yet marked as loaded (missing domainsAdded check).

instruction: In the android repository's WearOS companion app, users were unable to activate or deactivate any sensors from the app. Toggling a sensor appeared to fail each time (already-active sensors like battery level continued to be reported, but new toggles had no effect). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (Module: gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect/outdated Hilt dependency version (hilt was set to 2.48.1) causing a dependency/DI-related runtime issue that prevented retrieving core configuration for sensor sync; upgrading Hilt to 2.49 fixed the problem.

instruction: In the android app, there was a performance regression in a beta build: the app became very slow to start (tapping the Home Assistant icon resulted in a long delay before the app finished launching). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (dependency io.sentry:sentry-android). The predicted root cause reason is that upgrading the io.sentry:sentry-android dependency from 7.10.0 to 7.11.0 introduced a performance regression (Sentry initialization at app startup causing slow launch).

instruction: In android, there was an issue where the History page would start refreshing endlessly after the user navigated to an entity that does not exist, making it impossible to view the history for that entity. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: io.sentry:sentry-android). The predicted root cause reason is a bug in the Sentry Android SDK version 7.10.0 (io.sentry:sentry-android) that caused problematic behavior (session/exception handling leading to a UI refresh/reload loop) which was resolved by upgrading the dependency to 7.11.0.

instruction: In the Android companion app repository, there was a report of a device profile where one Home Assistant instance consumed 100%+ CPU and the system log (logcat) was being flooded; attempting to collect logs just spun without completing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this high CPU / log flooding behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle.kts (Module: app.build.gradle.kts). The predicted root cause reason is a bug in the kotlinx-coroutines dependency (version 1.6.1) — specifically the ThreadLocalElement/Coroutine context handling bug that caused coroutine thread-local state to be mishandled, leading to excessive CPU usage and log flooding; fixed by upgrading kotlinx-coroutines to 1.6.2.

instruction: In the android app repository, there was a bug where videos on certain Samsung devices (S21 and S22) did not automatically enter full-screen when they were supposed to. The user reported that the video only becomes full screen after switching away to other screens or closing and reopening the app; full-screen works fine in Chrome and the problem started occurring recently on those devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle.kts (Module: app.build.gradle.kts), automotive/build.gradle.kts (Module: automotive.build.gradle.kts), common/build.gradle.kts (Module: common.build.gradle.kts), and wear/build.gradle.kts (Module: wear.build.gradle.kts) — i.e., the dependency coordinates in the project build files that were updated. The predicted root cause reason is an out-of-date/incorrect kotlinx.coroutines dependency version (kotlinx-coroutines-core / kotlinx-coroutines-android / kotlinx-coroutines-guava at 1.6.4) causing a coroutine-related runtime issue affecting the fullscreen video behavior; bumping the coroutines libraries to 1.7.1 fixed the problem.

instruction: In the android repository, beacon monitor commands stopped working: when Home Assistant sends the command to turn on beacon monitoring while the phone is in the HOME zone, the automation waits for beacons but they are never discovered/updated in the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is common/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/common/bluetooth/ble/IBeaconMonitor.kt (Module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.common.bluetooth.ble.IBeaconMonitor). The predicted root cause reason is that the sensor update broadcast/notification was targeted at the wrong receiver after the code was moved to the common module (missing/incorrect broadcast receiver usage or missing receiver registration), so sensor updates were never sent.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android app, Quick Settings (Tiles) did not visually refresh their state when tapped — for example, turning a light on would successfully change the entity but the tile color/state did not update until the Quick Settings panel was reopened (observed on Android 12/13). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/qs/TileExtensions.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.qs.TileExtensions). The predicted root cause reason is that the Tile implementation was not subscribing to entity state change updates for tiles (missing state-change subscription/collection), so tiles did not receive and apply state updates after a tap and therefore did not refresh their visual state.

instruction: In this Android repository/app, there was a problem where the Wear OS daily steps sensor (and related health sensors) stopped updating for long periods (for example, the last update was seven hours ago) while the watch was paired and being used. This resulted in stale step counts and delayed sensor updates on the phone. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is wear/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/sensors/HealthServicesSensorManager.kt (Module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.sensors.HealthServicesSensorManager). The predicted root cause reason is that the Health Services passive listener/callback could become stale and stop providing updates and there was no timeout-based detection/restart (missing logic to re-register/restart the callback after prolonged inactivity), causing the daily steps sensor to stop updating.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android repository, users reported that the Wear OS app always shows an error when loading entities on the watch (watch and phone app versions and Home Assistant server version were provided). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure: which file or module was responsible, and what went wrong to cause the error when loading entities on the wearable.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (the io.sentry:sentry-android dependency entry / the sentry-android dependency in the build configuration). The predicted root cause reason is an incompatible/outdated dependency version: the project pinned io.sentry:sentry-android to 7.1.0 which caused a runtime incompatibility/error when loading entities on Wear (resolved by bumping the sentry-android version to 7.2.0).

instruction: In the android app repository, there was an issue where playing a video clip that was opened from a notification caused an "Unable to connect to Home Assistant" error message to appear on top of the video, even though the video continued to play. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/webview/WebViewActivity.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.webview.WebViewActivity). The predicted root cause reason is that the connection-check logic in WebViewActivity (waitForConnection) incorrectly showed the connection error prompt for URLs that are local or API paths — a missing/incorrect URL path check caused a spurious "Unable to connect" display.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android app, there was a problem where enabling High Accuracy location mode caused the app to stop sending frequent location updates after running for a while — the app would stop accessing location at the expected high-frequency interval (e.g. every few seconds) even though High Accuracy mode remained enabled. This happened both in the foreground/high-accuracy service and in background location updates. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/full/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/sensors/LocationSensorManager.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.sensors.LocationSensorManager). The predicted root cause reason is that the code did not track/detect when location updates had stopped (missing tracking of the last received location timestamp and missing recovery/restart logic), so background/high-accuracy location updates could silently stop and were not restarted.

instruction: In the android repository/app, a user reported that on a fresh install the app detected the server, asked for login and 2FA, but when they pressed "Finish" to complete initial setup the app immediately crashed with a "Home Assistant has stopped" error. This happened during the final connection/registration step after entering connection data (and occurred regardless of the location setting). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/launch/LaunchActivity.kt (module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.launch.LaunchActivity). The predicted root cause reason is an unhandled exception during the initial registration sequence (saving URL / registering auth code / registering device) — specifically SSL/network-related errors (e.g., SSLHandshakeException / SSLException on older Android/OkHttp) were not caught, causing the app to crash.

instruction: In the android Home Assistant app, there was a severe failure: on a Samsung device running One UI (Android 12) tapping a Home Assistant device from the Device Controls panel caused the phone to hang and become unresponsive, requiring a reboot. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle.kts (module: app) — specifically the io.sentry:sentry-android dependency (version declared/managed in app/build.gradle.kts). The predicted root cause reason is an uncaught/untreated exception in Sentry callback handling (missing handling of callback exceptions) that could crash or hang the system UI; updating the sentry-android version to a release that catches these callback exceptions fixed the issue.

instruction: In the Android companion app repository, the WearOS app was crashing on startup on some watches and never progressed past the splash screen. This happened while the app was initializing UI input/scroll handling for wearable devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is wear/src/main/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/util/RotaryEventDispatcher.kt (class: io.homeassistant.companion.android.util.RotaryEventDispatcher). The predicted root cause reason is a NumberFormatException caused by attempting to parse a non-numeric string (using .toString().toFloat() on a reflected Method) when trying to obtain the scaled scroll factor on certain devices; there was no exception handling for devices without the rotary/scroll factor, so the app crashed.

instruction: In the android repository/app, there was a problem where turning High Accuracy location mode on via the notification command while away from home caused location updates to stop as soon as the user entered their home_expanded zone. The binary sensor and app notification still showed High Accuracy as enabled, but updates ceased until the mode was toggled again inside the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/full/java/io/homeassistant/companion/android/sensors/LocationSensorManager.kt (Module: io.homeassistant.companion.android.sensors.LocationSensorManager). The predicted root cause reason is that the internal state used to track high accuracy mode (e.g., lastHighAccuracyMode / related state) was not updated/kept in sync when the mode was changed via the notification command (missing/incorrect state update), causing the background setup logic to mis-evaluate the change and not start/stop the high-accuracy location service as expected.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android repository, there was a problem where a Pixel 4a running Android 12 stopped sending location/zone updates for days on one phone even though an identical phone with the same app version and configuration continued to report location normally. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that explain why location updates stopped on that device.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle.kts (Module: app) — the dependency declaration for io.sentry:sentry-android. The predicted root cause reason is a faulty third-party dependency version (io.sentry:sentry-android:5.6.1) that interfered with the app's background/location behavior; upgrading the Sentry dependency to 5.6.2 resolved the issue.

instruction: In the android repository, there was an issue where after the Home Assistant server was switched from HTTP to HTTPS with a new SSL certificate, the Android client only sent updates while the app was in the foreground. When the app moved to the background it stopped updating sensors. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason. In other words, specify the file or module that was changed to fix this and explain the underlying cause that made background updates fail.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated com.google.devtools.ksp dependency (was 2.0.0-1.0.21) causing incorrect/buggy code generation/annotation processing that led to background HTTPS update behavior failing; upgrading KSP to 2.0.0-1.0.22 resolved the issue.

instruction: In the Android repository, users observed that on Android 11 the Home Assistant power menu integration would not execute actions (taps produced a vibration but nothing happened) and long-pressing an entity produced a black, empty pop-up. This happened when interacting with the power menu UI. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused these UI/interaction failures.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (the dependency entry for com.google.android.horologist:horologist-composables / the Horologist UI library). The predicted root cause reason is a bug/regression in the third-party Horologist UI library version 0.5.10 that broke UI/interaction handling for the power menu (missing/faulty UI behavior), fixed by bumping the dependency to 0.5.14.

instruction: In the Home Assistant Android repository, users reported that the app would log in successfully but then, after a short period of normal use (seconds to ~20s), the app would show “Unable To Connect to Home Assistant” and lose access (including via Nabu). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (Module: gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect/outdated dependency versions (specifically ksp and horologist entries) in the libs versions file that caused incompatible library artifacts to be used, resulting in authentication / connection failures (access denied) shortly after login.

instruction: In mhabit, there was a database migration to version 4 that caused the app to fail to start: on launch the migration attempted to recalculate habit record UUIDs and the process aborted with a unique-constraint error in the records table (UUID conflict). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/persistent/local/db_helper.dart (mhabit.persistent.local.db_helper.DatabaseToV4MigrateHelper.reCalcHabitRecordUUIDs). The predicted root cause reason is that the migration recalculated record UUIDs and attempted to update them without detecting/handling cases where different records would generate the same new UUID (duplicate UUID collisions), causing an SQLITE_CONSTRAINT_UNIQUE failure on the records table.

instruction: In the mattermost-mobile repository, the Android app crashes immediately when launched only in production (release) builds; development builds and the older release-1.19 branch work fine. The crash happens on app start after building with BUILD_FOR_RELEASE=true VARIANT=release make run-android. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the release-only startup crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is package.json (path: package.json; Module: package) and the lockfile package-lock.json (path: package-lock.json; Module: package.lock). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect dependency specification for mattermost-redux (a dependency resolution issue pointing to a problematic source/version), which caused an incompatible/untranspiled dependency to be included in the release bundle and led to the app crashing in production builds.

instruction: In the mattermost-mobile app, launching the app immediately showed a red error box that said something like: Unexpected keys "analytics", "teamAnalytics" found in previous state received by the reducer, and the app would not proceed. This happened right after building and running the master branch. Your task is to identify the root cause component (the specific file or module that should be changed) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that produced the unexpected keys warning).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/reducers/index.js (Module: reducers/index). The predicted root cause reason is that stale persisted Redux state contains keys ("analytics", "teamAnalytics") that are no longer present in the combined reducers (removed/renamed reducers) causing redux-persist rehydration to warn — i.e., missing migration/cleanup for removed reducer keys.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was no audio on macOS when booting any game for the first time — sound is silent until the user opens Settings → Audio and reselects the audio source, after which audio works. This occurs on initial startup of a title; reselecting the device restores audio. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is SDL/SDLMain.cpp (module: SDL.SDLMain). The predicted root cause reason is that automatic audio-device switching/initialization runs too early during startup (improper handling of SDL audio device events) — there was no adequate startup-time guard, so the app attempted to open/switch audio devices before the system audio devices were ready, causing audio to fail until the device is manually reselected.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a rendering bug in ULJS-00460 (Dai-2-Ji Super Robot Taisen Z Saisei) where the unit movement map's grid would disappear when you zoom in/out or move the view. This happened on Vulkan builds (working in v1.18.1, broken in v1.19) and occurs while the engine is processing 2D geometry draws on the movement map. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that produced the rendering corruption).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/DrawEngineCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.DrawEngineCommon) and the caller in GPU/GPUCommonHW.cpp (module: GPU.GPUCommonHW) — also involving the corresponding header GPU/Common/DrawEngineCommon.h. The predicted root cause reason is that the early-out culling path did not advance the vertex stream pointer (i.e., bytesRead/vertexAddr was not handled) when skipping a draw, so vertex data/stream state became misaligned leading to incorrect rendering (missing grid).

instruction: In ppsspp, loading the libretro core on Android (selecting a game) caused the app to crash during startup: the core would start, audio would initialize, then the process would crash before the content ran. This happened across games and only for the affected builds; older builds ran to completion. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this crash. In other words, point to the file/module that was responsible and explain what went wrong (the underlying bug or incorrect behavior) that would lead to the Vulkan/graphics crash during core load.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/System.cpp (Module: Core.System). The predicted root cause reason is that GPU/graphics initialization was performed in the asynchronous loader thread (wrong ordering/thread) for libretro builds, causing an ordering/threading-sensitive initialization error (GPU initialized off the main thread / initialization happened too early or in the wrong context), which led to a Vulkan crash; libretro needed the old, main-thread GPU init ordering.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a build failure when compiling the PPSSPPSDL and libretro/RetroArch targets after a recent commit. The compiler stopped with a type-conversion related error in the media playback subsystem, preventing successful builds. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HW/MediaEngine.cpp (Module: Core.HW.MediaEngine). The predicted root cause reason is that range-based for loops used const-qualified loop variables (const auto&), which resulted in pointer-to-const types when taking addresses of codec-context members; this caused a type mismatch/invalid conversion when calling FFmpeg C APIs that expect mutable AVCodecContext** (i.e., an incorrect const qualifier on the loop variable / missing removal of const).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, the libretro core began crashing immediately on launch on Linux (the crash happens very early during startup when the core tries to initialize display/AV information). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash: which file/module contained the bug, and what specifically went wrong (the underlying cause in terms of state, value, or missing check).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is libretro/libretro.cpp (Module: libretro.libretro). The predicted root cause reason is that the code used an invalid/zero internal resolution (g_Config.iInternalResolution == 0), resulting in geometry base_width/base_height being set to 0 (no validation/assertion), which led to an invalid window/display parameter and an immediate crash during initialization.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash at startup when using the Vulkan backend while running PPSSPP as the libretro core in RetroArch on an Android device: after updating the core, the core immediately crashes during the boot/initialization phase when loading a game (OpenGL still works). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is libretro/libretro.cpp (Module: Libretro.libretro). The predicted root cause reason is that the libretro boot/update flow incorrectly blocked/polled the boot process and proceeded in a way that used the GPU before a valid Vulkan/graphics context was available (missing proper deferred boot handling and missing checks around gpu usage), causing use of an uninitialized/null GPU and a crash.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, users reported that creating a save state or reporting feedback (for example, taking a screenshot) on Android could cause the app to crash instantly. This happened when those actions were performed and ran on background threads. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module was responsible and what went wrong that allowed these operations to crash the app.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/Screenshot.cpp (Module: Core.Screenshot). The predicted root cause reason is that the screenshot/save-feedback callback was enqueued with the wrong TaskType (CPU_COMPUTE), causing code that requires Android JNI/scoped storage access to run on a thread without JNI attached — i.e., incorrect thread-type selection / missing JNI attachment on that thread leading to an immediate crash.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, dynamic transparent smoke/steam in Jak & Daxter: The Lost Frontier appeared with horizontal striping and a blocky outline around characters when the smoke was rendered over or near models. This occurs in areas with dynamic, transparent particles (for example during the Phoenix chase or when smoke is produced by attacks). Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was changed to fix this) and the root cause reason (what was going wrong that produced the visual artifact).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is assets/compat.ini (the compatibility flags / compat configuration file in the assets module). The predicted root cause reason is a missing compatibility workaround for the game's use of a depth-buffer swizzle (depth buffer swizzle mismatch / missing depth-buffer-swizzle workaround), causing incorrect depth handling for transparent smoke and producing horizontal stripes and blocky outlines.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a reproducible softlock in Code Lyoko: Quest for Infinity. During gameplay, certain dialogue boxes with voice lines appear but the voice audio never plays; because the audio never finishes or reports completion the dialogue box cannot close and the game becomes effectively softlocked (requiring a reset). This happens consistently on some voice tracks (e.g., the third dialogue after an early battle). Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was changed to fix this) and the root cause reason (what in the audio/path handling went wrong that caused the playback to fail and softlock the game).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ext/at3_standalone/atrac3plusdec.cpp (Module: ext.at3_standalone.atrac3plusdec). The predicted root cause reason is that the Atrac3+ standalone decoder treated mismatched frame/channel block data as a fatal error (returned AVERROR_INVALIDDATA) instead of tolerating/handling it, causing audio decode to fail and the dialogue audio to never play (softlocking the game).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash when attempting to import team save data for ULJM05698 (CarnageHert EXA). The user followed these steps: placed the provided save data in the SAVEDATA folder, started the game, entered Battle Mode, opened Team Formation, chose Team Data Transport, navigated to the Team Transport Folder and selected import. Instead of completing the import flow, the emulator crashed when the game tried to access the save data files. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/Dialog/SavedataParam.cpp (module: Core.Dialog.SavedataParam). The predicted root cause reason is that the code logged/iterated the wrong file list pointer and dereferenced an invalid pointer (accessing systemEntries instead of normalEntries / no sanity check on the list pointer), causing a null/invalid pointer dereference during file-list logging.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, enabling "Auto Max Quality" on Vulkan with the default Qualcomm driver caused 2D element textures (menu graphics) to show cracks and visual corruption on some Android devices (Snapdragon 870). Mesa's driver did not exhibit the problem. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/TextureCacheCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.TextureCacheCommon). The predicted root cause reason is that anisotropic filtering state (key.aniso) was left enabled/incorrectly applied together with a forced-nearest filtering path in the Auto Max Quality code path (ordering/missing clear of the aniso flag), causing a conflicting sampler state that breaks on Qualcomm drivers.
