instruction: In the ppsspp repository, players reported that lighting in Syphon Filter was much darker when using the hardware/driver rendering path (different on GL/Vulkan and between platforms), with some lights appearing to be missing while software rendering looked correct. This difference was observed while running the game (frame dumps were provided) and seemed to vary by backend and OS. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/VertexShaderGenerator.cpp (module: GPU.Common.VertexShaderGenerator). The predicted root cause reason is that a negative value was being passed into pow() (the spot/angle base was not clamped), causing inconsistent/incorrect results across backends; there was a missing clamp/guard against negative angle/specular values before calling pow().

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a bug where a user disabled plugins in Settings > System, closed the emulator, and after reopening the emulator the plugins setting had been re-enabled by itself. This happened on Android when toggling the plugins option and restarting the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the plugins setting not to persist across restarts.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/Config.cpp (Module: Core.Config). The predicted root cause reason is a configuration/INI key name mismatch/collision: the plugins setting was registered with the wrong key name (e.g., "EnablePlugins" vs the expected "LoadPlugins"), causing the setting to be saved/loaded incorrectly and the disabled state not to persist.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash on Linux that occurred whenever the user selected the Achievements entry (Achievements screen) from the settings or related menus — instead of opening the achievements screen the emulator segfaulted. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is UI/RetroAchievementScreens.cpp (path: UI/RetroAchievementScreens.cpp, module: UI.RetroAchievementScreens). The predicted root cause reason is a printf-style formatting call receiving a std::string temporary (not a C string) for a "%s" vararg, causing a type/ABI mismatch / undefined behavior (invalid pointer) and resulting in a crash.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a crash when starting a race in "Outrun 2006 Coast 2 Coast" on Linux — the game segfaults as the race begins (sometimes right at the countdown end or a few seconds after the player car appears). This happens in both standalone and RetroArch core builds and with both OpenGL and Vulkan backends. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: specify the file/module where the underlying bug was, and explain what went wrong to cause the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/VertexDecoderHandwritten.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.VertexDecoderHandwritten). The predicted root cause reason is a wrong SSE/store intrinsic usage that caused an incorrect-sized memory store (vector store mismatch) and memory corruption — specifically using the wrong _mm_* store intrinsic which overwrote adjacent memory and led to a segfault.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a rendering error that appeared on some Android devices: certain scenes (e.g. Platypus) produced visually incorrect colors/packed pixels compared to expected output (see provided good vs bad images and a framestuff dump). This happened during normal gameplay/graphics rendering on affected devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FragmentShaderGenerator.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.FragmentShaderGenerator). The predicted root cause reason is a precision/rounding bug in the fragment shader float->u8 conversion: the scale multiplier used to convert floats to 0..255 was too large (and in lowp precision on some Android GPUs 1.0 * multiplier rounded up to 256), so floor produced 256 which overflowed the u8 packing and produced incorrect colors (i.e., a float precision/rounding overflow in the shader conversion).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was an audio problem observed when playing Digimon Adventure (NPJH-50686): during non-video cutscenes the characters' voices sounded slow and distorted while the rest of the game (menus, gameplay, performance) appeared normal. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect audio behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceAtrac.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.sceAtrac). The predicted root cause reason is that the ATRAC decoding code assumed a fixed two-channel output and computed bytes written accordingly (hardcoded channel count), instead of using the actual output channel count from the decoder—resulting in incorrect sample/byte calculations and distorted/slow audio.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash when running a homebrew app: PPSSPP v1.17.1 crashes when sceGuCopyImage is given a bad address (the emulator aborts instead of handling the faulty access). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/GPUCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.GPUCommon). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect calculation of the source/destination size used by DoBlockTransfer (miscomputed srcSize/dstSize used for memory validity checks), which allowed an invalid memory range to be accepted and led to the crash.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a reproducible crash: after watching a specific in-game cinematic (a fireworks scene that occurs on day 8) the emulator finishes the video, then freezes on a black screen and becomes unresponsive (even closing the emulator is not possible). This only happens with that particular cinematic (all cinematics are PMF), and skipping the cinematic avoids the problem. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this freeze.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/scePsmf.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.scePsmf). The predicted root cause reason is an infinite/blocked loop in scePsmfPlayerGetVideoData caused by continuing to step video after the stream has ended (missing check for video end / video timestamp no longer advancing), which causes the emulator to hang.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash in Pangya Fantasy Golf (ULUS-10438) that occurred when changing clothes in the room screen while software skinning (sw skinning) was enabled. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/DrawEngineCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.DrawEngineCommon). The predicted root cause reason is an unchecked vertex decode range leading to decoding past the vertex buffer limit (missing bound check / decoding too many vertices from a nonsense index buffer, causing out-of-bounds memory access and a crash).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash when launching Mega Man Powered Up (ULUS10091): on startup you can briefly see the "now loading" text and then PPSSPP shuts down completely. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/Dialog/PSPMsgDialog.cpp (Module: Core.Dialog.PSPMsgDialog). The predicted root cause reason is that a recent change made the dialog button text parameter use std::string_view, and callers were passing a NULL C-string (or not handling a missing button) which results in undefined behavior/crash — effectively a missing null/empty-string handling when the argument type changed.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering bug in Steins;Gate where certain background transitions show the wrong images — you see menu/loading screens or other unrelated screens instead of the correct background during transitions. This happens during specific in-game transitions on mobile (Android) using the GLES backend. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/ReplaceTables.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.ReplaceTables) and Core/MIPS/MIPSAnalyst.cpp (Module: Core.MIPS.MIPSAnalyst). The predicted root cause reason is a missing/incorrect hook for the game's framebuffer readback (no steinsgate_download_frame replacement/hash entry), so the emulator never performed the readback into memory and used stale/incorrect framebuffer data (resulting in menu/loading images showing instead of the intended backgrounds).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a graphical corruption in the Naruto Kizuna Drive menu when running with the OpenGL backend: certain menu textures appeared wrong or misaligned. This happened while the emulator was uploading texture data for rendering. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the incorrect texture uploads and the resulting visual glitch.  In ppsspp, there was a graphical corruption in the Naruto Kizuna Drive menu when running with the OpenGL backend: certain menu textures appeared wrong or misaligned. This happened while the emulator was uploading texture data for rendering. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the incorrect texture uploads and the resulting visual glitch.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/GLES/TextureCacheGLES.cpp (module: GPU.GLES.TextureCacheGLES). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect stride calculation/padding when preparing texture data: an unnecessary minimum stride (padding to 16 bytes) was used (and stride wasn't passed along), causing wrong dataSize/stride for narrow textures and resulting in incorrect texture uploads (visual corruption).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering bug where Daxter's UI textures on the pause screen appear partially broken when running with the Vulkan renderer and texture scaling is disabled (the textures look correct again if texture scaling is enabled). This happens in the context of using the setting that saves/decodes textures for export. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Vulkan/TextureCacheVulkan.cpp (module GPU.Vulkan.TextureCacheVulkan). The predicted root cause reason is an ordering bug: the Vulkan color component swizzle/mapping was chosen before the texture format was forced/adjusted for saved textures (forcing decode to RGBA8888), causing the wrong color swizzle/mapping to be used and resulting in incorrect colors.

instruction: In ppsspp, a Zig PSP homebrew example (EBOOT) that should show a textured, rotating box instead displays only a grey screen on current builds (it runs correctly on real PSP hardware and in the software renderer). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain why this homebrew's graphics end up blank on modern PPSSPP builds.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/ShaderUniforms.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.ShaderUniforms). Also relevant are GPU/GLES/ShaderManagerGLES.cpp (Module: GPU.GLES.ShaderManagerGLES), GPU/Directx9/ShaderManagerDX9.cpp (Module: GPU.Directx9.ShaderManagerDX9), and Common/Math/math_util.h (Module: Common.Math.math_util) which were involved in the fix. The predicted root cause reason is that the depth-range math produced infinite/invalid float values (e.g., division by zero producing Inf) which were passed to shader uniforms; there was no sanitization for Inf values, causing the GPU shader/path to render incorrectly (resulting in the grey screen).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a rendering bug where replacement textures (ktx2) lost visible detail and appeared blurry in-game (Toukiden Kiwami) when using the Vulkan and D3D9/11 backends, while the OpenGL backend rendered those same textures correctly. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that led to the incorrect texture sampling/filtering behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/TextureCacheCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.TextureCacheCommon). The predicted root cause reason is that anisotropic filtering was not being enabled for replacement textures with mipmaps (the anisotropy flag/key was not set in the sampling parameters), causing incorrect/overly-blurred sampling on Vulkan/D3D backends.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering glitch in ULJM05416 (Hayate no Gotoku!! Nightmare Paradise) where character sprites incorrectly show through the background at the beginning of the scene when all the characters scatter. This happens on OpenGL & Vulkan backends while the software renderer appears correct. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect handling of block transfers from RAM into depth buffers (failed to detect/handle uploads to auto-swizzled VRAM depth addresses and mismatched stride/BPP and framebuffer range checks), so the depth buffer was not initialized/updated and depth testing rendered characters in front of the background.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a crash that happened when toggling the screenshot feature: using the screenshot toggle caused the application to crash (reported on Windows with Intel HD Graphics, occurring across games). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/UI/Screen.cpp (Module: Common.UI.ScreenManager). The predicted root cause reason is an ordering bug: the post-render callback was invoked at the wrong point in the render sequence, allowing rendering to occur after the callback and causing the screenshot mechanism to run at an unsafe time which led to the crash.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash when using the D3D11 backend while loading certain texture replacement packs (KTX2). The same packs worked with OpenGL, Vulkan and D3D9, so the failure only appeared when running with D3D11 and happened while the emulator was applying/replacing textures. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this D3D11-only crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/D3D11/TextureCacheD3D11.cpp (Module: GPU.D3D11.TextureCacheD3D11). The predicted root cause reason is that block-compressed replacement textures with dimensions not divisible by the 4x4 block size were not being adjusted/padded for D3D11, causing D3D11 texture creation to fail (missing handling/padding for BC texture dimensions).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a severe visual corruption and performance problem seen when starting a new game (Metal Gear Acid 2 on an AMD GPU). Large parts of the screen were not drawn (appearing as skipped/blank regions) and overall performance dropped dramatically on AMD/D3D11. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/GPU/Vulkan/VulkanQueueRunner.cpp (Module: Common.GPU.Vulkan.VulkanQueueRunner). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect render-area merging: the code that combined VkRect2D renderAreas (MergeRenderAreaRectInto / renderpass merge logic) did not account for offsets when expanding extents (and thus computed too-small/incorrect combined render areas), causing the driver to skip rendering large portions of the screen.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering bug where the tornado effect in Lunar Silver Star rendered incorrectly on PC (visible visual artifacts in the tornado effect across all backends). This happened when the emulator sampled or bound the current render target as a texture while drawing the effect. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon (files: GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp and GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.h). The predicted root cause reason is that cached copies of the current framebuffer were being reused in shader-blending/self-texturing cases (i.e. a render-target copy was inappropriately cached and reused), causing stale/incorrect texture data to be sampled — missing/unused "uncached" behavior (missing use of an uncached flag and corresponding check) allowed the cached copy to be reused when it should not have been.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a regression where third-party Android launchers that used shortcuts to send VIEW intents with game file URIs could no longer launch PPSSPP directly into a game (this had worked in v1.14.2). Users reported that invoking the emulator via a launcher shortcut no longer opened the app or the specified game. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/AndroidManifest.xml (Module: android.AndroidManifest). The predicted root cause reason is that the activity's intent-filter did not accept content:// URIs (missing a <data android:scheme="content"/>), so intents carrying content URIs did not match the activity and the app could not be launched.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, enabling the Qt UI build while SDL support is disabled caused a compilation failure: building the Qt target fails during compile. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this build break.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Qt/QtMain.cpp (Module: Qt.QtMain). The predicted root cause reason is that SDL-specific audio functions were called unguarded when SDL support was disabled (missing conditional compilation / missing #ifdef SDL around calls to StopSDLAudioDevice()/InitSDLAudioDevice), causing compile errors due to undeclared symbols.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was persistent graphics corruption in ThrillVille that appeared immediately when starting a game: visible artifacts and incorrect clearing/Z-buffer behavior while the game used immediate-mode draws for clearing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason. Specifically, name the file or module that was responsible and explain what went wrong (for example: a missing call, incorrect state handling, or similar).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/GPUCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.GPUCommon). The predicted root cause reason is a missing call to check depth-buffer usage when performing immediate-mode draws (i.e., CheckDepthUsage was not invoked during FlushImm), causing depth/clear handling to be incorrect.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a failure where several rtc autotests (rtc/arithmetic and rtc/lookup) were failing when running headless on Linux/BSD. The observed behavior was incorrect date/time conversions causing those tests to fail — saved times/dates and RTC-derived values were wrong during the test run (the failures were reproducible on a 32-bit Linux build). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceRtc.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.sceRtc). The predicted root cause reason is reliance on 32-bit time representations and standard library time functions (time_t / gmtime / timegm) for tick <-> PSP time conversions, which caused overflow/incorrect date calculations; missing use of portable 64-bit date arithmetic led to wrong RTC conversions.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a black screen at the start of the game Kidou Keisatsu Patlabor - Kamubakku MiniPato (ULJS00026) when running with the GPU backend (Vulkan); the software renderer displays the scene correctly. This occurs right at the beginning of the game and results in no visible image. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/ShaderUniforms.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.ShaderUniforms). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect handling of a zero depth viewport scale (gstate_c.vpDepthScale == 0): depth range / cull-distance formulas performed divisions by zero or produced -INF/invalid values, causing wrong depth clip/cull behavior (missing guard against zero scale).

instruction: In ppsspp, when starting Warriors Orochi the game reports there is not enough free space to save at the beginning, preventing progress. The user tried changing compatibility options but the problem persisted. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what specifically was wrong) that caused the emulator to trigger this save-space failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is assets/compat.ini (the compat.ini file, specifically the [ReportSmallMemStick] compatibility section). The predicted root cause reason is missing compatibility entries for the Warriors Orochi game IDs in compat.ini, causing the emulator to report incorrect memstick/free-space behavior (i.e., not reporting a 'small memstick' as the game expects) and thus the game incorrectly thinks there is insufficient space to save.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a rendering failure on Raspberry Pi 4B when using the Vulkan backend: in SOULCALIBUR: Broken Destiny the scene did not render correctly in Training mode or Quick Match — only the overlay was visible and shader compiler errors appeared in the logs on Broadcom VC4/V3D hardware. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Vulkan/GPU_Vulkan.cpp (module: GPU.Vulkan.GPU_Vulkan). The predicted root cause reason is that light ubershader generation was enabled on Broadcom VC4/V3D Vulkan drivers, causing shader compiler failures / incompatibility (i.e., a missing vendor-specific disable/workaround for the light ubershader feature).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a crash when running Killzone - Liberation: if you start a new game and wait for the initial FMV to finish without skipping it, PPSSPP crashes and shows a blue crash info window; skipping the video avoids the crash. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module in the emulator was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that led to the crash).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceMpeg.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.sceMpeg). The predicted root cause reason is that the code wrote an incorrect value to the MPEG decoder's initAddr (writing the frame status instead of the expected constant for newer mpeg library versions), causing an incorrect decoder/initialization state and leading to the crash.

instruction: In ppsspp, there were widespread graphic glitches and occasional crashes that occur when toggling the texture replacement option while using a texture.zip file (affecting many games and seen on Windows/Android with Vulkan). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed these texture ZIP reads to produce rendering corruption or crashes when the option was toggled.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/File/VFS/AssetReader (files: Common/File/VFS/AssetReader.cpp and Common/File/VFS/AssetReader.h; module: Common.File.VFS.AssetReader). The predicted root cause reason is concurrent, unsynchronized access to the libzip zip file handle (shared file descriptor) from multiple threads — i.e., missing locking around ZIP reads/queries causing data races/corruption and crashes.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a problem running Medal of Honor Heroes (ULES-00516) with the Vulkan backend where, after the title screen, the emulator reported a Vulkan "vshader cached" error and the game failed to continue correctly. This happened while the renderer was flushing and starting new draw calls around the title/menu transition. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/DrawEngineCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.DrawEngineCommon) and the backend DrawEngine DoFlush implementations (e.g. GPU/Vulkan/DrawEngineVulkan.cpp, GPU/GLES/DrawEngineGLES.cpp, GPU/D3D11/DrawEngineD3D11.cpp, GPU/Directx9/DrawEngineDX9.cpp). The predicted root cause reason is that the previous-primitive state (prevPrim_) was being cleared/reset during flush and/or not handled when GE_PRIM_KEEP_PREVIOUS was used, causing an invalid or incorrect primitive type to be used for subsequent draws (missing/preserved state for KEEP_PREVIOUS), which led to wrong vertex/shader behavior and the Vulkan vshader cached error.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, users reported that after a recent build update, the game Tactics Ogre began showing incorrect Kanji characters across scenes (text glyphs changed to wrong characters) and Android builds experienced a noticeable FPS drop on the title screen. This regression started at a specific build and did not occur in an earlier one. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this rendering and performance regression.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/TextureCacheCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.TextureCacheCommon). The predicted root cause reason is a regression in how the fake-mipmap / mipmap-level hack was handled: the fake-mipmap change state was not cached/handled correctly which caused incorrect detection/handling of texture mip levels (and pure 3D texture detection), leading to wrong base mip level selection (wrong glyph textures used) and extra work that caused the FPS drop.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering bug in Iron Man (ULUS10347) where 3D characters were not being clipped by background geometry based on depth (they appeared in front regardless of depth), and there was an associated performance problem occurring at the start of the game on multiple backends. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon) and the related compatibility declarations in Core/Compatibility.cpp / Core/Compatibility.h (Module: Core.Compatibility). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect handling of block transfers for depth buffers (depth buffer data was not being preserved/converted/used during framebuffer block copies), causing depth tests/clipping to fail (and related incorrect buffer size/memory handling causing performance issues).

instruction: In ppsspp, users reported that the emulator crashes when starting a quick rally as a guest after shuffling to the Italy track (both USA and Europe versions). The crash happens while loading the track (Vulkan backend, AMD GPU) and causes the app to exit instead of loading the level. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: point to the specific file/module that needed fixing and explain what went wrong to cause the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Software/SoftGpu.cpp (module: GPU.Software.SoftGpu), specifically the block transfer implementation (Execute_BlockTransferStart). The predicted root cause reason is an out-of-bounds memory access due to missing/insufficient range/bounds checks for block transfer memcpy operations (invalid source/destination addresses leading to memcpy reading/writing invalid memory and crashing).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a visual corruption bug: during the first cutscene in Monster Hunter 3rd HD (PSMF/MPEG playback under GE emulation, Vulkan on Android) the video displayed a double image/ghosting instead of a correct single image. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceMpeg.cpp (module: Core.HLE.sceMpeg). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect YUV conversion / chroma subsampling handling in the MPEG->YUV conversion routine (__MpegAvcConvertToYuv420 / sceMpegAvcConvertToYuv420): wrong pixel indexing and Y/CB/CR ordering (incorrect handling of 2x2 blocks and chroma placement / swapped Cb/Cr), causing the decoded video to be misassembled and appear as a double image.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a graphical corruption issue: starting a new game of JEANNE D'ARC (UCUS98700) and skipping the opening cutscene produced scrambled/weird rendered graphics (observed on Windows with Vulkan on an NVIDIA GPU). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this corrupted rendering behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect depth-blit selection logic: the code chose an unsafe framebuffer depth copy/blit path due to a faulty feature check and ordering (missing texture-depth capability check and wrong preference order for raster depth copy), causing the renderer to use a copy method that triggered driver/driver-path corruption.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering regression where enabling hardware transform on some Adreno 3xx GPUs produced black or glitched textures (for example when selecting a car in ULUS-10025 and in Everybody Golf) after a recent change. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/VertexShaderGenerator.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.VertexShaderGenerator). The predicted root cause reason is that the generated GLSL used an unsigned value and unsigned case labels in a switch (e.g., 'type' with 'case 1u', 'case 2u'), which older Adreno drivers do not accept, causing shader compilation failures; missing conversion/cast to int and use of unsigned case literals.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, a developer reported that a Windows MSVC build with /permissive- failed with many compilation errors (errors like C2039, C2065, C2923, C2976, C2641, C2371, C2955, C2780) while attempting to msbuild the solution. The failures occurred during normal project build (not running the app) and manifested across several modules. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was changed to fix the problem) and the root cause reason (what in the code was wrong and why it caused the MSVC build to fail).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/GPU/thin3d.h (module: Common.GPU.thin3d.AutoRef). The predicted root cause reason is a missing inequality operator (operator!=) on the AutoRef<T> template class, which caused template instantiation/type-resolution failures under MSVC's strict conformance (/permissive-) and produced the cascade of compilation errors.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, PPSSPP crashes or gets stuck while playing the extended ending movie on the "Legend" stage of Outrun 2006 Coast 2 Coast (Android, OpenGL/GLES). The game either crashes or fails to continue past the movie and sometimes returns to the menu. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module in the project was responsible for the failure and what specifically went wrong to cause the crash/stall.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/GPUCommon.cpp (module: GPU.GPUCommon) and GPU/Software/SoftGpu.cpp (module: GPU.Software.SoftGpu). The predicted root cause reason is that the GPU CALL handler tried to execute an illegal/invalid target (NULL/0x00000000) and this was treated as a fatal GPU error state (missing/insufficient handling for bad memory/call targets — no ignore/guard for bad memory access), causing the emulator to enter an error state and crash/stall.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a graphics regression where, during battle scenes in one game, an enemy character rendered as a solid black texture when using the OpenGL/GLES backend while other backends (Vulkan, Software) rendered the scene correctly. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/GPU/OpenGL/DataFormatGL.cpp (module: Common.GPU.OpenGL.DataFormatGL). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect GL format/internalFormat selection for single-channel (R8) textures on GLES: the code used an incompatible GL_RED/sized-internal-format combination (or otherwise wrong format) for GLES, causing texture data to be interpreted/uploaded incorrectly and resulting in black textures (missing/incorrect format selection for GLES; should use GL_LUMINANCE or a proper sized internal format).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was visual corruption (garbled textures / incorrect colors) observed in SOCOM U.S. Navy Seals: Fireteam Bravo 3 and Tactical Strike when GPU readbacks were enabled and the "simulate block transfer effects" option was turned on (Vulkan). The artifacts appeared in parts of the game and did not get resolved by ClearToRAM; this regression reappeared in recent builds while other SOCOM titles behaved differently. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/TextureCacheCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.TextureCacheCommon) and GPU/Common/DepalettizeShaderCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.DepalettizeShaderCommon). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect handling of CLUT8 texturing from the framebuffer — the game misuses CLUT8 lookups from the main framebuffer and the emulator interpreted the bit layout / bits-per-pixel and index shift incorrectly (missing special-case compatibility handling), causing wrong palette indices and the visible artifacts.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a bug in NPJH-50589 (TIGER & BUNNY On-Air Jack) where an in-game photograph shown in a newspaper was visibly corrupted after finishing a stage, and the game subsequently black-screened and crashed when continuing the story (the corrupted photo is also saved with the game data). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceJpeg.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.sceJpeg). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect JPEG decoding due to wrong handling of image size/stride and YUV/chroma ordering (and related buffer size/stride checks), which caused malformed pixel data and out-of-bounds/corrupt writes leading to the corrupted photo and crash.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a glitchy FMV during the intro of Way of The Samurai Portable on Android: the movie frames show corruption unless the emulator is minimized (which temporarily clears the glitch). This started happening after a recent change and did not occur in the last known-good release. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that produced the corrupted video frames during FMV playback (which part of the code was fixed, and what was wrong there).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon). The predicted root cause reason is improper framebuffer copy/display handling: missing/insufficient checks that allowed copies between buffers of the wrong color format/stride or mismatched sizes (accepting an obviously wrong framebuffer copy), causing the display to use an incorrectly interpreted buffer and producing corrupted FMV frames.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a memory leak observed when using texture replacements in Persona 3 Portable: repeatedly opening the character status screen and cycling pages (holding L/R) caused RAM usage to steadily increase while showing the same replacement textures. This happened across rendering backends and was reproducible with a texture pack. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what specifically went wrong to allow memory to grow).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/TextureReplacer.cpp (Module: Core.TextureReplacer). The predicted root cause reason is that decoded replacement image data was being cached/managed by cache key (allowing many duplicate entries) and lacked appropriate shared-keying and cache pressure/eviction, resulting in duplicate decoded image data and unbounded memory growth (missing correct caching by filename and insufficient decimation/eviction).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a crash that occurred when loading saves (and sometimes savestates). It happened across games (for example, ULUS-10481 Yu-Gi-Oh! 5D's Tag Force 4), often right on boot when the emulator tried to load an older save file that worked in previous builds but now causes the app to terminate. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason behind this crash: which file/module is responsible and what went wrong that caused save loads to crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/D3D11/TextureCacheD3D11.cpp (module: GPU.D3D11.TextureCacheD3D11) and GPU/Directx9/TextureCacheDX9.cpp (module: GPU.Directx9.TextureCacheDX9). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect decoding/mapping of Direct3D texture formats (missing/incorrect handling of 16-bit formats), causing wrong Draw::DataFormat selection and resulting in invalid texture decoding that led to crashes when loading older saves/savestates.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, users observed a visible flickering in the game's startup video (Resistance Retribution, UCES01184) when the intro movie plays — the video frames rapidly flicker or show incorrect imagery during the start video playback on OpenGL/GLES backends. This regression started appearing after recent changes and affects the display of video/framebuffer content. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was fixed) and the root cause reason (what specifically went wrong that caused the flicker).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon), specifically around the CopyDisplayToOutput and NotifyFramebufferCopy logic. The predicted root cause reason is insufficient/incorrect framebuffer validation: copies and display selection could use buffers of the wrong color format/stride or accept conspicuous size-mismatched copies (e.g. 2x size differences), allowing the wrong framebuffer to be used for display and causing the video flicker (missing/too-loose checks on fb_format/fb_stride and copy size).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was an issue where running any Go!Explore disc would boot up briefly and then immediately return to the PPSSPP menu/home screen. This happens when the game attempts to access its required resources (these titles expect a NavNGo GPS device connected via USB) and fails to continue. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/FileSystems/ISOFileSystem.cpp (Module: Core.FileSystems.ISOFileSystem). The predicted root cause reason is a missing special-case handling in the ISO directory listing code: GetDirListing was not handling the ISO root sentinel correctly (entry == &entireISO) and therefore failed to map/list the root directory (missing mapping to GetFromPath("/")), causing the game to abort/return to the home screen.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a graphical corruption observed in IL-2 Sturmovik - Birds of Prey when running in the software renderer: white, glitchy flashing lines appear on the left side of the screen and worsen when turning the plane left. This only happens in the software renderer mode and manifests right after starting a new game. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Software/Clipper.cpp (Module: GPU.Software.Clipper) and GPU/Software/TransformUnit.cpp and GPU/Software/TransformUnit.h (Module: GPU.Software.TransformUnit). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect handling of clipped vertices / missing out-of-range checks: clip interpolation and ClipToScreen logic allowed projected screen coordinates to go out of bounds (and inverted polygons were not properly culled), causing invalid/inverted geometry and the visible software-renderer glitches.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was flickering textures during gameplay in Musou Orochi 2 Special (ULJM06097). The issue appeared on Vulkan, D3D9 and D3D11 backends (OpenGL was unaffected) and was introduced as a regression in the 1.13.x series. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for why rendering began flickering in those backends.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/GPUStateUtils.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.GPUStateUtils). The predicted root cause reason is that viewport/depth state "dirty" flags and cached viewport state updates were not being applied/propagated during viewport/scissor conversion (missing/incorrect dirty handling), so cached viewport parameters weren't updated and rendering state stayed stale, causing flickering.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a rendering bug where the bottom part of the title screen is missing in the game "Boku no Natsuyasumi 4: Setouchi Shounen Tanteidan" (observed on Windows with an AMD RX 580 using the Vulkan backend). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to parts of the scene being incorrectly clipped or not drawn.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/GeometryShaderGenerator.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.GeometryShaderGenerator) and GPU/Common/VertexShaderGenerator.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.VertexShaderGenerator). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect depth/clip distance calculation due to precision/rounding error (PSP 16-bit fixed-point depth precision causing a value that should be zero to be slightly negative), which caused geometry to be wrongly clipped; missing a small error-compensation (epsilon) in the clip distance computation.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, the game Dream C Club Portable (ULJS00333) shows a missing background when you talk to the first lady (the scene's background/CLUT-based artwork does not appear). This happens on Vulkan/Windows with the given build and a GE dump was provided. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this rendering failure: which file/module contains the bug that was fixed, and what went wrong conceptually to cause the missing background.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/DepalettizeCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.DepalettizeCommon.DepalShaderCache). The predicted root cause reason is that the 16-bit CLUT color-conversion cases were transposed/incorrectly mapped (the wrong conversion functions were used for BGR565 vs ABGR5551), causing incorrect depalettized CLUT textures and thus the missing background.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, shadows were missing in Hunter x Hunter: Wonder Adventure during gameplay — areas that should cast dark shadows appeared without them. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed the rendering state to incorrectly skip or mask the stencil/alpha write required for the shadows to appear. In other words, pinpoint which file/module was responsible and explain what went wrong in the rendering state handling that caused the shadows to be absent.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/GPUStateUtils.cpp (Module: GPU.Common.GPUStateUtils) and GPU/GPUCommon.cpp (Module: GPU.GPUCommon). The predicted root cause reason is that color write mask (RGB mask) changes did not properly trigger or account for depth/stencil state updates, so stencil-only writes intended to go into the alpha channel were masked/treated incorrectly (missing conversion/state handling), preventing the stencil/alpha write needed for the shadows (i.e., state not marked dirty / missing handling for RGB mask leading to alpha write being masked).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, after an update cutscenes in NPJH50562 (Kurohyou 2) started flickering and subtitles went missing when using the Vulkan and GLES backends (software rendering still appears normal). This affects all cutscenes and began after the referenced update. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.cpp and GPU/Common/FramebufferManagerCommon.h (Module: GPU.Common.FramebufferManagerCommon). The predicted root cause reason is a flawed framebuffer selection heuristic that failed to account for blending state (missing check for blending), allowing color-to-depth handling to be used when blending/logical ops were active which caused incorrect use of depth buffers for color/blend operations and produced the flickering/missing subtitles.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a regression where the "Simulate Block Transfer Effects" rendering option produced broken visuals when running with OpenGL: games that rely on block-transfer effects (for example, intro videos, HUDs, and loading backgrounds in several titles) displayed incorrect or corrupted graphics (e.g., white backgrounds, missing or displaced textures) at startup or during loading. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/Draw2D.cpp (module: GPU.Common.Draw2D). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect shader attribute/semantic name for the texture coordinate in the 2D draw vertex shader (a typo/hardcoded name: using "a_texcoord" instead of the expected "a_texcoord0"), which caused texture coordinates to be passed incorrectly and broke the block-transfer effects under OpenGL.

instruction: In the ppsspp app, Tekken 6's Nancy bonus stage shows the laser beam (lines) as invisible on a recent build (v1.13.1) while an older build (v1.12.3) renders it correctly. This happens on Android with Vulkan/OpenGL backends and appears related to line rendering/width. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for the invisible laser beam.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/SoftwareTransformCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.SoftwareTransformCommon). The predicted root cause reason is that line width/offset computations did not account for the homogeneous W components (pos_w / uv_w) when expanding lines, so the offsets were applied incorrectly (missing scaling by pos_w/uv_w), producing incorrect/too-thin (effectively invisible) line geometry.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, running the automated test command "python test.py --graphics=software" on Windows x86 (Release and Debug builds produced by Visual Studio) resulted in the test run failing to complete: the test log output appeared to stop/Be blocked and the overall test execution did not finish. This happened during CI-like automated testing of the software renderer. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure — indicate which file/module contained the defect and explain what went wrong (the underlying bug/issue).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Software/SoftGpu.cpp (Module: GPU.Software.SoftGpu). The predicted root cause reason is that the softgpu draw engine (and its bin/queue data) was not being freed — a memory/resource leak (missing cleanup) causing steadily increasing memory usage and the test run/log to be blocked.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a crash when running Splinter Cell Essentials (ULUS-10070) if the built-in debugger was opened: starting the game and opening the debugger (in the menu or in-game) causes ppsspp to crash shortly afterward, while the game runs fine when the debugger is not opened. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash (which part of the code/module was responsible and what went wrong to cause the crash).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/Debugger/DisassemblyManager.cpp (Module: Core.Debugger.DisassemblyManager). The predicted root cause reason is that the disassembly code attempted to hash/read an invalid RAM region (e.g. address 0) without validating the address/size first, causing an invalid memory access (dereference/overread) and crash.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, users reported that after updating to a recent build the emulator freezes/hangs and shows infinite loading when starting a new game or loading a save (selecting New Game / Load Game). This started happening on Android with Vulkan (worked in the earlier build). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file or module's change caused the regression, and why that change led to the hang/freeze behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/Thread/ThreadManager.cpp (Module: Common.Thread.ThreadManager). The predicted root cause reason is that IO-blocking tasks were not isolated from the main compute thread pool (and some Task subclasses did not report their TaskType), causing IO tasks to be scheduled on and saturate the compute threads. This thread-pool design/queueing issue led to worker threads being blocked on IO and caused the emulator to hang/infinite-load.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a hang and occasional crash when entering the main menu of Bleach: Soul Carnival 2 on multiple platforms (Android and Windows). The game would hang or crash at the main menu where the emulator is handling display/vblank behavior. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what specifically went wrong to cause the hang/crash).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceDisplay.cpp (module Core.HLE.sceDisplay). The predicted root cause reason is that the code held the listenersLock mutex while invoking vblank/flip listener callbacks, allowing re-entrant behavior that attempted to acquire the same lock (or otherwise caused ordering issues), leading to a deadlock/hang (and related crash).

instruction: In the ppsspp repository, there was a bug where using the software renderer with frame skipping (x1) caused the game ULJM05404 to freeze/hang during a fight scene on Android. The freeze happens only when frame-skipping is enabled in the software GPU path; without it the game runs. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Software/SoftGpu.cpp (Module: GPU.Software.SoftGPU) [and related GPU/Software/SoftGpu.h]. The predicted root cause reason is incorrect/missing per-buffer VRAM dirty tracking (relying on a global framebufferDirty_ flag / not marking the correct buffer as REALLY_DIRTY), causing stale/uncleared display buffer updates when frame-skipping/triple-buffering is used which leads to the freeze/hang.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a visual corruption: in Persona 3 Portable (ULUS-10512) while exploring Tartarus (floor ~147F) the game showed a persistent texture/visual glitch on Android (OpenGL/GLES) where geometry textures appear wrong or corrupted during play. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this rendering glitch.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/GLES/DrawEngineGLES.cpp (module: GPU.GLES.DrawEngineGLES). The predicted root cause reason is a faulty vertex cache / vertex-array/VBO caching mechanism in the GLES draw engine that caused stale or corrupted vertex data to be reused (incorrect VBO/element handling or invalidation), producing corrupted geometry/texture mapping (i.e., a broken vertex cache implementation leading to rendering artifacts).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was an incorrect shadow position observed in the game Fate/EXTRA (School Building 1st Floor) when using the Vulkan backend: shadows are mispositioned in Vulkan while OpenGL and software rendering look correct. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/Common/ShaderId.cpp (module: GPU.Common.ShaderId). The predicted root cause reason is that the UV generation mode bit(s) were not set for the software vertex transform path (UVGEN_MODE was only set for HW transform), causing the vertex shader to misinterpret UV layout (vec2 vs vec3) and produce incorrect shadow/UV positions.

instruction: In ppsspp (Android), there was a regression where DualShock 4 (DS4) controllers connected via Bluetooth stopped working in PPSSPP 1.12 and newer — they no longer respond in emulator menus or games, though the same controller still works in other Android apps and worked in PPSSPP 1.11.3. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/src/org/ppsspp/ppsspp/InputDeviceState.java (module: org.ppsspp.ppsspp.InputDeviceState). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect input source prioritization / device classification: gamepad input was checked after keyboard/pointer checks, causing devices that also report keyboard/pointer sources (like many gamepads) to be misclassified and not treated as gamepads.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a regression on Android where Tom Clancy: Ghost Recon (ULES01350) crashes after the player enters their name — the crash occurs when the game triggers utility/dialog functionality (dialog initialization/shutdown). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module is responsible for the bug, and what went wrong that caused the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Core/HLE/sceUtility.cpp (Module: Core.HLE.sceUtility). The predicted root cause reason is mismanagement of the utility access helper thread lifecycle (double initialization / deleting or reinitializing the accessThread while it may still be running), i.e. a race / missing state checks and cleanup for the accessThread leading to unsafe deletion and volatile memory lock issues.

instruction: In ppsspp, enabling hardware tessellation in King Of Fighters '96 on Android with the Vulkan backend caused the emulator to crash during rendering. This happened when the game attempted to use the hardware tessellation/bezier/spline path, producing a hard crash rather than a recoverable glitch. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is GPU/GPUCommon.cpp (module: GPU.GPUCommon) and GPU/Common/SplineCommon.cpp (module: GPU.Common.SplineCommon). The predicted root cause reason is that buffered draw/vertex state was flushed at the wrong time relative to changing the tessellation/submit state (gstate_c.submitType). Because the flush happened after submitType was modified (or wasn’t done before the change), a bogus vertex shader ID was computed/used during the flush, leading to shader generation/usage errors and the Vulkan crash.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a problem where a game's save state (YGO Tag Force Special) would later fail to load and the emulator showed no warning about what caused the failure. The failure was observed when creating or exporting a save state: data appeared to be truncated/incorrectly written, so subsequent attempts to load that save state failed silently. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain why a save state could be generated in a form that later cannot be loaded.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/Serialize/Serializer.h (Module: Common.Serialize.CChunkFileReader) — specifically the CChunkFileReader::SavePtr implementation (and related callers in Core/SaveState.cpp and libretro/libretro.cpp that invoke it). The predicted root cause reason is that the save routine did not validate that the number of bytes written matched the expected/measured size (missing size validation/check), allowing truncated save data to be reported as a successful save.

instruction: In the ppsspp repository/app, there was a bug where using the Libretro core produced a black screen on a second (and subsequent) content launch while audio continued to play, and when using the D3D11 renderer closing content after the second launch caused a crash. This happens after closing and reloading content repeatedly (first launch is fine). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the black screen and crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is Common/Thread/ThreadManager.h (module: Common.Thread.ThreadManager) and libretro/libretro.cpp (module: libretro.libretro). The predicted root cause reason is that the thread pool/ThreadManager teardown was not performed on content unload — background worker threads remained running (or were immediately reused) across unload/load boundaries, leading to racing access of rendering/graphics resources after they were freed (missing Teardown call / missing proper thread shutdown), causing the black screen and eventual crash.

instruction: In ppsspp, there was an app crash on iOS that occurred whenever a game controller (e.g. a DualShock-like controller) was connected — the app would crash or fail to open unless the controller was turned off. This happened while the app was setting up or responding to controller inputs. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ios/ViewController.mm (module: ios.ViewController). The predicted root cause reason is that the code accessed controller profile button properties/selectors (e.g. buttonHome, buttonMenu, buttonOptions, leftThumbstickButton, rightThumbstickButton) without verifying those selectors exist on the particular controller profile, causing an Objective-C unrecognized selector / crash (missing respondsToSelector / guard for optional controller members).

instruction: In ppsspp, there was a problem building on an aarch64 Devuan system: initial configuration reported an unsuitable PNG library version, and when running the build script for the Qt frontend the configure step completed but the build later failed because a required external shader-remapping library could not be found at link time. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is ext/CMakeLists.txt (module: ext.CMakeLists). The predicted root cause reason is that the build system was attempting to build/link the SPVRemapper component by default (missing/incorrect CMake setting), which led to a missing -lSPVRemapper link requirement; there was no switch set to disable spvremapper, causing the linker error.

instruction: In the kiwix-android app, there was a problem where the "Send diagnostic" report did not attach the device logs on a Google Pixel 7a and, when logs were large, the app failed to send the diagnostic email. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/main/java/org/kiwix/kiwixmobile/core/error/ErrorActivity.kt (org.kiwix.kiwixmobile.core.error.ErrorActivity). The predicted root cause reason is that the implementation placed large log data into the email Intent (EXTRA_TEXT) and resolved/sent that intent, creating an oversized Binder parcel which triggered android.os.TransactionTooLargeException — i.e., attaching the full log content to the Intent instead of using a FileProvider/stream caused the failure.

instruction: In kiwix-android, there was a crash when attempting to save a bookmark while viewing a zim-split (split) ZIM file: tapping the bookmark icon causes the app to crash if the archive includes an extra ZIM chunk of zero size. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/main/java/org/kiwix/kiwixmobile/core/main/CoreReaderFragment.kt (module: org.kiwix.kiwixmobile.core.main.CoreReaderFragment). The predicted root cause reason is an unhandled exception thrown by the libkiwix/JNI layer when processing splitted ZIM files that contain a 0-size extra chunk (missing exception handling around the bookmark save/book update flow), which led to the application crash.

instruction: In the kiwix-android app, users reported that clicking a video never starts the video (the video content fails to open, sometimes showing a blank page). This happens after downloading a file with videos and attempting to open a video link; it was observed across multiple branches and in published builds. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/main/java/org/kiwix/kiwixmobile/core/reader/ZimFileReader.kt (module: org.kiwix.kiwixmobile.core.reader.ZimFileReader). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect URL/file-path handling: query parameters (the part after '?') were not consistently stripped/normalized before looking up content, causing the reader to use a wrong path and fail to find/open video resources.

instruction: In the kiwix-android app, there was a crash that could be triggered by stressing the library content search: while browsing/searching library content the app would sometimes crash or terminate unexpectedly when trying to extract details from a content URL. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/org/kiwix/kiwixmobile/utils/NetworkUtils.java (module: org.kiwix.kiwixmobile.utils.NetworkUtils). The predicted root cause reason is invalid substring/index calculations when parsing parts of a URL (missing bounds checks), which allowed out-of-range string indexes and caused a runtime exception (StringIndexOutOfBounds).

instruction: In the AppFlowy repository/app, there was a regression where after updating the Windows desktop app from 0.4.1 to 0.4.2 the first launch produced an empty window. The user killed the process with Task Manager and after restarting the app it showed an error page and could not be reset, forcing the user to downgrade back to 0.4.1 to recover. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this broken startup behavior after the update.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is frontend/appflowy_tauri/src-tauri/Cargo.lock (module: frontend.appflowy_tauri.src_tauri.CargoLock). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect/outdated upstream dependency revision (the collab crate commit referenced in Cargo.lock) which introduced a buggy dependency version causing the app to fail on restart (dependency/commit mismatch leading to startup failure).

instruction: In the android repository/app, there was a UI bug in the video fullscreen flow: if a user opens a video, pauses it, and then enters fullscreen, the video remains paused but the fullscreen UI shows the pause button (and it does not toggle playback) instead of the play button. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason that led to the paused video and incorrect button state in fullscreen.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/ui/preview/PreviewVideoFullscreenDialog.kt (com.owncloud.android.ui.preview.PreviewVideoFullscreenDialog). The predicted root cause reason is that the play/pause UI state was not initialized when entering fullscreen — the playback-state listener was not run/queried on entry, so the UI button state was not synced with the player's isPlaying (missing initial state check/invocation).

instruction: In the android repository (Nextcloud Android app), writing the same file through the DocumentProvider in short succession failed: a backup using Seedvault to the Nextcloud document provider fails almost immediately and subsequent quick writes/read attempts to the same document can fail. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason explaining why the provider failed when files were written in rapid succession.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/providers/DocumentsStorageProvider.java (module: com.owncloud.android.providers.DocumentsStorageProvider). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect logic for determining whether a file needs downloading/exists on device (relying on a storage-path null check instead of a proper existsOnDevice check), causing a race/incorrect state handling when a file was just uploaded (empty storage path) and leading to failed opens/writes (missing/incorrect existence check / flawed condition).

instruction: In the Nextcloud Android app, inserting an image into an OnlyOffice (direct edit) document from a directory does nothing: the file selection UI never appears and you are returned to the document. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that prevented the image selection/upload).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/ui/activity/EditorWebView.java (Module: com.owncloud.android.ui.activity.EditorWebView). The predicted root cause reason is missing file-chooser handling in the editor web view (no WebChromeClient.onShowFileChooser / uploadMessage and no onActivityResult handling), so file input elements for local image upload were not handled for direct-editing views.

instruction: In the Nextcloud Android app, attempting to share files stored on a Nextcloud instance caused the share to fail and the provider to crash for some client apps (some apps could share files while others triggered a crash or prevented the file from being shared). This happened when the system requested the document from the provider and the operation failed while handling the document open request. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/providers/DocumentsStorageProvider.java (Module: com.owncloud.android.providers.DocumentsStorageProvider). The predicted root cause reason is that a network operation (downloading the file via DownloadFileOperation.execute) was performed on the main/UI thread — causing a NetworkOnMainThreadException / failure due to missing background/asynchronous execution for network I/O in the DocumentProvider.

instruction: In the animeko app, there was a crash that occurred when opening the danmaku (comment) list from the playback screen while the device was in landscape orientation. The same action in portrait orientation worked fine. Reproduction requires a playing episode, danmaku already loaded, and opening the danmaku list. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/src/commonMain/kotlin/ui/subject/episode/details/DanmakuListSection.kt (module: ui.subject.episode.details.DanmakuListSection). The predicted root cause reason is using a UUID object (randomId) directly as the LazyColumn item key, which is an unsupported/unstable key type for Compose Lazy lists and caused the crash; converting the key to a String fixes the issue.

instruction: In animeko, there was a bug where the pause/resume action for torrent downloads did not work: tapping pause had no effect and downloads continued (or could not be toggled) when managing torrent file downloads. This happened while interacting with the torrent download controls (pause/resume) in the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is torrent/api/src/commonMain/kotlin/api/files/TorrentFileEntry.kt (module: api.files.AbstractTorrentFileEntry.AbstractTorrentFileHandle). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect equals() and hashCode() implementations on the torrent file handle causing handle equality/hash-based lookup to fail (file handles representing the same entry were not treated as equal), so pause/resume operations could not find or update the correct handle/state.

instruction: In the animeko app, searching with any filter applied exhibits a failure: after the first ~20 results load, scrolling to the bottom does not reliably trigger loading of subsequent pages (you must wait minutes or interact unusually to get more results). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the search pagination to stop loading further items when filters/sorting are used.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/app-data/src/commonMain/kotlin/data/repository/subject/SubjectSearchRepository.kt (Module: me.him188.ani.app.data.repository.subject.SubjectSearchRepository). The predicted root cause reason is that filtering was performed at the UI layer (hiding items after mapping) instead of in the paging/data layer, causing a mismatch between the Pager's source item counts/offsets and the displayed items which prevented pagination from triggering (i.e., UI-level filtering removed items after paging, breaking pagination).

instruction: In the animeko repository/app, the macOS desktop build crashes with a segmentation fault and exits immediately on startup on Apple Silicon (aarch64). The app prints initial startup/info lines (platform, data/cache/log dirs) but then terminates; this happened across several recent releases and debug output showed JVM/runtime startup warnings. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this startup crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/build.yml (module: github.workflows.build.yml) and the related CI workflow files updated in the PR: .github/workflows/release.yml (module: github.workflows.release.yml) and .github/workflows/src.main.kts (module: github.workflows.src.main.kts). The predicted root cause reason is that the packaged JetBrains Runtime/JCEF binary for macOS aarch64 (an older JBR JCEF version) caused a native segmentation fault at startup — i.e., an incorrect/outdated JBR artifact version used in the build/release workflow leading to a native crash (missing/incorrect runtime version).

instruction: In the animeko repository/app, there was a crash and incorrect behavior in Settings → Storage when configuring the BT video cache location. If a user enters a relative path (for example "./data/media_download") into the BT video cache input and confirms, then later clicks to open the directory chooser for that setting, the app crashes and the BT cache location resets to the default. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that allowed this to happen.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/ui-settings/src/desktopMain/kotlin/ui/settings/tabs/media/CacheDirectoryGroup.desktop.kt (module: ui.settings.tabs.media.CacheDirectoryGroup). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect path validation and normalization: the BT cache input accepted and saved relative or otherwise invalid paths and passed them to the desktop directory chooser (native API) without resolving to an absolute/canonical path or rejecting non-existent/invalid directories, causing the native failure and subsequent reset.

instruction: In animeko, there was a crash when adjusting the UI size slider on the Settings screen: dragging the UI adjustment handle all the way to the right edge causes the app to crash with layout-related errors (messages about maxWidth < minWidth, invalid minWidth/minHeight, and layout state not idle before measure). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/ui-adaptive/src/commonMain/kotlin/ui/adaptive/AniListDetailPaneScaffold.kt (Module: ui.adaptive / AniListDetailPaneScaffold). The predicted root cause reason is missing/minimum width constraints and missing pane expansion anchors/state for the list/detail panes (the drag handle could drive widths into invalid ranges so maxWidth < minWidth or negative min sizes), causing invalid layout measurement.

instruction: In the animeko app, there was a problem on Ubuntu where the window's fullscreen button had no effect. Reproduction: run Ani on Ubuntu, open any series/episode, and press the fullscreen button — nothing happens (users can only reach fullscreen via system shortcuts and hiding the sidebar). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module was responsible for the broken fullscreen behavior, and what specifically went wrong to make the fullscreen button ineffective.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/ui-foundation/src/desktopMain/kotlin/platform/window/LinuxWindowUtils.kt (me.him188.ani.app.platform.window.LinuxWindowUtils). The predicted root cause reason is that Linux lacked a proper implementation to toggle undecorated fullscreen — the code did not set the WindowState placement to Fullscreen (missing/absent override of setUndecoratedFullscreen), so the fullscreen action was effectively a no-op.

instruction: In animeko, there was a bug where the danmaku on-screen density setting had no effect, and after dragging a density control then reopening the settings the value reverted to the state before the drag. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/src/commonMain/kotlin/ui/subject/episode/video/settings/EpisodeVideoSettings.kt (Module: ui.subject.episode.video.settings — EpisodeVideoSettingsViewModel) and the related UI file app/shared/src/commonMain/kotlin/ui/subject/episode/video/components/EpisodeVideoSideSheet.kt (Module: ui.subject.episode.video.components — EpisodeVideoSideSheets). The predicted root cause reason is that the state update API accepted and applied a full DanmakuConfig value (a stale snapshot) rather than a transform based on the current VM state; this caused updates to be overwritten by stale values (missing functional/transform-based update), so UI interactions like dragging reverted or had no effect.

instruction: In the animeko app, there was a Windows-specific bug where after opening the application the mouse cursor immediately turned into the horizontal resize (double-arrow) cursor and any click or interaction inside the app acted like a horizontal window resize. This made the UI unresponsive — clicking Settings, Update, or content did nothing except resize the window horizontally. The problem started after updating to version 4.5.0 a1 and disappeared when reverting to 4.4.3, then reappeared after updating again. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect cursor/interaction behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/ui-foundation/src/desktopMain/kotlin/platform/window/WindowsWindowUtils.kt (platform.window.WindowsWindowUtils.TitleBarWindowProc). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect non-client hit-test logic: the titlebar/window hit testing used wrong/stale window frame metrics and coordinate handling (missing update of window info / improper lParam coordinate usage), causing the resizer hit-test to be reported everywhere (HTLEFT/HTRIGHT) and thus the cursor to be locked to the horizontal-resize state and block normal interaction.

instruction: In animeko, there was an intermittent crash during torrent downloads: when a piece finished downloading, the download session would sometimes crash while notifying open file handles — especially when file handles were opened or closed around the same time. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is torrent/anitorrent/src/commonMain/kotlin/session/AnitorrentDownloadSession.kt (module: me.him188.ani.app.torrent.anitorrent.session.AnitorrentDownloadSession). The predicted root cause reason is that a mutable list (openFiles) was mutated concurrently while being iterated from different coroutines/contexts, causing a ConcurrentModificationException / unsafe concurrent access due to lack of a thread-safe/atomic collection or proper synchronization.

instruction: In the animeko repository/app, there was a crash when switching the follow (subscriptions) list: the UI stutters and the app later crashes with an error message saying an Skia Picture object was already closed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash: which file or module change fixed the issue, and what was the underlying cause of the failure (what went wrong) that produced the "Object already closed" error.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/android/build.gradle.kts (module: me.him188.ani.app.android) — the project dependency / Compose Multiplatform version configuration that was updated. The predicted root cause reason is a Compose/Skia resource lifecycle bug (use-after-close of an org.jetbrains.skia.Picture) caused by an incompatible/buggy Compose Multiplatform version; the issue was resolved by upgrading the Compose/CMP dependency to a version that fixes the Picture being closed prematurely/closed twice.

instruction: In the animeko app, users reported that on the PC/desktop build automatic playback would skip episodes incorrectly: manually tapping "next episode" would jump two episodes, and choosing an episode from the episode list would jump an extra one. This happened when using the desktop player and affected automatic consecutive playback. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that caused the extra skips).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/shared/video-player/src/desktopMain/kotlin/ui/VideoPlayer.desktop.kt (module: ui.VlcjVideoPlayerState). The predicted root cause reason is that the desktop player set the "finished"/end-of-media state at the wrong lifecycle callback (using the wrong event), causing the finish/auto-play logic to trigger at the incorrect time and result in double-skipping (inconsistent finish state timing compared to Android).

instruction: In the animeko app, users sometimes saw a "Failed to open video source: NO_MATCHING_FILE" error when trying to play a file from a newly added torrent. This happened during torrent lifecycle events shortly after a torrent was added (the app attempted to synchronize/load the torrent's file list but playback failed). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is torrent/impl/anitorrent/src/commonMain/kotlin/session/TorrentManagerSession.kt (module: me.him188.ani.app.torrent.anitorrent.session.TorrentManagerSession). The predicted root cause reason is that the code attempted to load/sync the torrent file list too early (triggered on the wrong event — e.g., onTorrentFinished) before metadata and checked state were available, causing an empty file list (race condition / missing guard/check for metadata/onTorrentChecked).
