instruction: In accrescent, there was a crash that occurred when a background operation timed out: a WorkManager job timed out and the app crashed instead of failing gracefully. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason. In particular, point to the file or module that was changed to fix this, and explain what went wrong (the underlying cause that made the timeout lead to a crash).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml (module: app.accrescent.client.Accrescent). The predicted root cause reason is a missing foreground-service permission and service declaration for WorkManager's foreground service type (android.permission.FOREGROUND_SERVICE_DATA_SYNC / SystemForegroundService). Because these entries were absent, WorkManager's attempt to start the foreground service on timeout caused a SecurityException/illegal foreground start and crashed the app.

instruction: In the accrescent app, users observed the app suddenly crashing while downloading apps over very slow network connections — typically after reaching about 80–90% progress — and the app would also often crash quickly if the user switched away from the app during a download. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these crashes.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml (module: app.accrescent.client). The predicted root cause reason is a missing foreground-service configuration/permission: WorkManager-initiated foreground service (data sync) was not declared/authorized in the manifest (missing FOREGROUND_SERVICE_DATA_SYNC permission and SystemForegroundService declaration), causing the worker to fail when starting its foreground service (crash when the app is backgrounded or the download progressed to the worker’s foreground transition).

instruction: In QField, using the autocompletion to pick entries from a very large reference list causes the app to crash (often reproducible when tapping a filtered entry as it appears). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/core/featurelistmodel.cpp (module: src.core.featurelistmodel.FeatureListModel). The predicted root cause reason is that a pre-existing running gatherer thread/object (mGatherer) was not being properly stopped/disconnected before creating a new one, leading to a race condition/use-after-free (signal/slot invoked on an invalid or replaced gatherer) and consequent crashes.

instruction: In the QField repository/app, there was a problem where QField on a tablet (Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 GT-P5200) started but showed an empty, unresponsive screen and missing menu text after the tablet was upgraded to a newer Android ROM. The app worked fine on other devices but on this tablet it became non-responsive and UI elements were missing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/astyle.yml (CI workflow step using EndBug/add-and-commit) and Gemfile.lock (fastlane-plugin-sentry entry) — i.e., the CI/dependency configuration files that were changed. The predicted root cause reason is that outdated CI/dependency tooling versions (an older EndBug/add-and-commit action and an older fastlane-plugin-sentry entry) required bumping — the issue was caused by obsolete tooling/dependency versions in the repository's CI/build configuration rather than by the app runtime code itself.

instruction: In the QField repository/app, official Google Play releases were reported as unstable on a Samsung Note 4: users experienced startup crashes, the app hanging on a white screen when changing orientation, crashes when opening projects with more than three layers, and failures to restore after sleep. A locally built APK from the same source, however, was stable. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the official release builds to be unstable while local/manual builds were stable.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is /Gemfile.lock (bundler group) — i.e. the repository's bundler dependency lockfile (bundler: Gemfile.lock). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/mismatched build-tool dependency pinned in the Gemfile.lock (notably fastlane-plugin-sentry and/or rexml), causing the official release build pipeline to use an incompatible build/release tooling version which altered packaging/signing/processing and produced unstable/corrupt APKs (build tooling dependency mismatch in the release pipeline).

instruction: In the termux-x11 repository, enabling the "Capture external pointer devices when possible" option caused the OnePlus Pad Pro touchpad to stop moving the pointer and clicking entirely. This happened only when the capture feature was turned on; with it off the touchpad behaves normally. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible and fixed) and the root cause reason (what was wrong in that component) that led to the captured touchpad input being ignored or non-functional.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/termux/x11/TermuxX11Activity.java (module: com.termux.x11.TermuxX11Activity). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect handling of external touchpad input source (e.g., MotionEvent/InputDevice.SOURCE_TOUCHPAD) in the pointer-capture input path, so touchpad events were filtered out or treated incorrectly when capture was enabled.

instruction: In the termux-x11 repository/app, there were random segmentation faults of the X server when running on a Pixel Watch 2 with a non-standard 384x384 display resolution. From a user's perspective, the desktop environment sometimes crashes the X server; the DE (MATE) itself handles the display fine but termux-x11 complains about the resolution and the X server sporadically segfaults during normal use (for example when running glmark2 or starting the DE). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: point to the specific file/module that was responsible and explain what went wrong (the underlying bug or missing check that led to the crash).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/termux/x11/XServer.java (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is that non-generic/square display resolutions (e.g., 384x384) were not handled correctly, causing an invalid framebuffer/stride or array index calculation and resulting in an out-of-bounds access (segmentation fault) due to a missing validation/check for unsupported resolution sizes.

instruction: In the termux-x11 repository, a user reported that starting the X server with the command `termux-x11 :1` on a Bliss-Go (Android 12L) image running in VirtualBox produced a "Bad system call" error. The same installation files worked on a physical phone but failed in the VirtualBox environment. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/debug_build.yml and .github/workflows/update-wrapper.yml (modules: .github.workflows.debug_build.yml and .github.workflows.update-wrapper.yml). The predicted root cause reason is outdated GitHub Action versions in the CI workflow (using actions/setup-java@v4 and gradle/actions/wrapper-validation@v4) that needed to be bumped to v5.

instruction: In the termux-x11 repository, there was a bug where the system's surfaceflinger RSS memory steadily grows (by >10 MB each app switch or screen off/on) while termux-x11 is running; after prolonged use surfaceflinger can consume gigabytes and destabilize the system. This happens when switching the X11 view to another app and back or turning the screen off and on. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: specify which file/module contains the defect and explain what went wrong (the underlying cause of the leak or incorrect behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/cpp/lorie/android.c (Module: app.src.main.cpp.lorie.android), with related native surface handling code in app/src/main/cpp/lorie/InitOutput.c (Module: app.src.main.cpp.lorie.InitOutput). The predicted root cause reason is improper native surface/JNI lifecycle handling across threads — surfaces/ANativeWindow jobjects were passed/managed without correct JVM attachment and global-ref/release semantics (incorrect surface destruction/ownership), causing BufferQueue to be abandoned and resulting in surfaceflinger memory growth (resource leak).

instruction: In termux-x11, there was an issue where the Galaxy Tab S8+ keyboard cover touchpad produced incorrect behavior: right-clicks appeared to be cancelled and two-finger gestures had inverted axes when moving up/down/left/right. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/termux/x11/input/TouchInputHandler.java (module: com.termux.x11.input.TouchInputHandler). The predicted root cause reason is that touchpad events were being handled like regular touchscreen events and coordinates were transformed based on display rotation; the touchpad reports coordinates in its own physical orientation (independent of display rotation) and the code lacked proper touchpad-specific handling (correct axis transformation and mouse button state processing), causing axis inversion for two-finger gestures and canceled right-clicks.

instruction: In the wallet app, there was a reproducible crash: after a user finishes entering the 24-word recovery phrase (the "Your Recovery Phrase" page) and taps Submit, tapping the Hamburger (drawer) menu immediately causes the application to crash. This happens right after completing the recovery phrase setup and opening the app drawer. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/account/Settings.tsx (Module: src.account.Settings). The predicted root cause reason is the recovery-phrase-in-settings change: adding the recovery phrase entry into the Settings screen caused Settings to be rendered/used in a context where required state/flow assumptions (navigation params/feature flag/selector) were not valid, producing an invalid navigation/render path and causing the app to crash.

instruction: In wallet, there was a crash on Android nightly builds that occurred 100% of the time when a user opened the app immediately after installing it. The failure happened on multiple Android devices and build variants (release/nightly) but did not occur on iOS. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: name the file or module that needed to be changed and explain what went wrong that allowed this crash to happen (the underlying technical cause).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/mobile/android/app/proguard-rules.pro (Module: packages.mobile.android.app.proguard-rules.pro). The predicted root cause reason is missing ProGuard/R8 keep rules for react-native-reanimated (classes under com.swmansion.reanimated.**) causing required classes/methods to be stripped/obfuscated in release builds, which led to the app crashing when ProGuard minification was enabled.

instruction: In the wallet app, the app crashed whenever an Android user tried to scan the QR code shown by the https://use-contractkit.vercel.app site after initiating a WalletConnect connection (selecting Valora from the Wallet Connect popup and arriving at the QR code screen, then scanning it via Connected Apps). This happened consistently on multiple Android devices but did not reproduce on iOS. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/mobile/src/walletConnect/saga.ts (Module: src.walletConnect.saga). The predicted root cause reason is that WalletConnect v2 initialization was attempted (the v2 code path was enabled) even though v2 support was not working on Android, causing an unhandled failure/crash when processing v2 QR URIs (i.e., an unsupported/buggy v2 flow triggered without proper handling).

instruction: In the wallet app, there was a bug where a “Confirmation” error is shown when a user tries to verify their phone number after changing the number during the new account/verification flow. This happens when the user starts verification (receives attestations), navigates back to the phone number input, changes the phone number, and then attempts to continue verification — instead of being able to request/receive new attestations and proceed, they are blocked by a confirmation error. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/mobile/src/verify/VerificationEducationScreen.tsx (Module: packages.mobile.src.verify.VerificationEducationScreen). The predicted root cause reason is that the verification state was not being reset when the phone number input changed (missing reset of verification state), so new attestations were not requested/sent for the new number and the verification flow could not continue.

instruction: In wallet, there was an intermittent failure where buying or selling CELO from the in-app exchange would succeed, then fail on the next attempt, and continue to alternate between success and failure. This occurred when a user attempted repeated Buy or Sell flows from the CELO exchange screen (navigate to Menu -> CELO, perform a purchase or sell, then immediately perform the operation again). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/mobile/src/exchange/saga.ts (Module: packages.mobile.src.exchange.saga). The predicted root cause reason is a race condition caused by not specifying the transaction nonce for exchange transactions (missing/incorrect nonce handling), which allowed the exchange transaction to be submitted before the prior approve transaction was recognized by the node.

instruction: In the wallet app, there was a bug where after completing onboarding and starting to create a new account, if a user reaches the phone number verification page, kills the app, then relaunches and re-enters their PIN, the phone number page shows a continuous loading indicator and the user is blocked from continuing verification. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/mobile/src/redux/sagas.ts (module: packages.mobile.src.redux.sagas). The predicted root cause reason is that the verification-related saga(s) were not initialized or ready when actions were dispatched after app relaunch (missing/incorrect wait for sagas to finish loading), so those actions were never handled and the phone number screen remained stuck in a loading state.

instruction: In the wallet app, toggling the iOS App Tracking setting while completing onboarding (specifically while on the phone number verification step) and then backgrounding and reopening the app resulted in the phone verification screen showing an infinite loading spinner (and the app sometimes crashing on relaunch). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure — i.e., which file/module was responsible and what went wrong to cause the verification step to get stuck.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/mobile/src/redux/sagas.ts (Module: packages.mobile.src.redux.sagas). The predicted root cause reason is that verification-related sagas (the root saga) were not initialized/ready in time after app background/relaunch, causing actions to be dispatched with no handler (a timing/order/synchronization issue / missing wait for sagas to finish loading), which left the phone verification flow stuck on a loading spinner.

instruction: In Metrolist, there was an app crash when opening the Appearance settings. The crash occurs when the app language is set to Japanese — tapping the Appearance option causes the app to terminate instead of opening the appearance settings screen. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash (which file or module was at fault, and what specifically went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/res/values-ja/metrolist_strings.xml (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is an unescaped percent sign in the localized string resource (sensitivity_percentage) causing a runtime string-formatting/format exception when the string is formatted (missing '%%' escape).

instruction: In the Metrolist app, there was a bug where using Gemini Play Music to open/play a YouTube watch link resulted in the wrong playlist being played instead of the expected playlist. This happens when attempting to play a playlist from a watch URL. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/kotlin/com/metrolist/music/MainActivity.kt (com.metrolist.music.MainActivity). The predicted root cause reason is that the YouTube watch handler did not parse and forward the playlist query parameter (the `list`/playlistId) when queuing/creating the WatchEndpoint, so the playlist ID was ignored and the wrong playlist was played.

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash when a player spammed the letter/category selection keys in Freeplay and tried to leave at the same time (for example, when Back is bound to the same key as a category key). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/ui/freeplay/LetterSort.hx (module: source.funkin.ui.freeplay.LetterSort). The predicted root cause reason is that the letter-selection handling did not check whether input controls were active (missing guard around instance.controls.active) before performing animations/timers/sound, allowing UI actions to run when the controls/UI were deactivated and causing the crash.

instruction: In the Funkin repository/app, there was a crash on Android where main menu buttons could be pressed multiple times during the fade/transition back to the main menu, which—if timed correctly—allowed the Freeplay menu to be opened twice and led to a crash. This happened after returning from other menus (Options, Story, Credits) and interacting with the main menu while the transition was still finishing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed this double-activation and crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/ui/mainmenu/MainMenuState.hx (Module: source.funkin.ui.mainmenu.MainMenuState), and the related exit/transition files source/funkin/ui/options/OptionsState.hx (Module: source.funkin.ui.options.OptionsState), source/funkin/ui/story/StoryMenuState.hx (Module: source.funkin.ui.story.StoryMenuState), and source/funkin/ui/credits/CreditsState.hx (Module: source.funkin.ui.credits.CreditsState). The predicted root cause reason is that input was not being disabled/enforced during menu transitions (missing toggling of FlxG.keys.enabled / missing suppression of input), allowing multiple menu selections/scrolls and duplicate state switches which led to an invalid/crashing state.

instruction: In the Funkin repository/app, there was a crash that happened when a song event fired a tween on an object and the player immediately returned to the chart editor after that event. The observed failure: after triggering the event during playtest and switching to the chart editor, the game crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash — name the file or module responsible and explain what went wrong to cause the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/play/PlayState.hx (module: source.funkin.play.PlayState). The predicted root cause reason is that active tweens and timers were not cancelled/cleared when exiting PlayState (missing cleanup of FlxTween.globalManager and FlxTimer.globalManager), allowing callbacks to run against removed/destroyed objects and causing the crash.

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash on the title screen: when opening the game and holding or repeatedly pressing the D key (and sometimes I) the game would immediately crash. This happened while interacting with the title screen controls before the title finished loading. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/ui/title/TitleState.hx (module: source.funkin.ui.title.TitleState). The predicted root cause reason is a null object reference caused by accessing a shader-related object (outlineShaderShit) before it was initialized — missing null checks / state accessed before initialization when handling key input (pressing D or I).

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash that occurred when entering playtest mode, restarting the song, and then immediately returning to the Chart Editor — the game would crash during that quick restart/exit sequence. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/play/PlayState.hx (module: source.funkin.play.PlayState). The predicted root cause reason is an active timer (vwooshTimer) / timer callback being started during a restart and not tied to the PlayState lifecycle (not canceled or scoped correctly). The timer's callback ran after the state was exited, accessing cleaned-up/null objects and causing the crash.

instruction: In the Funkin repository/app, there was a crash that occurred after finishing a song (reported while playing the 'Cocoa Erect' song) where the game crashed with a leaderboard/medal-related failure. The crash happened at the end of gameplay and could not be reliably reproduced by the reporter. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason — name which file/module is responsible and explain what went wrong to cause this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/api/newgrounds/Leaderboards.hx (module: funkin.api.newgrounds.Leaderboards) and source/funkin/api/newgrounds/Medals.hx (module: funkin.api.newgrounds.Medals). The predicted root cause reason is that code accessed Newgrounds leaderboard/medal data structures directly when they could be null (missing null-safe handling), causing a null dereference / null pointer exception when leaderboards or medals (or their internal maps) were not initialized.

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash when loading an FNFC via the Chart Editor's welcome dialog recent section: if you click a recent chart entry very quickly (before the entry's tooltip has a chance to appear), the game crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/ui/debug/charting/dialogs/ChartEditorWelcomeDialog.hx (module: source.funkin.ui.debug.charting.dialogs.ChartEditorWelcomeDialog). The predicted root cause reason is that the recent-link's tooltip can try to show after the dialog/link is being hidden/removed (a race condition / missing hide/disable), causing the tooltip to access a disposed/null UI element and trigger a Haxe UI null object reference crash.

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash that occurred when the user pressed F5 to hot-reload while any dialogue box was open. The game would immediately crash (null object reference) during the reload process. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this crash: which file/module (and method if relevant) caused the issue, and what specifically went wrong to produce the null object reference during hot-reload.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/play/PlayState.hx (module: funkin.play.PlayState, method: reloadAssets). The predicted root cause reason is that the reload path did not perform cleanup before forcing asset/state reload — active dialogue/stage objects remained running and referenced cleared or null resources, causing a null object reference during hot-reload.

instruction: In the Funkin repository/app, opening the Stage Editor and pressing the Delete (SUPR) key when no object was selected caused the editor to crash. This happened simply by hitting the delete key without having an active selection. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/ui/debug/stageeditor/handlers/UndoRedoHandler.hx (Module: funkin.ui.debug.stageeditor.handlers.UndoRedoHandler). The predicted root cause reason is a missing null/selection check: code attempted to delete or create an undo entry for a non-existent (null/undefined) selected object, resulting in a null-reference/invalid state access crash.

instruction: In the Funkin repository/app, there was a crash reported when a player restarts the game after logging into a Newgrounds account and quickly skipping the intro / mashing Enter to open the main menu. The game sometimes crashes with a Null Object Reference because Newgrounds-related data hasn't been retrieved fast enough. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/api/newgrounds/Medals.hx (module: source.funkin.api.newgrounds.Medals). The predicted root cause reason is a missing null-check for the medal list's internal data (its internal map not being initialized yet), causing a null reference when code accesses medal data before Newgrounds medals have finished loading.

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash when entering Freeplay if the 'CHAR SELECT' key binding was removed/unbound — the game quits/throws an error as Freeplay is opened. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/input/Controls.hx (module: source.funkin.input.Controls). The predicted root cause reason is that code attempted to access the first element of an inputs collection when that collection was empty (missing check/fallback), causing a null/object reference crash.

instruction: In Funkin, there was a crash that occurred when exiting the Input Offset / Latency screen from the options menu. The player reported that music had been affected and, after opening and then leaving the input offset screen, the game crashed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is source/funkin/ui/debug/latency/LatencyState.hx (module: funkin.ui.debug.latency.LatencyState). The predicted root cause reason is attempting to use FlxG.sound.music (setting its volume) when music is null — missing null check leading to a null reference crash.

instruction: In Thanox, users reported that when the “Open other apps” feature was enabled, they could not share images to an app in the Work profile (来自“炼妖壶”); disabling the feature made sharing work again. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: android.gradle.libs.versions.toml) — the kotlinx-coroutines dependency (org.jetbrains.kotlinx:kotlinx-coroutines-android, previously pinned at 1.8.0). The predicted root cause reason is a bug/regression in kotlinx-coroutines 1.8.0 (coroutine dispatch/scheduling on the main thread causing a race/incorrect dispatch that prevented intents/shares from being launched to the Work profile); the issue is resolved by upgrading to kotlinx-coroutines 1.9.0.

instruction: In the Thanox repository/app, there was a recurring Thanox core error visible in the system logs after a normal device startup on an Android 15 OneUI 7.0 (S25u) device. The user observed the core producing continuous error messages while simply running the system and collecting logs. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file or module) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that led to these core errors.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: android.gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated mockk test dependency (mockk was pinned to 1.13.10) that needed to be updated to 1.13.13 — the older mockk version introduced a bug/compatibility issue (primitive unboxing/Kotlin compatibility) that led to the observed failures.

instruction: In Thanox, there was a runtime failure reported on OneUI7 devices: when a new app process was being started under LSPosed hooks, Thanox logged errors from its process-start hook and the hook failed to complete, producing noisy error output and breaking the intended OOM/adj handling. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure (which file/module in the code was responsible and what exactly went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is github.tornaco.android.thanos.services.patch.common.am.XProcessRecordHelper (file: services/patch/common/am/XProcessRecordHelper.java). The predicted root cause reason is a reflective method lookup failure (NoSuchMethodError) caused by calling a ProcessStateRecord#setMaxAdj method with the wrong signature/type (method signature changed/removed on the platform), i.e., a signature mismatch when using XposedHelpers to call setMaxAdj (missing/incorrect parameter type leading to method not found).

instruction: In the Thanox app, enabling the “后台运行” (background run) feature caused some protection rules to stop working: apps set to be kept alive (e.g., “不清理播放音频的应用”, “不清理最近任务中的应用”, whitelist) were still killed — for example AntennaPod was terminated about 15s after screen-off even though it was configured to be preserved. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: android.gradle.libs.versions). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated dependency version (chucker pinned to 4.0.0) causing incompatibility; updating chucker to 4.1.0 resolved the issue.

instruction: In the Thanox app, Thanox-Core was repeatedly logging errors and contributing to high CPU usage whenever the system's usage-stats pipeline reported usage events (for example around user unlock / usage reporting). The observed behavior was continuous "reportEvent error" noise coming from the core while the system was handling usage events. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is github.tornaco.android.thanos.services.xposed.hooks.UsageStatsServiceRegistry (file: UsageStatsServiceRegistry.java) in the thanox-core module. The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect type assumption / bad cast inside the Xposed hook: the code casts a method argument to android.app.usage.UsageEvents$Event while the actual argument is an Integer (wrong parameter index or wrong method signature handling), causing a ClassCastException.

instruction: In Thanox, there was a UI bug in the app-management screens (e.g., Activity Management, Broadcast Manager) where an SDK entry (for example, "Pangle sdk") only showed a single source/item even though multiple activities/sources actually existed. As a result, toggling/ disabling an item could appear to work but after leaving and returning the switch would be back on because the UI only presented one of the entries. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect single-item display.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is /android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: android) — the com.tencent:mmkv dependency/version used by the app. The predicted root cause reason is a bug in the MMKV version in use (a multi-process MMKV loading/storage issue) that caused stored SDK source collections to be read incorrectly (truncating or collapsing multiple entries into a single entry), resulting in only one SDK source being shown.

instruction: In the Thanox repository/app, there was a bug where the system quick settings "Sensors off" tile that the user manually turned on would be automatically turned off after the device was turned off and back on the screen, even though Thanox's own "Close sensors" feature was disabled. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed Thanox to override or reset the user-enabled QS "Sensors off" switch when it should not have.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (Module: android.gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is an unintended dependency version bump (chucker 4.0.0 -> 4.1.0 and mockk 1.13.9 -> 1.13.10) that changed runtime behavior and caused Thanox to overwrite/restore the QS "Sensors off" tile state on resume (i.e., a dependency update introduced an unexpected side-effect that reset the user-enabled sensor toggle).

instruction: In the Thanox repository/app, users reported that after enabling Zygisk and installing the module via Magisk, the module could not be activated — tapping the patch/activation status produced no response and the UI appeared unresponsive. This happened on devices like Honor V20 (Magic OS 2.1, Android 9) using the Play version 5.0.6-row; the reporter could only install the module by manually copying and renaming an APK. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: org.mozilla:rhino-runtime / org.mozilla.javascript). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/buggy Rhino JavaScript runtime dependency (version 1.7.13) causing the app's scripting/activation path to fail or become unresponsive; upgrading the dependency to 1.7.14 fixes the issue.

instruction: In Thanox repository/app, there was a bug where the WeChat '模拟消息' (simulate message) action under the WeChat proxy feature produced no notification when tapped. This happened when trying to trigger a simulated incoming message via the app's UI — nothing appeared as a notification. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that allowed this behavior to occur.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (the libs version catalog entry for org.mozilla:rhino-runtime). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/buggy org.mozilla:rhino-runtime version (1.7.13) causing the script engine used for simulating messages to fail; the issue was resolved by upgrading to rhino-runtime 1.7.14.

instruction: In the Thanox app, a user reported that their scenario (automation) to auto-switch Bluetooth worked when launching a monitored app (Bluetooth would be enabled), but when that app was stopped the automation did not turn Bluetooth off as expected. This happened on Realme GT Neo3 (Android 12) with Thanox 4.1.1 (Xposed). Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what specifically went wrong) that allowed this behavior to occur.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: com.github.skydoves:landscapist-glide). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/incorrect dependency version entry (landscapist-glide set to 2.4.4) that needed to be bumped to 2.4.7 (dependency version mismatch/outdated dependency).

instruction: In the Thanox repository/app, there was a bug where the per-app "force show in recent tasks" setting for apps like WeChat would work until the device was rebooted — after reboot the forced-show behavior stopped working (swiping away the app's recent-task card then immediately reopening the app would cause the app to hang), and manually toggling the same setting in the UI made the behavior work again. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this regression: which file/module was responsible and what specifically went wrong (the underlying bug or missing behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is thanox-core/src/main/java/com/tornaco/thanox/module/privacy/RecentTaskPolicyManager.java (module :thanox-core). The predicted root cause reason is that the forced-show recent-task state was not being restored/applied after device reboot (missing restore/apply during init/BOOT handling), so the in-memory enforcement was lost — essentially a missing re-application of persisted settings on startup (initialization order/missing boot handling).

instruction: In the Thanox repository/app, there was a "Framework error" reported by users running the app (Android 12 on a Sony device) where the app's core/service failed and a framework error dialog appeared. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure — specify the specific file/module that was fixed and the underlying reason why the error occurred.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: android.gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect/outdated dependency version: the com.github.skydoves:landscapist-glide dependency was pinned to 2.4.4 and needed to be bumped to 2.4.7 (dependency version mismatch causing the failure).

instruction: In Thanox, there was a problem where the Magisk module failed to work after exporting and flashing because the file system/framework/thanox-bridge.jar was reported missing during installation. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the missing thanox-bridge.jar in the Magisk module packaging and installation process.  In Thanox, there was a problem where the Magisk module failed to work after exporting and flashing because the file system/framework/thanox-bridge.jar was reported missing during installation. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the missing thanox-bridge.jar in the Magisk module packaging and installation process.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is magisk-module packaging script/template that assembles system files — e.g. magisk-module/build.sh or the magisk module template path at magisk-module/template/system/framework/thanox-bridge.jar (module reference: :magisk-module). The predicted root cause reason is that the thanox-bridge.jar was not included/copied into the Magisk module during packaging (missing file in module template or missing copy step), causing the installer to report system/framework/thanox-bridge.jar as absent.

instruction: In Thanox, there was a bug where enabling the “skip apps with notifications” option in 乖巧模式 (gentle/polite mode) did not actually skip an app that had an active download notification. In the reported case, dvget showed a download-progress notification in the status bar, was switched to the background, but about 2 seconds later the download progress stalled, the notification disappeared and the app was put into 乖巧 (gentle) mode; disabling gentle mode allowed the download to resume. instruction: In the APatch repository/app, users reported that the device often fails to boot cleanly: on boot or reboot the screen frequently goes black at the boot UI or immediately after entering the device password, and only after repeating boot/restart several times does the system become usable. instruction: In the APatch repository, after flashing a patched boot.img produced by the APatch tooling the device unexpectedly reboots as soon as it reaches the lock screen. instruction: In the APatch app/repository, installing APatch build 10763 and using it to patch the kernel to version 0.10.7 caused a Samsung S23 Ultra to enter a bootloop (device shows the warning logo, pressing power reboots, whereas reverting to an earlier APatch version that produced kernel 0.10.5 boots fine). The bug reproduces by installing the 10763 app, directly patching to 0.10.7 and rebooting (and the same patched image flashed from TWRP also fails to boot). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the bad patched image and resulting bootloop.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is apd/Cargo.lock (Module: apd.CargoLock) and apd/Cargo.toml (Module: apd.CargoToml). The predicted root cause reason is a dependency version bump in the apd Rust crate (notably updates to compression/zip-related crates such as miniz_oxide/flate2/zip and related checksum changes) that changed packaging/compression behavior of the patching tool, producing an incorrect/corrupted patched boot image which caused the device to bootloop.

instruction: In the APatch repository, a bug was reported in the Manager when updating/downloading modules whose display names contain a slash ("/"). When attempting to update such a module the download completes according to the notification, but APatch does not begin installation and the downloaded ZIP ends up placed into an unexpected subdirectory (the slash in the module name is treated as a path separator). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/bmax121/apatch/manager/DownloadManager.kt (module: apatch-manager.manager.DownloadManager). The predicted root cause reason is that module names containing '/' were not sanitized/escaped when constructing the local download file path, so the slash was interpreted as a directory separator resulting in files being saved to the wrong directory and preventing the post-download installation step.

instruction: In APatch, there was a crash of the BankID app when launching on devices that had a patched boot image flashed by APatch. instruction: In APatch, the DSU sideloader stopped working: when opening the DSU sideloader and tapping the Setup button the app no longer allows choosing the temporary files location and, after a reboot, an alert appears that the file has stopped working. This dependency change caused a runtime/native failure in the apd library used by the DSU sideloader (a dependency/version incompatibility introduced by the dependency bump).

instruction: In the APatch repository, the original Manager app crashes (stops working) when the user attempts to hide the Manager. instruction: In the APatch repository, users reported that Chromium crashes when launched inside a chroot environment because the browser's sandbox cannot be used there, while running the same setup after rooting with Magisk allows the sandbox to work. instruction: In APatch, there was a bug where enabling ZygiskNext caused the Manager app to crash whenever the user tried to patch the boot image or install Magisk modules; disabling ZygiskNext allowed those operations to succeed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason

instruction: In APatch, there was a failure when installing a Magisk module (youtube-revanced-magisk-v19.04.37-all.zip): the installer reported "Mount failed" and "SU not found" and the module installation did not complete. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason

instruction: In APatch, there was a failure where the module manager and the superuser (root) authorization page became non-functional after the device had been running for a few minutes to a few hours. instruction: In the APatch repository, users reported that Magisk modules could not be flashed and the APatch Manager could not be hidden — the failure occurred when attempting to install Magisk modules or to hide the manager via the app/daemon. instruction: In the APatch repository/app, there was a problem where granting Root permissions to the MacroDroid app caused MacroDroid to fail to open properly (white screen / crash) while revoking Root made the app work normally. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason

instruction: In APatch, there was a user-facing crash where the APatch Manager would crash during verification and fail to run normally when the device/system language was set to a non-English locale. instruction: In APatch, a user reported that patching a boot.img extracted from CRDroid 10 (Android 14) on a Redmi Note 9 (Merlinx) failed. instruction: In deltachat-android, there was an F-Droid build failure: an automated F-Droid build of the app failed while producing a new release, preventing the app from being built and published. instruction: In deltachat-android, opening the map from a conversation caused the app to crash instead of displaying the map. instruction: In deltachat-android, there was a problem where images or text shared from other apps would appear to send but then keep reappearing in the chat as unsent/draft items (the shared content is actually sent, yet it keeps showing up repeatedly as a draft). This happened when using the system share flow (send -> Delta Chat -> switch to Delta Chat, enter optional text, press send), and the draft repeatedly appears in the same conversation after connectivity or app-state changes. The predicted root cause reason is that direct-sharing logic which opens the conversation was executed from a method (refreshTitle) that is called on connectivity/state changes, causing a new ConversationActivity to be opened repeatedly — i.e., the direct-share initiation was placed in a frequently-invoked callback (missing a one-time/open-once guard), leading to duplicate/reappearing draft state.

instruction: In deltachat-android, there was a crash occurring when notifications were being processed on some devices (for example, Nexus 4 running Android 8.1). The predicted root cause reason is that a blocking/background-only image-loading API was invoked on the main/UI thread (a Glide Request/submit().get() or GlideApp.get() call), causing an assertion/crash because the operation must be performed off the main thread.

instruction: In maui-samples, there was a crash in the FlyoutPageSample app on Windows: when a user selects any item from the flyout the app breaks and terminates. The predicted root cause reason is that the code unconditionally sets IsPresented = false when handling a flyout selection (missing guard for split-mode), causing an invalid state change on Windows (attempting to change IsPresented while in split/default presentation mode) which triggers the crash.

instruction: In badgemagic-app, there was a layout overflow in the About Us screen observed on a 6.2" (403 ppi) device: text and UI elements on the About Us page were overflowing / getting cut off instead of wrapping or truncating appropriately. The predicted root cause reason is that Text and Row children on the About Us screen lacked proper wrapping and sizing constraints (missing softWrap/Flexible and TextOverflow handling) and the image had no fit, which allowed content to exceed available layout space and cause overflow on certain screen sizes.

instruction: In the badgemagic-app, there was a UI problem where the AnimationContainer and EffectsContainer layouts overflowed on smaller screens (e.g., a Motorola G5 Plus) so parts of the images/controls extended beyond the container and caused layout clipping/overflow. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: point to the file/module that needed fixing and explain what in that component caused the overflow behavior.

The predicted root cause reason is that the Image widgets used fixed explicit heights (preventing them from scaling down) and lacked responsive layout/wrapping (no Flexible/BoxFit containment), causing the images to overflow on small screens.

instruction: In cgeo, there was a crash when a user tried to open a GPX file via the Android "Open with" / content provider flow (for example, from the Files app choosing "Open with: c:geo GPX import"). The app immediately crashed and could not be restarted normally afterwards. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this failure.

The predicted root cause reason is that intent handling did not account for ACTION_VIEW (a GPX opened via content provider), so the attachment invocation check/flow left the list type (CacheListType) null and a subsequent access to navigationMenuItem caused a NullPointerException.

instruction: In the cgeo repository/app, importing a GPX file that contains the same ascent split into two tracks produced an incorrect elevation plot: when the track is a single segment the max altitude is shown correctly, but when the same data are stored as two tracks inside the same GPX the second track appears to start at the same altitude as the first and the reported maximum elevation is wrong. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason explaining why the elevation data become incorrect when multiple track segments are present.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is main/src/main/java/cgeo/geocaching/files/AbstractTrackOrRouteParser.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.files.AbstractTrackOrRouteParser) and main/src/main/java/cgeo/geocaching/files/GPXTrackOrRouteParser.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.files.GPXTrackOrRouteParser). The predicted root cause reason is that the elevation list for points was not properly handled/reset between track segments (wrong/unstable variable usage), causing elevation values from previous segments to be reused/merged into subsequent segments and producing an incorrect elevation plot and wrong max elevation.

instruction: In the cgeo app, there was a bug where enabling the Unified Map and then mapping a list from History with a filter applied (e.g., excluding found/owned) resulted in no geocaches being shown on the Unified Map, while the non-Unified map displayed them correctly. The predicted root cause reason is that the Unified Map was launched in list mode without propagating the current GeocacheFilterContext (missing/incorrect parameter propagation), causing the default/offline filter to be used and the user-applied filter to be ignored.

instruction: In the cgeo app, there was a crash when opening a cache that contains a waypoint using a calculated/projected coordinate if one of the projection variables had no value (was left empty or deleted). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is main/src/main/java/cgeo/geocaching/models/Waypoint.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.models.Waypoint) and main/src/main/java/cgeo/geocaching/utils/formulas/Formula.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.utils.formulas.Formula). instruction: In the cgeo app, GPX routes exported from the GME map editor and loaded via “Load track/route from GPX” are displayed as disjointed: only some segments of the drawn route are shown (it looks like every other segment is missing). This happens when viewing routes/tracks on the map after loading the GPX. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that lead to these non-connected / partially missing route segments.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is main/src/main/java/cgeo/geocaching/models/Route.java (class cgeo.geocaching.models.Route, method getGeoData). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect conditional logic when assembling route segments: points for segments that are not linked to the previous segment were never added (missing/incorrect handling of rs.getPoints() for non-linked segments), causing every other segment to be skipped and the route to appear disjointed.

instruction: In the cgeo app, the map view would sometimes crash and return the user to the home screen after the phone was locked and then unlocked while a GPX track/route was displayed (screen briefly blank/white, then app returns to home). This happened intermittently and was not reliably reproducible. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these random map crashes after locking/unlocking the device.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is main/src/cgeo/geocaching/maps/mapsforge/v6/caches/AbstractCachesOverlay.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.maps.mapsforge.v6.caches.AbstractCachesOverlay). The predicted root cause reason is that removing layers during map lifecycle shutdown could throw an IllegalStateException when a layer was not assigned/attached internally (i.e., state inconsistency), and this exception was not handled, causing the map to crash.

instruction: In the cgeo repository/app, there was a filtering problem: some geocache items that had both 'disabled' (deactivated) and 'archived' status at the same time were not shown when the user applied the filter for archived-only caches. This was observed after importing certain lists (e.g., pocket queries) where caches could carry both flags. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is main/src/cgeo/geocaching/models/Geocache.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.models.Geocache). The predicted root cause reason is that the isDisabled() logic did not account for the archived state: disabled was returned as true even when a cache was archived (missing/incorrect check to let archived state win), causing archived caches that were also marked disabled to be treated as disabled and thus filtered out.

instruction: In the cgeo app, users reported that when viewing the cache details on the waypoints page, long-pressing or tapping the compass icon on the right (to open the map for that waypoint) often triggers the fast-scroll/scrollbar instead of opening the map. This started happening after a recent update and makes it hard to access the map view from the waypoint list. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the compass/tap being intercepted by scrolling behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is main/src/cgeo/geocaching/ui/FastScrollListener.java (module: cgeo.geocaching.ui.FastScrollListener). Additionally, the waypoint list layout was involved: main/res/layout/cachedetail_waypoints_page.xml and main/res/values/dimens.xml (module references: res/layout/cachedetail_waypoints_page and res/values/dimens).  The predicted root cause reason is that the fast-scroll touch handling overlapped the compass touch area and remained active for too long (timeout too high), combined with insufficient right-side padding on the waypoint list; as a result touch/long-press events intended for the compass were captured by the fast-scroll handler instead of the compass action.

instruction: In the aves app, users reported that while browsing the gallery and scrolling through images for about a minute the app suddenly crashes. The crash reliably happens after scrolling/viewing images for some time, often after a logo appears in the status bar and then the app abruptly exits. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/deckers/thibault/aves/utils/ImageLoader.kt (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is an OutOfMemoryError caused by decoding or retaining full-size bitmaps (no proper downscaling / missing bitmap recycling or cache management) leading to memory exhaustion while scrolling.

instruction: In the aves repository/app, the application crashes immediately on launch on a very old phone (32-bit ARM device). This happens right when starting the app and prevents it from running at all. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain why the app cannot start on that device.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is that 32-bit ARM native libraries were excluded (abiFilters or APK splits omitted armeabi-v7a), causing a missing native library (UnsatisfiedLinkError) on the old ARM device at startup.

instruction: In the aves repository/app, there was a regression where the app's UI became slow and unresponsive when scrolling through the gallery (users report janky, laggy scrolling starting in v1.12.9). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this performance regression.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/scorecards.yml (CI workflow: ossf/scorecard-action usage). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/pinned OSSF scorecard action version that was bumped (ossf/scorecard-action@f49aabe0b5af0936 -> ossf/scorecard-action@05b42c6), i.e., the CI workflow configuration needed an action version update.

instruction: In the aves app, users reported that trying to edit a photo always fails: after opening a photo and selecting Edit from the menu, a system dialog says "There are no apps that can handle this." Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that made the app unable to find an external editor. Specifically, name the file/module where the fix should be applied and explain the underlying mistake that caused the edit intent to have no matching handlers.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/app/src/main/kotlin/deckers/thibault/aves/AvesActivity.kt (module: android/app/src/main/kotlin/deckers/thibault/aves). The predicted root cause reason is that the code built the edit Intent incorrectly (missing or wrong MIME/type setting when setting the Uri — e.g., using setData() without setType() or otherwise not using setDataAndType()), so the resulting Intent did not match any apps (missing proper data type on the edit intent).

instruction: In the Aves app repository, users reported that almost every video they play will stutter on certain devices (mostly custom Android 15 ROMs). The stutter occurs during normal playback while other gallery apps on the same OS play the same videos fine. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/scorecards.yml (module: .github/workflows/scorecards.yml in the CI/workflow configuration). The predicted root cause reason is an environmental/platform issue: missing or incompatible native video codec/decoder libraries on some custom Android 15 ROMs causing the app to fall back to software decoding (or otherwise use a suboptimal playback path) and resulting in video stutter.

instruction: In the Aves app, users reported that after selecting photos and adding tags via the app's Tag quick action, duplicate images appeared in Google Photos (a copy for every tag added), even though the underlying files shown in file managers did not appear duplicated. This happened after leaving the Aves app and viewing the same date in Google Photos. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that was addressed to resolve this issue.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/scorecards.yml (the GitHub Actions workflow that uses the ossf/scorecard-action). The predicted root cause reason is that the workflow was pinned to an older ossf/scorecard-action version and was updated (bumped) from v2.4.0 to v2.4.1 (uses: ossf/scorecard-action@f49aabe0b5af0936a0987cfb85d86b75731b0186), i.e., an outdated third-party GitHub Action version required updating.

instruction: In aves, when playing a video the device screen turns off after the system screen timeout instead of staying on until the video finishes. This happens consistently when a long video is playing and the phone obeys the Android screen-off timeout rather than keeping the display awake for playback. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/viewer/video_viewer.dart (module: lib.viewer.video_viewer). The predicted root cause reason is that video playback did not enable a wakelock / request keep-screen-on (missing wakelock or keepScreenOn logic), so the system screen timeout turned the display off during playback.

instruction: In the aves app, users reported a crash / complete failure to browse images after minimizing the app to the recent apps list, opening an image from the file explorer using Aves, then returning to the app. After returning, the gallery view failed to show all images (only newly added images appeared). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain this behavior: which file/module introduced the problem and what went wrong (the underlying bug or missing handling) that would produce the observed failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/deckers/thibault/aves/AvesActivity.kt (module: app).  The predicted root cause reason is improper handling of incoming VIEW intents / activity lifecycle on resume (missing or incorrect onNewIntent/state reset). The activity left the viewer in a single-item or stale collection state and did not reload or reset the gallery collection when a new VIEW intent/task transition occurred (e.g., missing setIntent/onNewIntent handling or missing collection reload), causing most images to be unavailable after returning.

instruction: In the Aves Android app, users reported that while running a slideshow (shuffle mode) after viewing many items the screen sometimes turns completely black and the app stops responding to any input (next/previous or Android back), requiring killing and relaunching the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was fixed) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that led to this freeze/unresponsiveness.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/slideshow/slideshow_controller.dart (module: slideshow / package:aves). The predicted root cause reason is that heavy image decoding work was being performed on the UI/main isolate (synchronous/blocking work), blocking the event loop and causing the UI to hang (black screen and no input responsiveness).

instruction: In the Aves repository/app, users reported that when they download a new image to their phone, the Aves gallery takes a very long time to show the newly downloaded image in the image list compared with other gallery apps. This happens after downloading an image from another app and then opening Aves; the new image does not appear promptly. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/dependency-review.yml (Module: github.workflows.dependency_review_yml). The predicted root cause reason is that the change only updated a GitHub Actions dependency (CI/workflow file) and did not modify any application code responsible for media discovery/refresh; the PR is unrelated to the image-refresh behaviour (i.e., no actual fix for the slow display was applied).

instruction: In the Aves app repository, users reported that they could no longer edit photos or other media from the app: tapping “Edit” on any saved photo shows the error “there are no apps that can handle this.” Editing still works only immediately after taking a screenshot (before saving). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this regression — specify the exact file/module responsible and explain what went wrong that made external editors unavailable for saved media.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/dev/deckerst/aves/intent/IntentUtils.kt (the module handling creation/launching of external edit intents). The predicted root cause reason is that the intent used to launch external editors did not grant read access to the content URI (missing FLAG_GRANT_READ_URI_PERMISSION / missing ClipData URI permission), so external apps could not access the saved media and the system reported no apps could handle the intent.

instruction: In the aves repository, continuous integration workflows began failing: builds, release jobs and the dependency review step were failing during the GitHub Actions runs, preventing successful build/release checks from completing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/quality-check.yml (Module: github.workflows.quality_check), .github/workflows/release.yml (Module: github.workflows.release), and .github/workflows/dependency-review.yml (Module: github.workflows.dependency_review). The predicted root cause reason is that GitHub Actions were pinned to outdated/incorrect action revisions (actions/setup-java and actions/dependency-review-action), so the workflows used older action versions that lacked required bugfixes/behavior (necessitating bumping to newer patch releases v4.7.1 and v4.3.5).

instruction: In the aves app, tapping a video thumbnail to open it in the viewer caused the app to crash (images open fine). This happened for multiple video files and persisted after reinstalling the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is packages/aves/lib/src/viewer/video_viewer.dart (Module: packages.aves.lib) The predicted root cause reason is initialization of the native media_kit player causing a native crash under hardened_malloc (incompatible native library behavior) with no guarded fallback/exception handling, leading to the app process crashing.

instruction: In the Aves app, adding tags to certain MP4 videos that contain multiple MDAT atoms caused the video file to become corrupt and unplayable after tagging. This happened when a user attempted to write metadata/tags to such MP4 files. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/app/src/main/java/deckers/thibault/aves/metadata/mp4/MP4TagEditor.kt (module: app/src/main/java/deckers.thibault.aves:metadata/mp4/MP4TagEditor.kt). The predicted root cause reason is improper handling of MP4 files with multiple 'mdat' atoms — the code assumed a single MDAT (or merged/rewrote MDATs incorrectly), leading to incorrect box/offset updates and truncation/corruption of the file (missing handling/logic for multiple MDAT boxes).

instruction: In the aves app, users reported that applying tags to one or more images from the thumbnail (grid) view intermittently failed: when selecting a cluster of images and adding tags, only one image received the tag while the others were not updated. The problem happened from the thumbnail selection workflow (no error shown when viewing a single image). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused tag updates to not be applied to all selected items.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/src/selection/selection_actions.dart (selection/tag-apply handler) or the module responsible for batch tag edits in the selection workflow (selection/tag application code). The predicted root cause reason is an async/batch processing bug: the batch tag application logic did not correctly process or await updates for all selected items (e.g., using an async forEach or otherwise failing to await/apply updates for each item), causing only the first item to be updated and the remaining updates to be skipped or discarded.

instruction: In the Aves Android app, a user reported that after moving photos and videos to a nested folder on an SD card and running a rescan, a small set of moved photos did not appear in the app's collection. Repeated rescans and clearing the app cache did not help, but uninstalling and reinstalling the app made the missing photos appear immediately. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure (which file/module was fixed and why it caused the problem).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/quality-check.yml (module: github.workflows.quality_check) and .github/workflows/release.yml (module: github.workflows.release). The predicted root cause reason is that GitHub Actions were pinned to outdated action versions/commits (actions/setup-java and actions/attest-build-provenance), requiring version bumps (i.e., an outdated CI action configuration caused the problem and was fixed by updating those action versions).

instruction: In the Aves Android app, users reported that gestures in the image viewer are often missed, ignored, or misinterpreted (for example, fast swipes to go to the next image or swiping up to view info frequently require repeating the gesture). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file or module in the repository contained the root cause, and what specifically went wrong to cause the gesture recognition to fail.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/dependency-review.yml, .github/workflows/quality-check.yml, .github/workflows/release.yml, and .github/workflows/scorecards.yml (modules: github.workflows.dependency_review, github.workflows.quality_check, github.workflows.release, github.workflows.scorecards). The predicted root cause reason is that the submitted change only updated CI workflow actions (bumped step-security/harden-runner version) and did not modify any application code handling viewer gestures — i.e., no fix for the gesture handling bug was provided in the repository.

instruction: In the Aves Android app, users observed that when they moved media to the Recycle Bin and then cleared the Recycle Bin, the items were not actually removed from device storage — after closing and reopening the app the photos reappeared in the collection. This happened when a user moved a picture to the recycle bin, cleared the bin, and then relaunched the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that allowed cleared items to remain on storage instead of being deleted.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/src/storage/recycle_bin.dart (module: package:aves/src/storage/recycle_bin.dart). The predicted root cause reason is that the clear/delete path used direct file deletion (or otherwise bypassed the MediaStore/ContentResolver/SAF APIs required on modern Android) / missing appropriate deletion call or permission check, so files were never actually removed from device storage (scoped storage misuse / missing proper delete handling).

instruction: In the aves app, users reported that location details stopped showing full address information (street, number, city, etc.) and instead only showed a three-letter country code (for example, Belgium appeared as "BEL"). This change in behavior was observed when browsing item/location details. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that explains this regression.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/dependency-review.yml (and the other workflow files changed in the PR: .github/workflows/quality-check.yml, .github/workflows/release.yml, .github/workflows/scorecards.yml) — i.e., the change was only to the CI workflow (step-security/harden-runner) and not to the app code handling location display. The predicted root cause reason is that the reported location-display bug was not addressed in this change: the PR only bumped a CI dependency (harden-runner) and made no code changes to the location/geocoding logic, so there is no fix for the actual bug in the submitted changes.

instruction: In the Aves Android app, users reported that gallery thumbnails sometimes appear duplicated or show "the file no longer exists" when a duplicated image has been moved or deleted. The problem can persist even after a complete app reinstall and is observed when the media cache or its permissions are corrupted. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module in the codebase was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong in that component) that would lead to these stale/duplicated thumbnails and the failure to recover after reinstall.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/dev/deckerst/aves/thumbnails/ThumbnailCache.kt (module: :app). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect thumbnail cache key / invalidation logic: the cache used an unstable or insufficient identifier (e.g., file path/name only) and did not properly invalidate entries when media were moved, deleted, or when permissions changed, causing stale or duplicated thumbnails to be served.  (Alternative acceptable component paths that refer to the same logical area may include the thumbnail repository/provider implementation, e.g., app/src/main/java/.../thumbnail/ThumbnailRepository.kt or app/src/main/java/.../thumbnail/ThumbnailProvider.kt, with the same reason about broken cache key/invalidation.)

instruction: In the aves app, users reported that when viewing the monthly collection the app only showed photos stored on the device's primary (local) storage while photos kept on a removable SD card were missing from the view. This occurred when opening the app and browsing the month collection — expected behavior was to see all photos for that month regardless of whether they were on internal storage or an SD card. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/release.yml (GitHub Actions workflow: release.yml). The predicted root cause reason is the GitHub release action was pinned to an older version of ncipollo/release-action (v1.14.0); the fix was to bump the action to v1.15.0 (i.e., an outdated/incorrect CI workflow action version).

instruction: In the Aves repository/app, users reported a problem related to SVGs when creating a ZIP export: the produced ZIP/release artifact contained unexpected/incorrect SVG output (the export artifact was wrong) when performing the release/export operation. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect ZIP/export behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/release.yml (module: github.workflows.release.yml). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/pinned GitHub Action (actions/attest-build-provenance) version; the workflow was using v2.2.0 which caused the build/attestation/release artifact issue, and bumping it to v2.2.2 fixed the problem.

instruction: In komodo-wallet, there were crashes reported in the address book and send flows: (1) when creating or editing a contact, deleting the contact name to an empty string and then confirming and later re-editing the contact caused the application to crash; and (2) clicking the "send" button for the Smart Chain option caused the app to crash instead of presenting the expected selection of smartchain networks. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was fixed) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) for these failures.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/core/atomicdex/models/qt.addressbook.contact.model.cpp (module: atomic_dex.addressbook_contact_model) and atomic_defi_design/Dex/Wallet/SendModalContactList.qml (module: Dex.Wallet.SendModalContactList). The predicted root cause reason is that the addressbook contact model lacked validation/handling for empty contact names (missing check/guard for empty name leading to invalid model/index access and a crash), and the send flow lacked proper normalization/handling of the "Smart Chain" network type (missing/incorrect coin-type mapping causing an unhandled backend "No such coin" condition).

instruction: In komodo-wallet, there was a crash on macOS (M1) that occurred while switching UI tabs (for example, from the Dashboard to the DEX). The app would terminate unexpectedly and users reported the coin-graph area showing a white/blank screen around the time of the tab switch. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is atomic_defi_design/qml/Exchange/Trade/CandleStickChart.qml (module: atomic_defi_design.qml.Exchange.Trade.CandleStickChart). The predicted root cause reason is unsafe creation/destruction/reparenting of a WebEngineView (QQuickWebEngineView) per-chart — dynamic instantiation and teardown of the WebEngineView caused the Qt WebEngine to crash on destruction (missing reuse/proper cleanup/reparenting of the single web engine instance).

instruction: In komodo-wallet (atomicDEX-Pro), the user reported that after performing many swaps the 'Recent swaps' page suddenly cleared and new swaps stopped appearing in the UI even though the swap data still exists in the database. The issue was observed on Windows and the application log showed a panic in the background swap service which appears to coincide with the moment history stopped updating. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain why the history UI stopped updating (what file/module was responsible and what went wrong to cause this behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mm2src/coins/lp_coins.rs (module: coins::lp_coins). The predicted root cause reason is an unwrap() on a Result that returned Err (missing error handling) which caused a panic in the swap/coins code when an OS/file operation failed on Windows (leading to the background service crash and broken swaps history).

instruction: In komodo-wallet, there was a failure observed when attempting to build (particularly on Windows). After following the build steps, the build/validation step reported missing configuration JSON files and the build failed during a validation check that expects certain asset/config files to be present. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/actions/validate-build/action.yml (Module: github.actions.validate-build.action). The predicted root cause reason is the CI validation script was checking for configuration/asset files at outdated/hardcoded locations (and for a removed build_config.json), causing file-not-found validation failures after assets/configuration were moved/managed by the SDK (incorrect path/variable usage in the action).

instruction: In the LibreTube app, users observed that YouTube Music search tabs did not load correctly: search results for albums/playlists often showed no titles, and tapping an album led to endless loading (though pasting the album’s direct link worked). Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the underlying reason why these two symptoms occurred.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/github/libretube/extensions/ToID.kt (module: com.github.libretube.extensions.ToIDKt) and app/src/main/java/com/github/libretube/api/NewPipeMediaServiceRepository.kt (module: com.github.libretube.api.NewPipeMediaServiceRepository). The predicted root cause reason is twofold: 1) The ID/URL normalization function failed to strip the YouTube Music origin (missing handling for music.youtube.com and short URLs), producing malformed playlist IDs/URLs (which caused infinite loading when opening albums). 2) The content mapping omitted assigning the playlist name to the ContentItem (missing name field), causing titles to be absent in search results.
