instruction: In ALVR, there was an issue where when using Pico motion trackers configured to create fake Vive trackers, both elbow fake trackers showed up in SteamVR with the device name reported as "/device/ALVR/tracker/unknown" instead of distinct left/right elbow tracker names. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is alvr/server_openvr/cpp/alvr_server/FakeViveTracker.cpp (module: alvr.server_openvr.cpp.alvr_server.FakeViveTracker). The predicted root cause reason is that the code omitted the name/registration cases for the left and right elbow tracker device IDs (missing conditional branches / assignments), causing those devices to fall through to the default "ALVR/tracker/unknown" name.

instruction: In ALVR, there was a problem where the VR client would randomly disconnect from the server while streaming (e.g., during VRChat sessions). The disconnects appeared to be triggered by a transient socket I/O status, but the client treated that condition as a fatal error and disconnected the session. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is alvr/common/src/connection_result.rs (module: alvr.common.connection_result). The predicted root cause reason is that a transient Windows overlapped I/O condition (WSA_IO_PENDING / error code 997) was not treated as a non-fatal 'try again' case — there was no check to ignore/rawly handle error 997 on Windows, so the socket condition was classified as a fatal error and caused disconnection.

instruction: In ALVR, there was a compilation failure on Linux (Arch) after updating Vulkan headers: the build failed with an error reporting a missing member in the Vulkan dispatch object, preventing the project from compiling. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is alvr/server/cpp/platform/linux/ffmpeg_helper.h (module: alvr.server.cpp.platform.linux.ffmpeg_helper.VkContext). The predicted root cause reason is a missing member function getVkHeaderVersion() in the VkContext::dispatch struct (i.e., a missing version-getter required by newer vulkan-headers leading to a compile error).

instruction: In HeliBoard, there was a crash that almost always happened when typing the contraction "you'll" in any text input (or when completing/finding that word). The crash occurred while the keyboard was generating or updating suggestions. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/helium314/keyboard/latin/DictionaryFacilitatorImpl.kt (module: helium314.keyboard.latin.DictionaryFacilitatorImpl). The predicted root cause reason is an unchecked collection access in the suggestion-selection logic (use of first()/last() with predicates that can fail / inconsistent predicate logic), causing a NoSuchElementException when expected suggestion items are not present (incorrect handling of emoji vs typed-word checks).

instruction: In the Boorusama app, there was a bug where, after adding a blacklist tag from the UI, the current page would suddenly disappear (go blank). This happened while interacting with the blacklist/tag UI (the page vanishes immediately after the tag is added). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behavior: name the file or module that was fixed and explain what went wrong to cause the blank page.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/boot.dart (Module: boorusama.boot.boot). The predicted root cause reason is that the VideoControllerScope wrapper in the app bootstrap was incorrectly wrapping the app (misplaced scope/widget), which interfered with the app's provider/state lifecycle and caused the widget tree to be rebuilt/disposed in a way that produced a blank screen when a blacklist tag was added (i.e., an improper widget scope placement causing state/context loss).

instruction: In the Unciv app, declaring war on a civ that has defensive pacts caused distant third parties to be pulled into the war in a chain reaction. For example, attacking Siam led Byzantium's defensive pact partner China to also be declared at war, even though China was only allied to Byzantium and had no direct relation to the attacker. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/civilization/diplomacy/DeclareWar.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.civilization.diplomacy.DeclareWar). The predicted root cause reason is that defensive-pact ally calls were allowed to propagate/chain because the war type was not checked (missing guard for DefensivePactWar), causing callInDefensivePactAllies to be invoked recursively and pull unrelated civs into the war.

instruction: In the Unciv repository/app, there was a crash that caused a StackOverflowError whenever a player clicked “Next Turn” in a 3‑player multiplayer game after the v4.12.18 patch. This happened on both Windows and Android with no mods installed and prevented the game from advancing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason behind this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/json/Vector2Serializer.kt (and its registration in core/src/com/unciv/json/UncivJson.kt — modules: com.unciv.json.Vector2Serializer / com.unciv.json.UncivJsonKt), with the fault manifesting when serializing the automatedRoadConnectionPath field in core/src/com/unciv/logic/map/mapunit/MapUnit.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.map.mapunit.MapUnit). The predicted root cause reason is a faulty custom Vector2 serialization that caused infinite recursion / stack overflow when Vector2 objects were serialized inside lists (List<Vector2>), leading to a StackOverflowError during save/serialization (triggered on end turn).

instruction: In the Unciv app, there was a bug where the "Connect Road" pathfinding tried to route roads through Mountain tiles (which should be impassable) when connecting points on the map. This happened while attempting to generate a road path between tiles. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the pathfinder to treat mountain tiles as valid road path tiles.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/map/MapPathing.kt (Module: com.unciv.logic.map.MapPathing). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect boolean logic / operator precedence (missing parentheses) in the road-path validation check (isValidRoadPathTile) that allowed the "canBuildImprovement" condition to be ORed in a way that bypassed impassability and other checks, letting Mountains be considered valid road path tiles.

instruction: In the Unciv repository/app, the game crashed when the player clicked the 'Next Turn' button after several hours of normal play (last shown screen: WorldScreen). The crash happened during end-of-turn processing and caused the application to terminate unexpectedly. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: specify which file/module contained the faulty code that was fixed, and describe the actual bug (what went wrong) that led to the crash during the turn-processing flow.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/city/CityConstructions.kt (Module: com.unciv.logic.city.CityConstructions). The predicted root cause reason is that city-level handling of "free building" / construction updates was mutating city/civ state while iterating (causing an inconsistent state / concurrent modification during end-of-turn processing). This unsafe state modification during turn processing led to a crash, and the fix moves/changes the free-building and construction-completion handling to avoid those unsafe mutations.

instruction: In Unciv, there was a bug where a unit that should not be able to move (it had the "Cannot Move" unique) was nevertheless able to move when on roads — the unit showed a movement arrow and could traverse road tiles. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that allowed the unit to move).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/map/mapunit/MapUnitCache.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.map.mapunit.MapUnitCache). The predicted root cause reason is that the "CannotMove" unique was not cached/recognized by the movement logic (missing/absent cannotMove flag in the unit cache), so movement checks could be bypassed (e.g., on roads) and allowed a supposedly immobile unit to move.

instruction: In the Unciv repository/app, there was a failure when the game tried to check the online server status: the game logged that a remote server “does not support server feature set” and a SerializationException complaining it was "Unable to convert value to required type: true (com.unciv.logic.multiplayer.ServerFeatureSet)". This happened while the client was contacting an online multiplayer server to read its capabilities. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this failure: which file/module in the codebase is responsible, and what went wrong to cause the serialization error.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/multiplayer/OnlineMultiplayerServer.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.multiplayer.OnlineMultiplayerServer). The predicted root cause reason is a JSON deserialization type mismatch: the code attempts to deserialize a boolean value (true) into the ServerFeatureSet type (com.unciv.logic.multiplayer.ServerFeatureSet) — i.e., missing/incorrect handling of the server returning a boolean instead of the expected feature-set object (backward-compatibility/type check missing), causing a SerializationException.

instruction: In Unciv, there was an unexpected alert: the game showed "We have encountered the City-State of Kabul" even though that City-State had already been destroyed/defeated earlier in the playthrough. The alert appeared later when entering tiles near where that City-State had been, and no corresponding meet notification was shown. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/civilization/transients/CivInfoTransientCache.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.civilization.transients.CivInfoTransientCache). The predicted root cause reason is a missing defeat-state guard when updating/setting viewable tiles (i.e., the code allowed meeting/first-contact logic for defeated city-states because viewableTiles weren't cleared/ignored for defeated civs), resulting in false "encounter" alerts for dead City-States.

instruction: In Unciv, there was a UI bug where opening the city Cuzco (which has Petra) made two desert tiles belonging to another city (Cahokia) show their yields highlighted but did not allow placing a citizen on them. In other words, tiles that only provide yields via city-specific improvements (like Petra) appeared to have yields but could not be manually assigned to a worker. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason for this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/ui/components/tilegroups/CityTileGroup.kt (Module: com.unciv.ui.components.tilegroups.CityTileGroup). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect call to the tile stats function (wrong overload/arguments) — using getTileStats with only the civilization parameter instead of passing the city and civ, causing tiles whose yields depend on the city (e.g., Petra) to be treated as providing no yields and thus not selectable.

instruction: In the Unciv app, the Resources Overview screen showed incorrect counts: some worked-but-unimproved tiles (e.g., Horses, Citrus) were not listed in the overview table, so resource counts were lower than expected. This occurred while inspecting the Resources Overview for a player’s cities. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the missing unimproved resources in the overview table.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/ui/overviewscreen/ResourcesOverviewTable.kt (module: com.unciv.ui.overviewscreen.ResourcesOverviewTab). The predicted root cause reason is a control-flow/logic bug: an early continue/conditional caused the code to skip iterating city tiles when a city had no demanded resource, so unimproved resources on those tiles were not checked or counted (missing unimproved resource handling).

instruction: In Unciv, there was a crash when starting a new game after enabling the Epic of Fantasy mod and using the "Random nations pool" option with only mod nations selected: when choosing Random for one or more players and clicking Start game, the app crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/models/metadata/GameParameters.kt (module: com.unciv.models.metadata.GameParameters). The predicted root cause reason is that randomNations was persisted/handled as the wrong type (a collection of fully serialized Nation objects) which caused a type/serialization mismatch when consumed (code expected simple nation identifiers/strings), leading to runtime failure (missing/incorrect handling of the stored nation representation).

instruction: In the Unciv repository/app, promoting a Carrier (upgrading the unit) caused any air units on board to disappear as soon as the upgrade completed. This happened when performing a normal in-game upgrade action (e.g., Carrier -> Heavy Carrier) with units embarked. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/ui/worldscreen/unit/UnitActions.kt (module: com.unciv.ui.worldscreen.unit.UnitActions) and the related map unit behavior in core/src/com/unciv/logic/map/MapUnit.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.map.MapUnit). The predicted root cause reason is that the upgrade action destroyed the carrier by calling its destroy() method which, by default, also destroyed any transported units. The upgrade path lacked logic/flag to preserve transported units during unit replacement, so embarked air units were removed when the carrier was destroyed and replaced.

instruction: In the Unciv app, players observed that a city-state's "Recently paid tribute" penalty never expired — even after 150–200 turns — preventing them from demanding tribute from that city-state. This happened during normal play (Android/Bluestacks emulation) where the tribute cooldown should drop after ~20 turns but remained permanently active. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this infinite tribute cooldown behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/civilization/CityStateFunctions.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.civilization.CityStateFunctions). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect conditional check when applying the "Recently paid tribute" modifier: the code only tested that the recentBullying flag was non-null instead of verifying its numeric countdown is > 0, so the modifier continued to be applied even after the cooldown should have expired (missing proper value check).

instruction: In the Unciv app, there was a bug during diplomatic trade negotiations where an AI opponent's counteroffer could include a negative gold amount (for example, offering -15 gold in exchange for open borders). Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong to allow a negative gold offer to appear). In other words: identify the code component that needed fixing and explain why the AI was able to produce a negative-gold counteroffer.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/trade/TradeOffer.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.trade.TradeOffer). The predicted root cause reason is that offers with non-positive amounts (including negative gold) were treated as tradable by the AI because there was no tradability check/filter (missing/absent 'tradable' flag or check), allowing the AI to propose negative gold as a valid counteroffer.

instruction: In Unciv, there was a bug where a game would automatically end with a Time Victory even when the Time Victory option had been turned off in the game setup. Players reported that on long game speeds (e.g. Marathon or Epic) the game declared a time victory around turn 500 despite that victory type not being enabled. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/civilization/VictoryManager.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.civilization.VictoryManager). The predicted root cause reason is that the victory-checking logic used the rule set's list of victory types instead of the game's enabled victoryTypes (i.e., the code evaluated all possible victories from the ruleset rather than the active gameParameters), so a disabled Time Victory could still be detected and trigger an end-of-game.

instruction: In Unciv, there was an issue where the crash report produced by the game showed an empty "Save Data" section — the collapsible save-game panel on the generated crash report appeared blank even though a save existed. This happened when generating or copying crash reports from the game UI. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/ui/crashhandling/CrashScreen.kt (com.unciv.ui.crashhandling.CrashScreen). The predicted root cause reason is a formatting bug in the crash-report string: a missing newline after the Markdown code-fence (triple backticks) caused the saved-game data not to render in the GitHub crash report (i.e., incorrect string construction when embedding the save data).

instruction: In Unciv, Great People and some other units were observed to not provide or perform their unique abilities — for example a Great Prophet could not Spread Religion and a Great General did not provide the expected combat bonus to nearby units. This happened while loading or playing a saved game after generating a Great Person; the units appeared normally but their special actions/bonuses were unavailable. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/models/ruleset/unique/UniqueType.kt (module: com.unciv.models.ruleset.unique.UniqueType). The predicted root cause reason is missing enum entries/unique definitions for the Great Person (and other) uniques in the UniqueType enum, so those uniques were not recognized/applied by the game.

instruction: In Unciv, players reported that choosing the policy/unique option that should reduce the Faith cost to purchase Missionary units (e.g. "[Faith] cost of purchasing [Missionary] units [-30]%") did not actually lower the Faith cost of missionaries; Inquisitors were also unaffected. This happened when buying units in cities after selecting that discount. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/models/ruleset/unit/BaseUnit.kt (Module: com.unciv.models.ruleset.unit.BaseUnit) and core/src/com/unciv/models/ruleset/unique/UniqueType.kt (Module: com.unciv.models.ruleset.unique.UniqueType). The predicted root cause reason is that unit purchase discount uniques were not being matched/applied because the unique definition/text was changed/renamed (deprecated form vs new form) and the buy-cost logic only looked for one UniqueType variant. In short: a mismatch/renaming of the UniqueType (and missing handling of the deprecated variant) caused the discount not to be applied (missing handling of the deprecated unique in the cost calculation loop).

instruction: In Unciv, players reported that Petra (and similar improvements) were unavailable when a city was built on a single desert tile — the game would not allow Petra even though it should be buildable "on or next to" a desert. This happened in new games started in later eras and on a custom map where the city tile itself was desert. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to "on or adjacent to" terrain checks failing for these improvements.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/map/TileInfo.kt (Module: com.unciv.logic.map.TileInfo). The predicted root cause reason is that the adjacency check did not include the tile itself (it only checked neighbors), so conditions that should match a tile "on or adjacent to" a terrain (e.g., desert for Petra) failed when the tile itself had the terrain (missing self-inclusion in isAdjacentTo).

instruction: In the Unciv app, users reported crashes while using an experimental mod: the game would crash back to desktop while playing (last shown screen WorldScreen), and a crash report was produced when the game tried to evaluate certain conditional 'unique' rules for units. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash — i.e., which file/module contained the bug and what went wrong that caused the crash during evaluation of those conditionals.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/models/ruleset/unique/Unique.kt (module: com.unciv.models.ruleset.unique.Unique). The predicted root cause reason is eager evaluation of a unit tile via state.unit?.getTile() which accessed a MapUnit lateinit property (currentTile) before it was initialized, causing an UninitializedPropertyAccessException; in short, a missing deferred evaluation/null-safety around getTile() led to accessing uninitialized state.

instruction: In Unciv, there was a bug where units that were clearly standing in foreign territory did not show the expected combat bonus for being on foreign land. Whether it was a unit-specific bonus or a civilization-wide bonus, the strength increase did not appear in the battle breakdown UI when inspecting combat modifiers. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/battle/BattleDamage.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.battle.BattleDamage). The predicted root cause reason is that conditional battle modifiers did not include their conditional text in the modifier description generation (i.e., the code generating modifier strings omitted unique.conditionals / the condition description), so condition-based bonuses like the "Foreign Land" condition were not shown to the user.

instruction: In Unciv, after loading a saved game the application's RAM usage started relatively high and then grew steadily each time the player advanced a turn — e.g. clicking “next turn” ~20 times caused memory to climb from ~700 MB to multiple gigabytes and it stayed high. This happened while progressing normal turns (no 3D graphics, just game state updates). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/civilization/CivilizationInfo.kt (Module: com.unciv.logic.civilization.CivilizationInfo). The predicted root cause reason is that getCivResources() reconstructed a new ResourceSupplyList on every call (no cached summarized civ resources), causing repeated large allocations and steady memory growth (missing caching / unnecessary per-call allocations).

instruction: In the Unciv app, buildings like the Commune that are supposed to grant "+1 population in this city" were instead increasing population in every city of the player. This happened when such a unique effect was activated and the population change applied broadly rather than only to the intended city. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/models/ruleset/unique/UniqueTriggerActivation.kt (module: com.unciv.models.ruleset.unique.UniqueTriggerActivation). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect scoping logic / missing special-case handling: the code iterated over all civInfo.cities and used the general filter check (city.matchesFilter(unique.params[1])) instead of handling the tokens "in this city" and "in other cities" (and updating the notification logic accordingly), causing the population change to be applied to all cities.

instruction: In Unciv, there was a crash during the NextTurn processing that started happening right after a city was razed to the ground. The failure occurred while the game tried to update city religion/follower information during the end-of-turn flow, causing the turn sequence to abort. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/city/CityReligion.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.city.CityInfoReligionManager). The predicted root cause reason is that updateNumberOfFollowers was executed when a city's population could be zero (after razing), causing a division by zero when computing pressure per follower — i.e., a missing guard/early return for population <= 0.

instruction: In the Unciv app, units were observed sometimes remaining on tiles they no longer could legally occupy after events like city razing, capture, or liberation. When such a unit was selected (or its actions inspected), the game could crash or behave incorrectly. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason responsible for this bug: which file/module contained the defect, and what went wrong that allowed units to stay on illegal tiles or caused the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/src/com/unciv/logic/battle/Battle.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.battle.Battle), core/src/com/unciv/logic/city/CityInfo.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.city.CityInfo), and core/src/com/unciv/logic/city/CityInfoConquestFunctions.kt (module: com.unciv.logic.city.CityInfoConquestFunctions). The predicted root cause reason is that units were not being moved/teleported off tiles they could no longer legally occupy (missing relocation after capture/liberation/raze) and there was an order-of-operations bug when removing city ownership (relinquish/remove sequence) which allowed state updates to run against an invalid city/capital state, leading to crashes.

instruction: In the Unciv repository, spaceship part production bonuses from buildings/wonders (e.g., Forge, Spaceship Factory, Hubble Space Telescope) did not increase spaceship part build production as expected. When a city had these buildings the production time for spaceship parts showed no bonus and the city drilldown did not credit the spaceship-part production boost. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these bonuses not being applied.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/assets/jsons/Civ V - Vanilla/Buildings.json (Civ V - Vanilla Buildings JSON). The predicted root cause reason is that the spaceship-part production uniques were written to target spaceship parts as "units" (i.e., the unique string expected unit-type items), but spaceship parts are implemented as buildings — a type/matching mismatch in the uniques prevented the boost from applying.

instruction: In the reference-browser app, there was an issue where a shortcut created via the "Add to homescreen" action could not be opened: after creating the homescreen shortcut and tapping it, the device reported "Application not found" instead of opening the page in the app. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml (module: app.src.main.AndroidManifest). The predicted root cause reason is a missing intent category for shortcuts in the activity's intent-filter (the required shortcut category was not declared, so the launcher could not resolve/open the homescreen shortcut).

instruction: In reference-browser, the app crashes when you open the first tab after entering a URL or selecting a suggested clipboard link (this happens on a fresh install or when all tabs are closed). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/org/mozilla/reference/browser/components/BackgroundServices.kt (module: org.mozilla.reference.browser.components.BackgroundServices). The predicted root cause reason is an API/constructor mismatch for FxaAccountManager after the dependency upgrade (missing/incorrect DeviceTuple parameter and updated package/constructor signature), causing a runtime failure when the account manager is instantiated.

instruction: In apps-android-commons, there was a bug where tapping the numeric Coordinates in a photo's details to open/share the location sometimes opened the wrong place (positioning the target app at 0,0) in some external map/editing apps while working in others. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/location/LatLng.java (Module: fr.free.nrw.commons.location.LatLng). The predicted root cause reason is that the app constructed and sent an incorrect/non-standard geo: URI for the location intent (wrong URI format), causing many apps to misinterpret the coordinates (resulting in 0,0).

instruction: In apps-android-commons, there was an issue where, during image uploads, the app produced many API error log entries such as "code:badinteger" and "code:missingtitle" at ERROR priority even when the upload appeared to succeed. These noisy error logs were observed while the app was performing media lookup/upload-related network calls. Your task is to identify the root cause component and root cause reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/OkHttpConnectionFactory.java (module: fr.free.nrw.commons.OkHttpConnectionFactory.UnsuccessfulResponseInterceptor). The predicted root cause reason is that the interceptor logged expected/known unsuccessful API responses at ERROR level (using Timber.e) without a way to suppress or downgrade those logs, causing benign API failures (e.g. missingtitle/badinteger responses) to be reported as errors.

instruction: In apps-android-commons, there was a problem where the Nearby tab showed no nearby locations and the app displayed a toast with an SQL error. In some cases the app first showed a “Location not available” message and then, a few seconds later, an SQL error toast; briefly switching to the Contributions tab and back changed the behavior but the SQL error persisted and no locations appeared on the map. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/bookmarks/locations/BookmarkLocationsDao.java (Module: fr.free.nrw.commons.bookmarks.locations.BookmarkLocationsDao). The predicted root cause reason is faulty database migration logic in BookmarkLocationsDao.onUpdate: the update condition only handled a single specific version (from == 8) instead of a range (failing to apply intermediate migrations), causing schema/version mismatch and resulting SQL errors.

instruction: In apps-android-commons, when the app crashed the ACRA crash-report flow opened Gmail to compose a report but the composing email contained no crash information (the email body was empty and no useful logs were present), so users could not send useful crash reports. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to crash details not being included in the email.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/CommonsApplication.java (class fr.free.nrw.commons.CommonsApplication in module fr.free.nrw.commons). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect ACRA mail sender configuration: crash data was configured to be placed in the email body (reportAsFile=false / not sent as an attachment), which resulted in Gmail showing an empty message and no attached logs; the report was not being attached as a file.

instruction: In apps-android-commons, there was a CI build failure on Travis: the build stopped during an openssl decryption step used for the app keystore when running CI (for example, on a pull request), preventing the build from completing. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/build.gradle (Module: app.build.gradle). The predicted root cause reason is that CI-related signing/publishing configuration (and the Play plugin) was applied unconditionally so Travis attempted to decrypt and use the keystore on PR/forked builds where encrypted secrets or files (nr-commons.keystore / play.p12) are not available — a missing/incorrect CI conditional guard caused the openssl decryption to run and fail.

instruction: In this Android ownCloud client, users reported that after a recent update the background synchronization permanently fails with authentication errors. The device can log into the server via a browser and the same app works for other accounts/devices; re-entering the password in the app briefly appears to be accepted but sync immediately reports authentication failure again. This is a download-heavy sync from a server with many files. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is owncloudData/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/data/authentication/datasources/implementation/OCLocalAuthenticationDataSource.kt (module: com.owncloud.android.data.authentication.datasources.implementation.OCLocalAuthenticationDataSource). The predicted root cause reason is that the app did not refresh or persist updated credentials in the Android AccountManager (missing call to set the password/refresh stored credentials), so the sync service kept using stale credentials and produced permanent authentication failures.

instruction: In wolvic, there was a bug where opening a WebXR 360-degree link on a Meta Quest device caused the VR UI to respond in the opposite direction of head movement (e.g., looking left made the UI move right) after entering VR mode. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/gecko/assets/userAgentOverride.json (gecko/assets userAgentOverride.json). The predicted root cause reason is a missing/incorrect user-agent override for the affected site causing the server to deliver WebVR content instead of WebXR (UA mismatch), which led to inverted headset UI behavior.

instruction: In the jerboa app, there were random crashes (notably on Android 9) that frequently happened while scrolling through the feed after a recent update. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for these crashes: which file or module was responsible, and what went wrong to cause the runtime failures.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/proguard-rules.pro (missing keep rule for androidx.compose.ui.graphics.layer.view.ViewLayerContainer / module: androidx.compose.ui.graphics.layer.view.ViewLayerContainer). The predicted root cause reason is a missing ProGuard/R8 keep rule that allowed a required method (dispatchGetDisplayList) to be stripped/obfuscated, breaking Compose's ViewLayerContainer behavior on Android 9 and causing the crashes.

instruction: In the jerboa app, there was an issue where tapping a comment's “Read more replies”/“X more replies” did not show the replies, pressing it multiple times continued to do nothing, and once the list was scrolled the app crashed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/jerboa/Utils.kt (module: com.jerboa.UtilsKt). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect comment-tree construction/handling for missing parent comments: replies were being inserted in the wrong place (producing duplicate comment entries/IDs in the flat/tree), which resulted in duplicate keys for the LazyColumn and caused the crash.

instruction: In lawnchair, there was a crash on app launch with the latest nightly build — the app immediately fails when trying to start (observed on a Pixel 7 Pro running Android 16 beta). The crash happens during startup while the app is loading persisted or remote configuration data, causing launch to abort. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lawnchair/src/app/lawnchair/ui/preferences/data/liveinfo/model/LiveInformation.kt (module: app.lawnchair.ui.preferences.data.liveinfo.model.LiveInformation). The predicted root cause reason is that the LiveInformation data class had non-optional properties (no default values) required by kotlinx.serialization, so deserialization failed when incoming/cached data omitted those fields (missing defaults), causing the app to crash on startup.

instruction: In the Lawnchair repository/app, users reported that after using QuickSwitch to make Lawnchair the system recents on a Nothing Phone running NothingOS 2.6, the launcher becomes a system app but the Recents UI does not switch — the Nothing Launcher recents remain active and invoking recents via the bottom gesture from an app no longer works. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused recents to stop working on NothingOS 2.6. Your answer should name the specific file(s)/module(s) responsible and describe the underlying reason why the behavior failed.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is quickstep/src/com/android/launcher3/LauncherAnimationRunner.java (module: com.android.launcher3.LauncherAnimationRunner) and related quickstep/systemUI listener and callback classes: quickstep/src/com/android/quickstep/RecentsAnimationCallbacks.java (module: com.android.quickstep.RecentsAnimationCallbacks), quickstep/src/com/android/quickstep/SystemUiProxy.java (module: com.android.quickstep.SystemUiProxy), and systemUIShared/src/com/android/systemui/shared/system/RecentsAnimationListener.java (module: com.android.systemui.shared.system.RecentsAnimationListener). The predicted root cause reason is missing handling of the newer onAnimationStart variant that includes a SurfaceControl.Transaction/TransitionInfo (introduced in NothingOS 2.5.5/2.6) — the SurfaceControl.Transaction was not applied (no transaction.apply()), so the animation transaction chain was never continued, breaking the recents animation/hand-off.

instruction: In lawnchair, there was a crash when dragging an app (reported with Instagram) onto the home screen: starting the drag caused the launcher to crash. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/com/android/launcher3/Workspace.java (module: com.android.launcher3.Workspace). The predicted root cause reason is a missing null check on dragView.getContentViewParent(): code accessed getContentViewParent().getParent() when getContentViewParent() could be null, causing a NullPointerException during drag start.

instruction: In the Lawnchair app, opening the app drawer, long-pressing an icon to move it, and dragging the icon around sometimes causes the app to crash. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module is responsible for this behavior and what went wrong to cause the crash when moving an icon in the app drawer.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/com/android/launcher3/Workspace.java (com.android.launcher3.Workspace module). The predicted root cause reason is a missing null check when handling the drag view's content parent: code assumed dragView.getContentViewParent() was non-null (and directly accessed its parent) when mDragInfo.cell was a LauncherAppWidgetHostView, causing a null pointer access during drag operations.

instruction: In the BCR Android app, recordings saved during direct-boot (in /data/user_de/0/com.chiller3.bcr/files/in_progress) were not being migrated after boot: the DirectBootMigrationService logs reported 0 files to migrate even though playable .oga files existed, and manual moving to the completed folder produced further failures during migration. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that caused the migration to skip or fail.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/chiller3/bcr/output/CallMetadataCollector.kt (module: com.chiller3.bcr.output.CallMetadataCollector) and app/src/main/java/com/chiller3/bcr/rule/RecordRule.kt (module: com.chiller3.bcr.rule.RecordRule). The predicted root cause reason is unhandled exceptions thrown while querying contacts during direct-boot (e.g., ContentResolver/contact queries producing exceptions or SecurityException when contacts are not available), causing contact lookups to fail and the migration flow to abort; missing exception handling around contact queries.

instruction: In BCR, there was a bug where using a filename template that included {direction} and {sim_slot} produced output filenames that did not include those fields (although the corresponding .json metadata files did contain them). This happened when generating filenames on Android 13 with a template that attempted to include SIM slot even for single-SIM devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/chiller3/bcr/output/OutputFilenameGenerator.kt (module: com.chiller3.bcr.output.OutputFilenameGenerator). The predicted root cause reason is twofold: 1) a missing return when resolving the "direction" variable caused the direction value to never be emitted into the filename; and 2) sim_slot handling lacked support for the "always" argument (and its validation rejected the argument), so the generator only emitted sim_slot when multiple SIMs were active and could not be forced for single-SIM devices.

instruction: In the BCR app, users observed that the first ~7–8 seconds of some calls were not recorded — for example an 18 second call was saved as only 9 seconds. This happened when starting a call recording using the app's configured output (e.g. M4A/AAC). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this failure: which file/module in the project is responsible for the problem, and what went wrong to cause the initial seconds to be dropped.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/chiller3/bcr/FilenameTemplate.kt (Module: com.chiller3.bcr.FilenameTemplate). The predicted root cause reason is that a slow SAF/document query (calling DocumentFile.findFile / listing the output directory to check for a custom bcr.properties template) was performed synchronously at recording start, blocking startup for several seconds and causing the recorder to miss the initial audio (i.e., blocking I/O and not deferring custom-template processing).

instruction: In the BCR repository/app, there was a bug where call recordings produced by the app resulted in m4a/aac files that could not be played correctly (files appeared corrupted / missing expected header data) after a call. This happened while recording phone calls using the default output directory and formats on affected devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the corrupted output files: which file/module was changed to fix the problem, and what specifically went wrong in the code that caused the corrupt recordings.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/chiller3/bcr/RecorderThread.kt (module: com.chiller3.bcr.RecorderThread). The predicted root cause reason is that output files were opened without truncation (missing O_TRUNC / not truncating existing files), allowing leftover old data to remain at the end of newly written recordings and thereby corrupting the m4a/aac files.

instruction: In App, there was an Android build failure in CI that prevented assembling a release and blocked other Android work (including fixes for playback and icon loading). The failure occurred when running the Android build pipeline and caused compilation to fail. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is components/provider.tsx (path: components/provider.tsx, Module: components.provider). The predicted root cause reason is an unconditional import and use of a platform-specific native module on Android (react-native-carplay) — i.e., missing a platform guard/conditional require and null checks, which caused the Android build to include/compile incompatible code and fail.

instruction: In outline-apps, there was a client crash after establishing a VPN-style connection: a user adds a server, connects, and then opens a web page in their browser; the client process unexpectedly terminates and the tunnel is not removed, leaving the machine without internet access. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is go.mod / dependency github.com/Jigsaw-Code/outline-sdk/x (the project updated this module from v0.0.5 to v0.0.6). The predicted root cause reason is a concurrency bug in the SDK's websocket handling that allowed concurrent writes to the websocket connection (missing synchronization / write serialization), causing a panic.

instruction: In the logseq app, a query like (and [[tag]] (or "text" "othertext")) produced a Query Error and was treated as invalid, even though the equivalent expanded form works and (or "text" "othertext") by itself works fine. This only happens when an or clause with string literals is nested inside an and clause. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that produced this failure: which file/module contains the fault, and what exactly went wrong to cause the nested and/or query with string literals to be treated as invalid.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is src/main/frontend/db/query_dsl.cljs (module: db.query_dsl). The predicted root cause reason is a bug in the add-bindings! logic: incorrect parameter/usage (signature change/misuse) and special-case handling caused the query form to be wrapped/extra-bindinged incorrectly when an or containing string literals was nested inside an and, resulting in an invalid query (i.e., wrong binding/wrapping due to add-bindings! using the wrong form variable/or-detection).

instruction: In the logseq repository/app, there was a failure where Logseq would not start on a Raspberry Pi 4 running Ubuntu Server 22.04.1 (ARM64). The user installed Logseq from Flathub and attempted to run it (flatpak run com.logseq.Logseq), but the app failed to open instead of launching normally. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/build-desktop-release.yml (Module: github.workflows.build-desktop-release.yml). The predicted root cause reason is that the release build pipeline lacked Linux ARM64 packaging/artifact publishing (only x64 builds/artifact names were produced), so no compatible ARM64 binary was built/published (missing linux-arm64 build support in CI/release workflow).

instruction: In the OsmAnd app, users reported that routing and navigation initially work with the external BRouter service, but after a variable time (around 20–50 minutes) the app shows the error "BRouter service is not available" and routing fails mid-session. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is OsmAnd/src/net/osmand/plus/routing/RouteProvider.java (module: net.osmand.plus.routing.RouteProvider) and the related application class OsmAnd/src/net/osmand/plus/OsmandApplication.java (module: net.osmand.plus.OsmandApplication). The predicted root cause reason is that the app did not handle a killed/restarted BRouter service: when the IBRouterService reference was null the code returned an error instead of attempting to reconnect (missing reconnect/retry handling for the IPC service), so service restarts by the OS caused immediate routing failures.

instruction: In OsmAnd, there was a crash when attempting to download tiles for a raster map. Reproduction: add a raster map source with limited zoom levels (for example min=8, max=16), set map storage to SQLiteDB, select this map source and use the download action (long tap > actions > download map). Instead of showing the download dialog, the app crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is OsmAnd/src/net/osmand/plus/resources/SQLiteTileSource.java (module: net.osmand.plus.resources.SQLiteTileSource). The predicted root cause reason is that the tile source's database was not initialized/opened before reading metadata (so the default maxZoom remained incorrect/out-of-range); missing initialization of the SQLiteTileSource (causing an invalid default maxZoom that violated slider bounds) which led to the crash.

instruction: In the OsmAnd app, there was a crash when attempting to open the track/menu popup. This occurred after navigating to Menu > My Places > Import (or selecting a non-Visible folder) and tapping the three-dot (more) button to open the popup menu — instead of the menu appearing, the app crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is OsmAnd/src/net/osmand/plus/widgets/popup/PopUpMenuDisplayData.java (net.osmand.plus.widgets.popup.PopUpMenuDisplayData). The predicted root cause reason is that a default layoutId was lost during refactoring (layoutId left uninitialized/zero), causing an invalid layout resource id and a crash when the popup menu tried to inflate or display (missing default layoutId initialization).

instruction: In the OsmAnd app, users reported incorrect screens in the OsmAnd Cloud flow: after logging into OsmAnd Cloud and then choosing Settings -> Log out, the Cloud menu reappears and an error like "Failed to fetch the file list from the server" is shown. Also, when selecting "Choose what to sync" the app navigates to the general Settings menu instead of opening the Backup/Storage selection UI, leaving users confused about how to pick data to back up. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this incorrect navigation/screen behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is OsmAnd/src/net/osmand/plus/backup/ui/BackupSettingsFragment.java (module: net.osmand.plus.backup.ui.BackupSettingsFragment) and OsmAnd/src/net/osmand/plus/activities/MapActivity.java (module: net.osmand.plus.activities.MapActivity). The predicted root cause reason is improper backstack/navigation handling on logout: logout used a generic onBackPressed() rather than explicitly dismissing the backup/cloud fragment and presenting the authorization screen, leaving the BackupCloudFragment visible (or in an inconsistent state) which then tried to fetch files after logout (missing explicit fragment dismissal / incorrect navigation flow).

instruction: In termux-app, there was a bug where termux-open and termux-share stopped being able to exchange files with other applications after a minor Android 8.1 security upgrade; attempts to share files fail with errors such as "Error copying <filename>" or "File could not be scheduled for upload". Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/termux/app/TermuxOpenReceiver.java (module: com.termux.app.TermuxOpenReceiver). The predicted root cause reason is improper construction of the content:// URI used for sharing files — the code built the URI in a way that encoded or mangled the file path (incorrect use of Uri.withAppendedPath / wrong path string), producing an invalid content URI so other apps could not access the file.

instruction: In the quran_android app, the UI sometimes showed that playback was playing (and logs repeatedly reported the same ayah being highlighted many times per second), but in reality the audio playback was stopped. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the UI and logs reporting a playing state while playback was actually stopped.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/.../playback/PlaybackController.kt (module: playback / PlaybackController or the playback service component that manages playback state and the progress/highlight updater). The predicted root cause reason is that the playback "isPlaying" state or progress/highlight updater was not updated/cancelled when playback stopped (missing synchronization / missing state update or missing cancellation of the Runnable/handler), causing the UI/logs to continue reporting playing and repeatedly re-highlighting the same ayah.

instruction: In the woocommerce-android app, users observed a crash when viewing the dashboard charts: an IllegalArgumentException complaining that a date string was not of the expected week-format (e.g. a value like "2018-09-24" being treated as a week string). The crash happened while switching the chart granularity (for example between Months and Days) and appears to be timing-related — the wrong date-formatted string is being passed to the date formatting helpers briefly during the switch. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is WooCommerce/src/main/kotlin/com/woocommerce/android/ui/dashboard/DashboardStatsView.kt (module: com.woocommerce.android.ui.dashboard.DashboardStatsView). The predicted root cause reason is that chart state/data (and its axis formatter state) was not cleared when initiating a new stats request, causing stale/incorrect date-format strings to be used by the axis formatter during quick granularity switches (a timing-related stale-state bug leading to an invalid date format being passed to the DateUtils).

instruction: In woocommerce-android, there was a fatal crash reported to Crashlytics: the app threw an IllegalStateException ("Can not perform this action after onSaveInstanceState") while attempting to clear a fragment back stack during activity/fragment lifecycle transitions, which caused the app to crash for a user. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is WooCommerce/src/main/kotlin/com/woocommerce/android/ui/main/MainActivity.kt (MainActivity in module com.woocommerce.android.ui.main). The predicted root cause reason is that code attempted to modify the FragmentManager (pop the child fragment back stack) after the FragmentManager/Activity state had been saved (onSaveInstanceState), i.e., missing a state check (isStateSaved) before calling popBackStackImmediate which led to an IllegalStateException.

instruction: In woocommerce-android, there was a crash reported when returning to the login screen after selecting an email credential/hint: the app threw a RuntimeException while delivering an activity result to the login flow and the login screen crashed for the user. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is libs/login/WordPressLoginFlow/src/main/java/org/wordpress/android/login/LoginEmailFragment.java (module: org.wordpress.android.login.LoginEmailFragment). The predicted root cause reason is a NullPointerException caused by accessing the email input view (mEmailInput) inside onActivityResult before the fragment's view was created (activity result arriving before onCreateView) — i.e., missing a null check/guard for mEmailInput.

instruction: In pocket-casts-android, there was an issue where, with an audio episode playing and the fullscreen (expanded) player open, rotating the device to landscape caused the playback controls (play/pause, scrub, and other player controls) to disappear while the artwork remained visible; rotating back to portrait or lowering the player restores the controls. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is modules/features/player/src/main/java/au/com/shiftyjelly/pocketcasts/player/view/nowplaying/ArtworkSection.kt (module: au.com.shiftyjelly.pocketcasts.player.view.nowplaying.ArtworkSection). The predicted root cause reason is incorrect determination of the WindowHeightSizeClass / orientation in the ArtworkSection composable (missing orientation-aware sizing and tolerance for near-compact landscape heights), causing landscape phones to be treated as non-compact height and the player controls to be hidden.

instruction: In pocket-casts-android, there was an issue where the playback progress thumb (the dot on the Now Playing seek bar) appears at the start after pausing an episode and restarting the app, even though the numeric time labels below the bar show the correct paused position. This occurs after seeking to a point in the episode, pausing, closing the app, and reopening the player. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is modules/features/player/src/main/java/au/com/shiftyjelly/pocketcasts/player/view/nowplaying/PlayerSeekBar.kt (Module: au.com.shiftyjelly.pocketcasts.player.view.nowplaying.PlayerSeekBar). The predicted root cause reason is an ordering bug where the playback position was applied to the seek bar before the duration was set (state applied before duration initialization), causing the visual thumb to render at zero despite the correct time values.

instruction: In the pocket-casts-android app, users reported that the app crashes every time they open the page for a specific podcast (The Economist). The crash happens while the app is observing or loading the podcast's episodes (it occurs shortly after opening the podcast page and persists despite unsubscribing and deleting episodes). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/com/pocketcasts/data/repository/EpisodesRepository.java (Module: app). The predicted root cause reason is an attempt to read a very large episode column (e.g., long show notes/transcript) into a Cursor that exceeds the CursorWindow capacity, causing an IllegalStateException; the code did not exclude/handle the oversized column or perform defensive/null/size checks before accessing the Cursor.

instruction: In BlueWallet, there was a visual bug in the Manage Wallets screen: when a user long-presses a wallet to open the Manage Wallets view and then swipes any wallet to the left, the red delete action area shows a Chinese/Japanese character instead of the expected delete icon. This happens on Android devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to the wrong character being displayed in place of the delete icon.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is components/ManageWalletsListItem.tsx (module: components.ManageWalletsListItem). The predicted root cause reason is a platform-specific icon name/compatibility issue: the code used an icon name that is not available or mapped correctly on Android (resulting in a font/glyph fallback to a CJK character) instead of selecting an Android-compatible icon name.

instruction: In ChameleonUltraGUI, there was a crash when recovering more than about 60 nonces from the Slot manager. While using Slot manager → select slot → Edit → Recover Keys → Recover Keys from >60 nonces, the ChameleonUltra goes to sleep and the collected nonces disappear, causing the operation to fail. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is chameleonultragui/lib/helpers/github.dart (module: chameleonultragui.lib.helpers.github). The predicted root cause reason is an incorrect artifact/version selection check (missing repository id filter) that allowed the app to pick the wrong CI artifact (e.g., from a fork or different repo), resulting in an invalid/ incompatible firmware/artifact being used and causing the crash when processing the recovered nonces.

instruction: In amnezia-client, there was an issue where the XRay VPN protocol on Linux would connect successfully but users could not access any websites; the problem often persisted after disconnecting and only switching to a different protocol restored normal access. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is client/ui/controllers/sitesController.cpp (module: client.ui.controllers.SitesController). The predicted root cause reason is unnecessary calls to flushDns() (DNS flush invoked when not required), which disrupted DNS resolution on Linux — flushDns should only be called after actual DNS settings changes.

instruction: In the Thunderbird for Android repository, subfolders in the folder drawer were displayed as a single dotted name like "Folder.Subfolder" instead of being shown as nested entries when opening the folder drawer. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is feature/navigation/drawer/dropdown/src/main/kotlin/net/thunderbird/feature/navigation/drawer/dropdown/domain/usecase/GetDisplayTreeFolder.kt (Module: net.thunderbird.feature.navigation.drawer.dropdown.domain.usecase.GetDisplayTreeFolder). The predicted root cause reason is that the drawer's folder-tree creation ignored the account-specific folder path delimiter (i.e., did not use the server-provided FolderPathDelimiter), so folder names containing the delimiter were treated as single flat names (e.g., "Parent.Child") instead of being split into nested nodes.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, the app crashed when a user navigated from Settings → Accounts → (an account) → General settings: opening the General Settings screen caused the application to terminate instead of showing the account-specific general preferences. This happened immediately after selecting an account's General settings. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is legacy/storage/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/preferences/migration/StorageMigrations.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.preferences.migration.StorageMigrations) and the related migration implementation file legacy/storage/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/preferences/migration/StorageMigrationTo27.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.preferences.migration.StorageMigrationTo27). The predicted root cause reason is a missing storage migration / missing migration registration to prepopulate new avatar fields (avatar monogram), causing absent or uninitialized avatar data when the General Settings UI accessed it and resulting in a crash.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, users reported that tapping “show accounts” in the sidebar causes the app to crash instead of showing the account menu. This happens when navigating to the account list from the sidebar. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash: which file or module in the repository is responsible, and what exactly went wrong to produce the failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is legacy/storage/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/preferences/migration/StorageMigrationTo26.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.preferences.migration) and the related preferences storage component legacy/storage/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/preferences/K9StoragePersister.java (module: com.fsck.k9.preferences). The predicted root cause reason is that stored identities contained invalid or syntactically invalid email values (no validation/migration for bad email data), causing code that expects valid email addresses to crash; the fix adds a migration to sanitize identity emails (and increments the storage DB version so the migration runs) and adds validation to prevent future invalid addresses.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a UI/UX bug encountered when using Search in the Inbox. After entering a query and confirming, matching emails were shown but a search icon remained visible next to the search results; tapping that icon then showed a "Sending query to server" message and only afterwards did the icon disappear. The expected behavior was that the keyboard closes and the search icon is not shown after results. Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file or module was responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that produced this misleading/incorrect icon behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is legacy/ui/legacy/src/main/res/menu/message_list_option_menu.xml (module: legacy/ui/legacy). The predicted root cause reason is that the menu item referenced the wrong drawable resource (used the generic local-search icon) — there was no distinct icon/resource for server-side (remote) search, causing a misleading UI; i.e., an incorrect drawable resource reference for the remote-search action.  (Also acceptable: noting the added drawable file legacy/ui/legacy/src/main/res/drawable/ic_search_remote.xml as part of the fix.)

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a UI problem where the unread message count shown on the inbox (navigation drawer) button did not clear after the only unread message was read. This happened when viewing the inbox/unified inbox in the app and the unread badge remained non-zero instead of updating to 0. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is feature/navigation/drawer/src/main/kotlin/app/k9mail/feature/navigation/drawer/data/UnifiedFolderRepository.kt (module: app.k9mail.feature.navigation.drawer.data.UnifiedFolderRepository) and related DI wiring in feature/navigation/drawer/src/main/kotlin/app/k9mail/feature/navigation/drawer/NavigationDrawerModule.kt (module: app.k9mail.feature.navigation.drawer.NavigationDrawerModule). The predicted root cause reason is that the navigation drawer did not have a repository/flow providing reactive message counts for the unified inbox (missing UnifiedFolderRepository and DI binding), so the unread count for the unified/inbox folder was not being observed/updated (i.e., missing subscription/flow for unified folder message counts leading to stale unread count).

instruction: In the thunderbird-android repository/app, deleting a message from the Inbox and moving it to Trash no longer removes the original from the server: a copy appears in Deleted Items but the original in Inbox is only marked deleted (so it still counts towards Inbox totals on the server). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mail/protocols/imap/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/mail/store/imap/RealImapFolder.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.mail.store.imap.RealImapFolder). The predicted root cause reason is that the code stopped issuing an EXPUNGE after moving a message — a refactor introduced a change to expunge behavior (introduction of an isExpungeImmediately config flag) and the logic no longer triggers an immediate EXPUNGE, so messages are only flagged DELETED instead of being expunged (missing/changed expunge call).

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was an issue where during account setup (or when adding a new account from Settings) typing a lowercase email local-part followed by a dot caused the first letter to become capitalized (for example, typing "josh." displayed as "Josh."). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is core/ui/compose/designsystem/src/main/kotlin/app/k9mail/core/ui/compose/designsystem/atom/textfield/TextFieldOutlinedEmailAddress.kt (Module: app.k9mail.core.ui.compose.designsystem.atom.textfield.TextFieldOutlinedEmailAddress). The predicted root cause reason is that the email address text field allowed keyboard auto-correction/autocapitalization (missing disabling of autoCorrect in the KeyboardOptions), causing the input to be auto-capitalized.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was an app crash that occurred while composing or replying to a message whenever the user began typing in the recipient field (autofill/recipient lookup). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash — indicate the specific file or module where the fix was applied and the underlying reason why the crash occurred.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/ui/legacy/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/activity/compose/RecipientLoader.java (Module: com.fsck.k9.activity.compose). The predicted root cause reason is an unhandled exception thrown when querying the crypto/contact provider (the code only caught SecurityException, so other exceptions bubbled up and caused a crash; missing broader exception handling).

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a problem when adding an IMAP account that uses a self-signed certificate: instead of a dialog asking the user to accept the certificate, the app reported a "Network error" (Read timed out) and the IMAP server showed the TLS handshake was closed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mail/protocols/imap/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/mail/store/imap/RealImapStore.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.mail.store.imap.RealImapStore). The predicted root cause reason is that TLS/SSL certificate/handshake exceptions were being caught and masked/converted (wrapped) by the checkSettings() implementation (caught as a generic/IO exception and turned into a MessagingException), so the original certificate validation/SSLHandshake error did not propagate to the caller/UI and therefore no "accept self-signed certificate" prompt was shown.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a bug where deleting a message did not make it show up immediately in the Trash folder — the message only appeared after manually refreshing the folder. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mail/protocols/imap/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/mail/store/imap/RealImapFolder.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.mail.store.imap.RealImapFolder) and mail/protocols/imap/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/mail/store/imap/UidCopyResponse.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.mail.store.imap.UidCopyResponse). The predicted root cause reason is that the IMAP COPYUID response parser did not handle untagged COPYUID responses (missing/disabled support for untagged responses), so no UID mapping was produced when the server returned an untagged COPYUID and the client therefore did not update the moved/deleted message list immediately.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a crash during first-launch account setup: when the user typed an email address containing an ampersand (e.g. you&me@email.org) the app crashed instead of advancing to the next screen. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is feature/account/setup/src/main/kotlin/app/k9mail/feature/account/setup/domain/usecase/ValidateEmailAddress.kt (module: app.k9mail.feature.account.setup.domain.usecase.ValidateEmailAddress). The predicted root cause reason is an uncaught/insufficient email parsing/validation issue — an EmailAddressParserException (caused by the invalid '&' in the local part) was not handled/validated early, allowing invalid input to propagate and crash the setup flow.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, notifications on a paired Wear OS 4 watch appeared silently when an email was received (the phone vibrated and rang as expected, but the watch showed the notification silently). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/core/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/notification/SingleMessageNotificationCreator.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.notification.SingleMessageNotificationCreator) and app/core/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/notification/SummaryNotificationCreator.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.notification.SummaryNotificationCreator). The predicted root cause reason is that GroupAlertBehavior was not explicitly set for single and summary notifications, causing Wear OS to treat the grouped notifications as silent (missing group alert behavior setting).

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a bug where new-mail notifications dismissed from the Android notification bar reappear shortly afterward (users swipe or clear the notification and it returns after a second or two, sometimes only disappearing after a second dismissal and occasionally popping up again later). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/core/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/notification/NotificationRepository.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.notification.NotificationRepository). The predicted root cause reason is that account notification state was not properly initialized/restored before modifications (restoreNotifications returned early / failed to initialize the in-memory NotificationData for accounts with no active notifications), allowing later operations to re-load/recreate notifications (i.e., missing initialization of notification state leading to re-creation of dismissed notifications).

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was an issue where folders renamed or removed on the mail server (for example in Gmail) were not removed from the app after performing a 'Refresh folder list' — the newly named folder might appear but the old/stale folder entry remained visible in the app. This happened when the user expected the refresh to both add new folders and remove folders that no longer exist on the server. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/core/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/mailstore/FolderRepository.kt (module: com.fsck.k9.mailstore.FolderRepository). The predicted root cause reason is that FolderRepository was not observing folder settings changes from the message store (missing registration of a FolderSettingsChangedListener / not listening for folder setting change events), so server-side folder rename/delete events did not trigger an update of the displayed folder list and stale folders remained.

instruction: In thunderbird-android, there was a crash/hang observed when a user drags an account entry downward on the accounts screen (during testing of a related fix). The UI interaction never completes and the app effectively crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/ui/legacy/src/main/java/com/fsck/k9/ui/K9Drawer.kt (class com.fsck.k9.ui.K9Drawer). The predicted root cause reason is updating the SwipeRefreshLayout's isRefreshing state from a non-UI/background thread (missing invocation on the main/UI thread), causing the crash/hang.

instruction: In thunderbird-android (K-9 Mail), there was a failure where mail stopped being delivered: the user reported no new incoming messages for days and outgoing messages were failing with a notification that some messages could not be sent due to an address resolution / permission/network error. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (module: io.ktor:ktor-client-core, alias: ktor / dependency version entry 'ktor' in gradle.libs.versions). The predicted root cause reason is a bug/regression in the third‑party Ktor client dependency (version 3.3.0) causing DNS/address-resolution failures (permission-related android_getaddrinfo EPERM) — fixed by bumping the Ktor dependency to 3.3.1.

instruction: In the NewPipe repository, F‑Droid builds were failing / F‑Droid reported it "can't build" the app (users observed that the F‑Droid rebuilds did not produce the expected APKs and reproducibility verification failed). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused F‑Droid to be unable to build or reproduce the release APK correctly. Your answer should say which file/module is responsible and why the problem happened (what went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/build-release-apk.yml (the repository's CI/build pipeline configuration for producing unsigned release APKs). The predicted root cause reason is a missing CI workflow to produce a reproducible/unsigned release APK for the master branch (i.e., absence of an automated build artifact meant F‑Droid/collaborators could not reproduce or verify the release build), causing the F‑Droid build/reproducibility process to fail.

instruction: In pslab-app, the app crashes when it is run for the first time after installation while a PSLab device is already connected to the phone. This happens during app startup while the app is handling the connected USB device and requesting any necessary permissions. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) and the root cause reason that lead to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/pslab/activity/MainActivity.java (module: io.pslab.activity.MainActivity). The predicted root cause reason is creating a PendingIntent for USB permission without specifying the required mutability flag (missing FLAG_IMMUTABLE/FLAG_MUTABLE), causing an IllegalArgumentException and app crash during the USB permission handling on first launch.

instruction: In pslab-app, there was a layout problem observed during a recent F‑Droid build: the APSD9960 sensor screen produced a build/lint warning about a duplicated UI identifier in its screen layout which prevented a clean build. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason — point to the specific file/module that needed fixing and explain what went wrong that produced the duplicate-id warning.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/res/layout/sensor_apds9960.xml (module: app, layout resource). The predicted root cause reason is a duplicate view ID declaration in the layout XML (the same @+id was defined more than once, causing a Lint DuplicateIds/build warning).

instruction: In pslab-app, the app crashes on older, memory-constrained devices when a user follows a specific sequence on the Oscilloscope/Pin Layout screens (changing device orientation, enabling the in-built mic, navigating back, then toggling Pin Layout Front/Back repeatedly without long pauses). The crash reliably happens after those UI and orientation transitions. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/pslab/fragment/PSLabPinLayoutFragment.java (module: io.pslab.fragment.PSLabPinLayoutFragment).
