The predicted root cause reason is that large image drawables were not released during the Fragment lifecycle (an ImageView was kept/assigned in a way that prevented dereferencing on pause), causing memory to accumulate and trigger an OutOfMemoryError on low-memory devices.

instruction: In the openhab-android app, opening an interactive chart from a sitemap and tapping it caused the app to crash whenever the chart's period was set to anything other than the default daily period (for example, period=8h). This happened on user devices when viewing a chart and tapping to open the interactive chart activity. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/ui/ChartWidgetActivity.kt (module: org.openhab.habdroid.ui). The predicted root cause reason is that the TemporalAmount period property was declared as lateinit and could be accessed before being initialized (state accessed before initialization / UninitializedPropertyAccessException); missing a safe default initialization or null-check caused the crash.

instruction: In openhab-android, users reported the app frequently crashing after an upgrade whenever any options were enabled on the "Send device information to server" page. The crash occurs when the app starts its background work to send device info, and the runtime error mentions a foregroundServiceType not being a subset of the manifest's foregroundServiceType attribute. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason: which file/module is responsible for the problem and what went wrong to cause this foreground service type mismatch and resulting crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/background/ItemUpdateWorker.kt (org.openhab.habdroid.background.ItemUpdateWorker). The predicted root cause reason is that the worker used an incorrect foreground service type constant when creating the foreground notification (a foregroundServiceType that did not match the service's foregroundServiceType declared in the AndroidManifest), causing an IllegalArgumentException due to the mismatch.

instruction: In the openhab-android app, icons began appearing in the wrong place in some widgets after a recent update: icons in section switches were visually misplaced until the view was scrolled or reloaded, and in at least one case an icon displayed an incorrect background. The problem could sometimes be reproduced by loading a view with many widgets and was not fixed by clearing the app cache. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these icon placement/visibility problems.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/ui/widget/WidgetImageView.kt (module: org.openhab.habdroid.ui.widget.WidgetImageView) and related changes in mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/ui/WidgetAdapter.kt (module: org.openhab.habdroid.ui.WidgetAdapter). The predicted root cause reason is that the automatic addition of a SkeletonLayout replaced/changed the original ImageView view hierarchy/ID and thus broke ConstraintLayout constraints (causing misplaced icons), and visibility was being manipulated in two places (WidgetAdapter and SkeletonLayout) so skeleton and image could be shown at the same time (missing/incorrect handling of view hierarchy/IDs and visibility management).

instruction: In openhab-android, the map widget for a Location item showed only a global earth view when first opening a site and only displayed the correct location after performing a manual refresh. This happened when viewing a site containing a Location item (opening the site shows the whole earth; refreshing or navigating back and in again shows the correct marker/zoom). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/full/java/org/openhab/habdroid/ui/MapViewHelper.kt (module: org.openhab.habdroid.ui.MapViewHelper). The predicted root cause reason is that the initial widget bind ran before the GoogleMap was initialized (map was null) so the map update was skipped; in other words, missing deferral/handling of the asynchronous getMapAsync caused the first bind attempt to be discarded (map operations were no-ops), leading to the location appearing only after a refresh.

instruction: In openhab-android, there was a UI bug where the app's left navigation drawer always showed only a single sitemap (the one currently used). When users added new sitemaps on the server they did not appear in the drawer; if the existing sitemap was deleted the app would prompt once to choose a sitemap but afterwards would not allow switching to other sitemaps. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this behavior.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/repository/SitemapRepository.kt (module: :mobile). The predicted root cause reason is that the code used the wrong data source / filtering when loading sitemaps (it requested or filtered for the currently selected sitemap instead of fetching the full list, effectively calling the single-sitemap endpoint/logic or applying a selection filter and caching it), so only the active sitemap was presented in the drawer.

instruction: In the openhab-android repository/app, there was a problem where the Log screen's share button did not open the Android share dialog on a Samsung Galaxy S21 Ultra running Android 11 — instead, tapping Share just reloaded the log view. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this sharing failure (which file/module was changed to fix it, and what was wrong that caused the observed behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/build.gradle (Module: mobile). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated test dependency: mockito-core was pinned at 4.2.0 which exhibited a bug/incompatibility; bumping mockito-core to 4.3.0 resolved the incorrect behavior (i.e., a dependency-induced issue that prevented the share flow from functioning as expected).

instruction: In openhab-android, there was inconsistent behavior sending device alarms to the server on some devices (notably Samsung): alarms were sometimes sent with wrong times (e.g. timestamps in the past or shifted), removals sometimes produced no update, and only some alarm updates (like alarms later the same day) worked reliably. This happened while setting, updating or removing alarms in the clock/calendar. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to these incorrect or missing alarm updates being sent to the server.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/background/BackgroundTasksManager.kt (org.openhab.habdroid.background.BackgroundTasksManager). The predicted root cause reason is a missing exclusion for Samsung's calendar package (com.samsung.android.calendar) in the list of ignored packages for alarm broadcasts, causing calendar events from that package to be processed as alarms and resulting in incorrect or missing alarm updates being sent to the server.

instruction: In the openhab-android app, the Android Beta app on a Samsung S21 Ultra did not receive broadcast notifications sent from the server via sendBroadcastNotification, while the same notifications were received correctly on another phone (OnePlus 7T Pro). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that explains this failure: name the file/module that was changed to address the problem and explain what went wrong.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/build.gradle (module: mobile). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated test dependency version: mockito-core was upgraded from 4.3.1 to 4.4.0 (i.e., a dependency version bump was applied).

instruction: In openhab-android, there was a bug where tapping the "SSL-Client Certificate" option in the server settings did not open the file explorer (the import flow did not start) on multiple Android 11 devices. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason. In particular, state which file/module was changed to fix this and explain what went wrong (the underlying cause of the failure).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/build.gradle (Module: mobile). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated test dependency (org.mockito:mockito-core was pinned to 4.2.0) causing a dependency/classpath conflict that affected the import/file-chooser flow; bumping mockito-core to 4.3.0 resolved the issue.

instruction: In openhab-android, there was a crash when using the voice command from the home-screen widget: the voice command is sent to the openHAB server but the Android app crashes every time when invoked from the widget (it does not crash when voice is launched from inside the app). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is mobile/src/main/java/org/openhab/habdroid/core/OpenHABVoiceService.java (org.openhab.habdroid.core.OpenHABVoiceService). The predicted root cause reason is an unhandled/unsupported message handling path in the voice service that caused a thrown IllegalArgumentException / crash (the service attempted to handle a message type that isn’t appropriate in the widget/home-screen context — e.g., snackbar usage with no parent view — and there was no fallback to showing a toast).

instruction: In openhab-android, there was a problem where the HABDroid app could not reliably display chart images defined in a sitemap: three chart items for a group often appeared blank (occasionally one would load) and the client repeatedly re-requested the same chart URLs from the server. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is .github/workflows/build.yml (the Gradle wrapper validation GitHub Action usage: gradle/wrapper-validation-action@v1.0.3). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated GitHub Action version for Gradle wrapper validation (gradle/wrapper-validation-action was on v1.0.3), which required bumping to v1.0.4 to address the underlying build/validation issue.

instruction: In flutter_server_box, there was a bug where opening the system status view on an Ubuntu host displayed a large list of loop devices (loop0, loop1, ...) that should not be shown. This happened when /proc/diskstats contained many loop device entries. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/data/model/server/server_status_update_req.dart (module: server_box.data.model.server.server_status_update_req). The predicted root cause reason is improper hostname parsing: the parser returned raw strings (including whitespace/newline or empty-only values) without trimming or converting them to null, causing downstream status parsing/display logic to misinterpret data and include loop devices in the system status.

instruction: In the cloudstream app, when users tapped the download arrow to save a stream the resulting file only contained the video track — audio and any embedded subtitles were missing. This happened across multiple providers, videos, and Android versions. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to downloads producing video‑only files (i.e., which file/module was responsible and what went wrong in its logic).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is library/src/commonMain/kotlin/com/lagradost/cloudstream3/utils/M3u8Helper.kt (module: com.lagradost.cloudstream3.utils.M3u8Helper2). Also relevant is the downloader call site app/src/main/java/com/lagradost/cloudstream3/utils/VideoDownloadManager.kt which did not request audio. The predicted root cause reason is incorrect/insufficient HLS (M3U8) parsing and selection logic: the parser/selector returned or selected video‑only variants (omitting audio and embedded subtitles) and the downloader did not request/require audio (missing selection flag), causing downloads to produce video‑only files.

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a failure while patching an APK (SD Maid SE) — the patch operation aborted with an error about the attribute "android:defaultLocale" not being found. This happened when applying tweaks (e.g., "Enable predictive back gesture" and "Change package name") and occurred during the APK resource rebuild/packaging step. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is patcher/src/main/assets/aapt2 (the bundled aapt2 binary in the patcher module). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/unsupported aapt2 binary (resource compiler) that does not recognize the newer android:defaultLocale attribute, causing resource compilation to fail.

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a regression where after updating to v1.24.0 (and later) the app no longer launches and instead crashes immediately on startup. Users reported the last working version was 1.23.3 and the app crashes without producing usable logs. Your task is to identify the root cause component (file/module) that was changed to fix this startup crash and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that caused the crash.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml (Module: android.app.src.main.AndroidManifest). The predicted root cause reason is that the Flutter Impeller GPU renderer was enabled and triggered a null pointer dereference / GPU renderer crash on certain devices/drivers; disabling Impeller via AndroidManifest meta-data prevents the crash.

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was an intermittent bug where, when the "Save patched app" setting was enabled, attempting to install a patched app would sometimes be immediately cancelled and the "Export APK" button would stop working. The problem tends to appear when you patch the same app multiple times in a row (e.g., patch, install, then patch again without closing the app). Your task is to identify the root cause component (which file/module contains the bug) and the root cause reason (what specifically went wrong that produced this behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/services/manager_api.dart (lib.services.manager_api.ManagerAPI). The predicted root cause reason is a race condition where the previously patched APK was deleted prematurely because deleteLastPatchedApp() was invoked/asynchronously executed without being awaited (missing await / premature file deletion), causing the installer/exporter to find the file missing and cancel the operation.

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a UI bug in the patch options screen: when a patch exposes two or more text options, changing the value of one or more (but not all) text fields and then tapping elsewhere on the screen causes option widgets to move positions and for values to appear to be copied/moved into other widgets. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/revanced/manager/ui/patch/PatchOptionsScreen.kt (module :app). The predicted root cause reason is missing/incorrect item keys or improper state/scoping for list items in the Compose UI (state attached to list index or reused across items), causing Compose to reuse/misassociate text field state when the list recomposes (i.e., missing unique keys for LazyColumn/items or improper state hoisting).

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a bug where typing into a patch option textbox (for example the Spoof client patch) caused the text cursor to jump to the end of the string after each character is entered or deleted. A user could move the cursor to the middle or start of the text, but as soon as they typed or backspaced the cursor would move to the end and further edits would always append. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/revanced/manager/ui/patch/options/OptionsTextField.kt (the patch options TextField UI component in the app module). The predicted root cause reason is that the TextField was driven by a plain String state (or otherwise not preserving TextField selection) so text selection/cursor position was lost on each update/recomposition — i.e., missing use of TextFieldValue or preservation of selection, causing the cursor to jump to the end.

instruction: In the revanced-manager app, there was an App list display error: when a source is first loaded (for example immediately after installing the app and following the workflow to open the app, download files, go to Patcher and select an app), the installed app icon, the number of patch options and the Suggested Version are not displayed correctly in the app list. The patch itself loads correctly and the missing UI elements reappear after leaving the screen and returning. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this incorrect display behavior (which part of the code was responsible and what went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/me/revanced/manager/ui/patcher/PatcherScreen.kt (the Patcher screen / app list composable in the app module). The predicted root cause reason is that the UI used cached local state on initial composition (e.g., values created with remember/mutableStateOf) instead of observing the ViewModel/Flow state (missing collectAsState/observer or incorrect LaunchedEffect key), so the app item fields remained stale when the source/patch metadata updated and the list did not recompose until navigation forced a refresh.

instruction: In revanced-manager, users reported that the app crashes when a patching operation is canceled — specifically, double-pressing the back button while patching causes the manager to crash. This occurs during normal use of the patcher flow: start patching, press back to cancel, then press back again and the app crashes. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is android/src/main/kotlin/app/revanced/manager/patcher/Patcher.kt (or the patcher-related Android plugin/handler in the app module). The predicted root cause reason is that a reply/result is submitted more than once (missing guard/duplicate reply) which causes an IllegalStateException ("Reply already submitted") when cancelling the patching flow.

instruction: In revanced-manager, when changing the app language from the Settings tab the language selector widget updates but most other strings on the Settings tab remain in the previous language until you manually switch to another main tab (Patcher or Dashboard) and come back. This happens after selecting a new language and confirming the dialog. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that caused the Settings tab to not update its displayed strings immediately after changing the language.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is lib/ui/views/settings/settingsFragment/settings_update_language.dart (module: revanced_manager.ui.views.settings.settingsFragment.SUpdateLanguage). The predicted root cause reason is that updating the locale did not trigger an immediate rebuild/refresh of the Settings view (the UI state was not refreshed after changing language), so the old strings remained — i.e., the locale change was applied but the view wasn't navigated/refreshed (missing action to force the UI to update) which caused the delayed language update.

instruction: In revanced-manager, the app crashed immediately on startup (the process failed while the app was being bound/initialized). This happened right after launching the application — users reported the app would not start and would terminate early during the application binding/initialization phase. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/AndroidManifest.xml (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is a manifest reference to Flutter runtime classes (an application/activity class from the Flutter embedding) that no longer exist after the migration to Jetpack Compose, causing a ClassNotFoundError/NoClassDefFoundError during app initialization.

instruction: In revanced-manager, opening the app caused it to get stuck on the startup screen and never finish loading the list of patches (the app appears to hang while 'loading patches'). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this startup hang — name the specific file or module that was changed to fix the problem and explain what went wrong (the underlying bug or faulty behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is pubspec.yaml and pubspec.lock (root-level dependency manifest files: pubspec.yaml, pubspec.lock). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/buggy dependency (notably connectivity_plus and related pub packages) causing a blocking or erroneous connectivity/startup check on app launch — a dependency bug/compatibility issue that blocked the startup flow (i.e., a dependency-induced hang during patch loading).

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a bug where the Manager app unexpectedly aborts while patching YouTube Music: the process consistently crashes right after reaching the "Compiling resources" step, causing the patching run to terminate. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that led to this failure.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (the kotlin-process dependency/version used by the app, i.e. the kotlin-process module referenced in the libs versions). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/buggy kotlin-process library causing external process execution (resource compilation / aapt2 invocation) to fail or hang, leading the Manager to abort; fixed by bumping the kotlin-process version from 1.4.1 to 1.5.1.

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a bug where the Manager would show “no application” when trying to select a target app (for example YouTube) — installed applications were not being detected/available to choose from. This happened while interacting with the app selection UI (during app loading/selection, including universal APK scenarios). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is package.json (path: package.json, module: package) and package-lock.json (path: package-lock.json, module: package_lock). The predicted root cause reason is an outdated/incorrect dev dependency configuration (semantic-release / semantic-release-pub version mismatch) in the project's package configuration causing build/release tooling to produce incorrect/missing artifacts (packaging step failure) which ultimately led to the Manager failing to load/detect applications (i.e., a tooling/dependency mismatch in the package config rather than runtime app code).

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a failure when trying to apply a patch: every time a user selects an app, picks any patch and taps the Patch button the patch process aborts with an error and no patch is produced. The failure consistently happens during the unpacking/decoding phase and prevents any app from being patched. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/revanced/manager/installer/ApkDecoder.kt (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is a NullPointerException caused by missing null checks when decoding the AndroidManifest.xml (manifest-decoding path) which allowed a null value to be dereferenced and abort the installer.

instruction: In revanced-manager, after installing and opening the app on a Samsung device running Android 13 the app immediately showed a black screen instead of its normal UI. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason that would explain why the app's UI never loaded on launch (what part of the system or app was responsible, and what went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is an external third-party network filter (AdGuard) / environment component (not a repository file) — i.e. AdGuard running on the device that intercepts/blocks network requests. The predicted root cause reason is that the third-party network filtering/AdGuard blocked the app's required local network connections (or DNS/HTTP requests) used during startup (e.g., to the app's local server or resources), preventing the UI/Flutter/WebView content from loading and causing the black screen.

instruction: In the revanced-manager app, selecting a YouTube APK and running the built-in patcher caused the patch operation to fail and abort partway through (the installer started, a working directory was created, the APK was copied and unpacked, dex files were read, and decoding of the AndroidManifest began, but the patching process then terminated). Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason for this failure. Specifically, identify which file/module was changed to fix the abort and state the underlying reason the patcher was failing (what went wrong).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is app/src/main/java/io/revanced/manager/installer/Installer.kt (module: app). The predicted root cause reason is the extracted native patcher binary was not given executable permissions (missing setExecutable), causing the patcher process to fail to run.

instruction: In revanced-manager, there was a bug where a user patched Twitter and attempted to install the patched APK; the install failed, but when they returned to the app dashboard the patched Twitter entry was still shown even though the patched app was never successfully installed. This happened when using the manager to patch and install a non-root app. Your task is to identify the root cause component (the specific file or module that was changed to fix this) and the root cause reason (what went wrong that produced the observed behavior).
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is gradle/libs.versions.toml (Module: gradle.libs.versions.toml). The predicted root cause reason is duplicate/incorrect entries in the Gradle version catalog (duplicate keys for versions such as compose-bom and navigation) which caused incorrect parsing or dependency/version resolution issues.

instruction: In the nym-vpn-client repository/app, there was a failure when a user in Estonia attempted to connect using the 'Fast' connection option: the client reported an unknown/unhandled error and the connection failed. Using the anonymous connection mode worked correctly, while selecting 'Fast' repeatedly failed. Your task is to identify the root cause component and reason
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is nym-client/src/config/gateways.json (the gateways/authenticator configuration used by the client). The predicted root cause reason is a missing authenticator address entry for the selected 'Fast' gateway (i.e., the client could not find an authenticator address in the gateways configuration for the Estonia/Fast gateway), causing the connection to fail.

instruction: In nym-vpn-client, there was an incomplete data removal issue: when a user ran the ForgetAccount command expecting a complete wipe of all account-related data, sensitive files such as credential databases and persistent store backups were left on the device. This violated the app's privacy expectations. Your task is to identify the root cause component (the file or module responsible) and the root cause reason (what went wrong) that allowed those sensitive files to remain after ForgetAccount ran.
scoring_points: The predicted root cause component is nym-vpn-core/crates/nym-vpn-account-controller/src/storage_cleanup.rs (module: nym_vpn_account_controller.storage_cleanup). The predicted root cause reason is that the account cleanup routine failed to remove certain backup/corrupted variants of persistent files (files with appended corrupted suffixes), i.e. missing deletion logic for corrupted/backup credential/persistent store files, so sensitive files were left behind.
